25:35 This is why GMOs are so important to keeping the world's growing population adequately fed. People who are anti-GMO and anti-pesticide simply do not understand how much of our food supply would be wiped out if we didn't take these measures. I'm all for rigorous testing to make sure the final result is safe for human consumption and that there is minimal environmental impact, but people who just want to ban GMOs and pesticides outright are showing their ignorance on the topic. They're also showing their privilege, because the way things always work in times of food shortage is that wealthy countries/people always get priority. The Irish potato famine only really happened because the majority of the crops were taken for export and sale, leaving the locals to starve. If we ban GMOs and pesticides, it won't be the yuppie crunchy moms and organic food nuts who suffer, it'll be the poor people of developing nations who already face food shortages.

Personally, I don't see GMOs as _inherently_ bad, the biggest problem with them is the consequences corporate fuckery can have. If it saves an essential crop, it's worth it. The stakes and practicalities should keep most or all of the applicable corporate fuckery in check (and one common problem isn't applicable anyway because the Cavendish is seedless), the gene shouldn't have any adverse effects I wouldn't think, and worrying about the Cavendish's purity is laughable.

Dave is a treasure for pitting up with this malarkey
the trouble with GMOs is not that they are bad for your health or something--unless something crazy is done to the food, they're perfectly good to eat. The problem is that when companies make GMO crops, they can /patent/ that DNA...and companies like monsanto have historically taken advantage of this fact, creating plants that will not go to seed so that farmers have to keep buying the same seeds year after year. Plus, if nearby crops interbreed with patented GMO crops, that is now basically a copyright violation. So, although GMOs are a neutral or even a very positive innovation on their face, they have been instrumentalized as a way for corporations to extract more profit and more dependency from farmers. In Haiti, during a period of famine, farmers even burned GMO seeds in protest of this practice.

Humans have been modifying their foods for generations, , sprouts, cauliflower, kale and cabbage are all the same plant. As for how red grapefruit was made...
I am so tired of people saying GMO's are bad for you. Well ok if they are then don't eat Broccoli, Peas, Cauliflower, Strawberries, or even the bananas from any era. You see every single one of these have been Genetically Modified by Humans. Oh and dogs...don't have a dog. They are genetically modified as well, and cats...horses, pigs, cows...you see we have been genetically modifying things for literally centuries. It is what is known as "Artificial Selection" (Meaning Nature or Natural forces didn't create this but Humans did through their "choice" or "Selection" of which plants or animals would be allowed to breed with which others)   When one sees a trait in the plant or animal that they want to "replicate" in another with a different "trait" they also desire they selectively breed them together. I.E. A sweet tasting strawberry that is small, and a tart tasting strawberry that is much bigger. They decide they want the sweet taste of the little one but the bigger size of the tart one. Well you would need to make sure that the bigger plant is only pollinated by the sweet tasting little one and keep doing that until you achieve a plant that produces large fruit with a sweet taste. Ta Da this is a Genetically Modified Organism.   There is honestly *nothing* that we eat that has genes to modify that isn't or hasn't been Genetically Modified. The stigma comes from when scientist do it quickly and efficiently in the lab; instead of taking years of the painstakingly slow process of plucking the pollen from the stamen of one plant and depositing it onto the pistol of the other, or through decades of breeding animals. This is just the "Artificially Selected" GMO's we haven't even talked about the "Naturally Selected" GMO's that is everything else.   You see *EVERYTHING* that has genes are even now being Genetically Modified because of Evolution (The process by which all life is diversified) this is because Evolution is by it's very definition the Modification of Genetics through slight mutations during the replication process. So it doesn't matter if a Scientist modifies bananas in a lab in Australia, or a monk from a monastery in 18th century Austria planting and observing sweet peas, or a Rancher in Texas breeds a more beefier cow, or Nature through some freak storm or a harsh winter creates a more hardier strain of wheat. *ALL* life is Genetically Modified because that is the process through which genes express themselves.  Stop with the GMO label, it is a bull$#!+ buzzword that literally applies to everything living on Earth; ergo *NOTHING* in your grocer is "Non-GMO" save minerals, chemicals, and water.

1:20 ‚Äú‚Äòtime lapse‚Äô or stop motion for a few days‚Äù is the cleanest, funniest shade I‚Äôve heard in eonsüòÇ
I know this is an older video but I'm very passionate about GMOs. Genetic modification isn't some scary thing like people who don't know better make it out to be! The scariest thing about GMOs are the companies who sell GMO seeds that are infertile, meaning the plants grown from those seeds will not produce viable seeds or seeds at all- making the farmers dependent on them (some companies have been known to lock these farmers into contracts to only grow from their seeds, too). A great example of how food has been genetically modified can be shown from visuals in this video! The wild bananas have been genetically modified via selective breeding by our ancestors through selective breeding! Any new varieties of plants/breeds of animals that have been bred selectively for different traits (including dogs- prime examples of selective breeding) are, in fact, genetically modified organisms (GMOs)! When done right- not making the plants infertile, MORE susceptible to disease/pests, locking people into contracts, or, in the case of animals, decreasing their quality of life- GMOs are GOOD things, or at least neutral things. Cattle being bred to have healthier udders and produce more milk in a way that doesn't decrease their QOL? A good thing as less cows are needed to produce the same amount of milk- saving space, feed, and their natural impact on the environment. A way to modify banana varieties to be more resistant to a devastating disease? A good thing as there can be more varieties grown at larger scales- giving us all more flavors to enjoy, the locals most importantly as well as having more genetic diversity in bananas in any given area- increasing their chances of surviving other diseases or new strains! Chickens who lay higher quality and quantity of eggs in a way that does not decrease their QOL? A good thing for the same reasons as cattle. Want potatoes with edible berries? Theoretically possible with selective breeding to stop them from containing solanine- the reason why they're poisonous- opening them up to be a potential viable food source. Ok long rant over but GMOs aren't some scary, nebulous thing that's making food somehow bad for you to eat. The only problem with them right now are the companies with bad practices that harm the farmers they sell to (which is a valid reason to not like GMOs, don't get me wrong)

The banana plantation/processing video is from the Philippines and is mostly intended for the export market.  The majority of locally sold ones from the markets aren't pretty and full of small little black spots or have some bruises but are perfectly good inside. The flawless ones are either exported or sold in hotels, restaurants, convenience stores and supermarkets at a premium price.  About Cavendish being endangered by Panama disease, we have here a dozen or so varieties of bananas and plantains (mostly for cooking) and we don't really rely on cavendish bananas for everyday consumption as it is too expensive for most Filipinos.

Here's my take on GMOs: I don't think combining genes from two breeds of the same species is a huge problem. It's the same species; you could probably achieve the same effect with old-fashioned breeding. My issue is the stuff I've read about DNA from *insects* being put into *plants*, or, as someone else mentioned, Monsanto making Round-Up Ready crops whose seeds farmers can't save and that cross-pollinate with other farmers' crops (due to Monsanto being able to sue for "patent reasons"). Mixing two types of natural banana is no big deal, but the rest of it? That's another story.   Thanks for the awesome video and information! :)
I didn't think much about GMOs, but then I saw GMO advocates condescending to the laymen with the absurd line, "Selective breeding is a type of genetic modification, therefore you're ignorant if you don't want us directly playing with the DNA of your food!"  Plus since it turns out the GMO companies deliberately produce infertile seeds to keep farmers reliant on the GMO companies, it seems like pro-GMO is effectively the morally bankrupt position. Especially as GMO advocates will accuse their critics of not caring about feeding the hungry. That's openly immoral. Doing something bad, pretending you're not by conflating it with something good or neutral, and claiming the moral high ground over the people who are opposed to you doing something bad; that's a pretty pure form of evil.

I really loathe the anti-GMO sentiment. All of our food is genetically modified.  Your only real options are these:  Eat food that was genetically modified over millennia or centuries through selective breeding and hybridization by people who didn't _really_ understand what they were doing, and are rendered safe simply by many generations of people not suffering or dying because of the ones that were successful.  Eat food that was genetically modified over months or years by laboratories that know _exactly_ what they're doing and why, that are rendered safe by (hopefully) rigorous scientific testing.  That's it. There is no other food, unless you want to subsist only on hunted game and foraged wild plants.  If you _truly_ don't want to eat food that's been genetically tampered with by humans in one way or the other, then an ear of corn would look like a blade of grass with an extra-large seed inside... 'cause that's what corn was before we modified it.  Actually, as we got better and better, and more conscious of _what_ we were doing, with the old method of hybridizing and selectively breeding our food plants and animals, we've created some truly unfortunate results, such as most modern tomatoes being very pretty and almost tasteless, and devoid of a lot of the micronutrients you can find in heirloom varieties. Now, with direct genetic editing, we're starting to put _back_ the flavor and nutrition that we took away by faffing about without as much direct understanding.  I don't understand why people are against GMOs. I can only assume, based on most of the erroneous trends and tropes from the 20th century, that at some point lobbyists and politicians on the take were involved... just like the SAD, the war on fat rather than carbs that's created the pandemics of obesity and diabetes, the war on salt, the war on aspartame, the war on drugs... America likes wars. All the wars.

Hi Ann!  I've been living in Cambodia for 9 years and this has baffled me, why is the world so set on Cavendish regardless its risks of getting wiped out? In Cambodia we've got several different species of bananas. KH: Check Pong Moan (EN: Chicken egg banana) [lat. Musa Aromatica, later debunked to be Lady Finger Banana] is the sweetest one, then there is a species that isn't as sweet and fragrant as Check Pong Moan, but good for eating as is or cooked into deserts etc. The species with largest hands looks really nice on a buddhist altar (often completely green), but I've never seen those consumed nor yellowing. Some BBQ joints serve raw, sliced banana to be eaten with the meat (the raw banana slices have really firm flesh that is fused to the peel and tastes extremely bitter.) Loved this vid, but ‚Äúcooked bananas are no good‚Äù - whaaa? Slice a firm, barely ripe, just out of green banana lengthwise into 4-5 slices. Fry them in butter until they brown nicely, getting barely darkish brown at the edges. Somehow that develops the sugars until they are like candy, which is why they were my favorite dessert as a kid. They can even develop little caramelly bits if you get them just right, yum.
Hey Ann! This is Ananya from India. There is a saying in Bengali that banana is an incredible plant, one of which we use everything, from stems to leaves, the roots that are used for toothaches, and of course the fruit. So there is no part of Banana that us Indians and Bengalis throw away. The leaves are used as serving dishes, ine that's very eco friendly and can be used as a substitute for plates. We also use the leaves to cook dishes, like the famous "Bhekti or Ilish macher Paturi". The stems and the flowers are used in many dishes. The stems are called "thor" in bengali and the flowers are called "mocha". As for the fruit, we cook it and make incredible dishes when raw and of course eat it as it is, when ripe and sweet. As of the Banana peel Bengalis actually have a banana peel recipe! We mash the skins of raw or green bananas into a pasta and cook it with spices into a dish that we eat with rice. It's known as "kacha kola khoshar bata" in Bengali. If you search it up on Youtube you would find plenty of Bengali recipes for the dish.

On the GMO issue, I am not opposed as long as the genetic origins are revealed for every change, so if the GMO bananas are identified as being modified with genes from another species of banana, I am ok. I think Roundup has a lot to answer for in terms of people being anti-GMO. Also I am leery because I have multiple food allergies. I need to know what is in the food I eat. For example, supposedly highly refined soybean oil is safe for me (I am allergic to soy), but the hives I get the day after tell a very different story.
The reason the banana thing was bad for plants is because most plants actually don't like lots of water being constantly on their roots. They get a disease called root rot. Plants usually prefer moist soil, not drenched. It can also happen if they're in a pot that doesn't drain so they're in a swamp, but since a banana has a lot of water in it, putting a plant directly into it is bad for it.
3:38 lol you can clearly see where they attached the roots, they are not even trying to hide the knot
GMOs are generally a great tool and this is a great example of how we can use them. The real issue at play here is that modern agriculture is highly dependent on monocultures and a few optimized breeds of both plants and animals and this makes it extremely vulnerable to both disease and environmental change. Agriculture needs to become more diverse and start incorporating modern knowledge about ecosystems in order to become more sustainable. At the same time this fungi demonstrates the importance of leaving land wild and uncultivated, we were only able to find a solution by borrowing the genetic diversity of wild nature but what if next time the piece of jungle with the resistent plant has been cut down?  GMOs like anything else are a tool and are not inherently bad or good, at their worst they can prop up unsustainable agriculture but at their best they can be part of a sustainable future and combat famine and climate change itself.

why don't they put the panama resistant gene into the big mike banana?
My husband and I used farm bananas in South Africa. We had Cavendish mostly, but because of the Panama problem, which was not in our area, but was in an area fairly close by, we started planting a variety called Williams, which was resistant to Panama.  These we purchased from the University in Pietermaritzburg, where they were propergated by cell culture. The only drawback was that the plants were very tall and it was difficult to harvest the bunches, which weigh an average of 25kilos, including the stem. I wonder if the variety you were talking about  is a Williams, or a newer variety. In South Africa, at that time, if Panama was found on your plantation, it was the law that your plantation had to be replanted with another crop, which went a long way towards containing the problem.  Sadly, though, a lot of farmers did go bankrupt.  It is very expensive to replant an entire plantation.

I could make a list that has thousands upon thousands of items that people don't realize are GMOs. GMOs are not deadly and don't affect our health at all. It is basically just taking an organism and changing one tiny part of one tin protein. It has nothing to do with anything that can harm you. People are ridiculous sometimes.

Speaking of citrus, while it doesn‚Äôt change anything, I am reminded of another obscure reference, from a period where the science (the name of the gas) wasn‚Äôt so important:  ‚ÄúSuds In Your Eye‚Äù (series, 6 books) by Mary Lasswell, in I believe the first book, from 1943, in San Diego where the story takes place.  Here, three old women move in together to deal with noxious family and homelessness in the face of inflated war housing prices.  One character, Mrs. Rasmussen, is a great cook and is forever finding ways to stretch a war-penny, and in one bit of advice she says to put wax at the stem end of a grapefruit, then store them in a cool, dry place, not touching each other and they‚Äôll ‚Äúkeep forever‚Äù.  No doubt, the ethylene here serves the same purpose as with the avocados, to signal time to separate from the tree, but hey!  Also, I don‚Äôt think your Aussie example of genetically modified bananas to get past Panama disease is a bad example of GMO, it parallels grafting English walnuts onto black walnut root stock here in Ca as English walnut trees can‚Äôt grow in our soil.  GMO nasties are Cargill and Monsanto genetically modifying plants grown in monoculture not so they can produce more food or deal with warmer weather but instead to stand up to Cargill and Monsanto pesticides used on those fields;  then the farmer is also contractually bound to buy ONLY C or M seed stock as well.

14:18
The reason we had the Gros Michel, was that it was the first banana to be hybridized to a degree of getting rid of the seeds. AND every plant was raised from a cutting, so they were all CLONES of that original. Later, when the first mold/blight destroyed them, the world scrambled and managed to hybridize the Cavendish to diminish the seeds (because it had them, too... AND eventually we rebuilt an economy on them, even though we gave up the flavor of the Gros Michel... AND exactly like the Gros Michel, the Cavendish bananas of today are clones, raised from cuttings of the original plants developed in a small operation...       AND I was concerned that we'd just move to the next variety that would be resistant or immune to this blight/mold EXACTLY as we had last time... It's somewhat refreshing to see that a positive (at least for the moment) result seems to be happening with a modification to the Cavendish, and a new strain of Cavendish might at least prop up the bananas...       I wonder how much that's going to cost the producers, and who's going to suffer between stock-holders in the industrial farms, the employees who are almost never treated well, and the consumers who very rightly throw fits over the outrageous costs of food versus their own income that never seems to rise with the so-called "inflation" so constantly blamed with the price gouging that carries on worldwide with every suspiciously artificial crisis whether it's related or not...        As to my own reservations on GMO's... I don't trust the likes of Monsanto, 3M, Dupont or any of the monopoly-driven industrialists who are big enough and with deep enough pockets to do anything with all the patent rights they can procure for every new GMO strain they can develop...        Yeah, okay, in the old days, crops were modified by selective breeding and planting practices. It was fine for farmers to just keep a reserve of seeds from their fields on hand, instead of selling out ALL their inventory at harvest time. Certain fruits, vegetables, and grains (especially) were stocked and held for the following year, and through winters and into early spring, those seeds were specifically sought out, treated as needs be, dried and then sewn during the appropriate part of planting season... Seedmills were even an invention to help advance the ease of doing exactly that, well into the 20th century...         Now, Monsanto's pretty notorious about it, but all the seed giants that have hybrids and new strains have specifically targeted farmers from the "old school" who work HARD to maintain their own stocks and reserves for every planting season. From suing them outright for "theft of intellectual property" because nobody can stop the bees or winds from cross pollenating one field with material from another, and the industrialists absolutely can NOT leave subsistance or any other kind of "competitor" alone... ALL THE WAY to actually outright attacking, threatening, and committing VIOLENCE on these people to stop them from using the seedmills.        OH YEAH, GMO's in this one instance are helping preserve a LOT of jobs on industrial farms where employees are thankful to be overworked, underpaid, treated like garbage, and threatened with their already meager wages to be docked for taking too many breaks so they sh*t in the g** d*** fields. HOOORAAAY!      Don't tell me you wondered how E. Coli (which is found in OUR OWN intestines naturally) keeps contaminating lettuce and other leafy greens...        BUT historically, they've been marketed as "the great future of pest resistant crops for everybody" by the Corporates, while the ACTUAL results are farmers being driven entirely out of business and off their land over something they OUTRIGHT REFUSED to buy or participate in... Why??? So the stockholders can get even MORE that they don't deserve... A family farm operated by pure sweat and old-school methods simply isn't ALLOWED to be viable... It doesn't profit the giants and their stockholders through New York, so they gotta go... AND GMO's WILL PUSH THAT WAY.         Eat up! Enjoy! When that piece of asparagus costs your soul, don't bitch at me...   ;o)

Literally every food is genetically modified. Heck, your dogs and cats are genetically modified. A part of genetic modification is selective breeding for desirable traits. The bananas that we consume, the Cavendish, are drastically different from other wild bananas. The seeds are almost entirely gone, the peel is softer, and most of them are basically clones of one another. This is from taking the ancestor of these bananas, seeing what we liked, and inbreeding them till we got what we wanted. All delicious without any hard seeds to crack your teeth against. Basically maximizeing what you can eat, and minimizing what you can‚Äôt, aka turning it into a crop through genetic modification. Comparing a banana that hasn‚Äôt been turned into a crop with a crop banana is like looking at entirely different plants, like all crops and dogs.¬†Selective breeding takes years and years, gmos are basically the same process but sped up in a lab with modern tech.  GMOs aren‚Äôt going to kill you, they aren‚Äôt going to twist your dna like your dog isn‚Äôt going to. What will harm you and your local ecosystems are the literal chemical poisons we call pesticides. Which are actually twisting the biology of local wildlife. And actually endangering our entire planet. But we don‚Äôt want to talk about that. Just how people don‚Äôt like that their tomato‚Äôs are larger than 5 years ago, and it didn‚Äôt take decades.
GMO feeds the world. It is not bad, in fact nearly everything marked non-GMO was modified many generations ago and are now excepted as the standard to not modify. Heritage plants and seeds will produce a crop that looks nothing like the non-GMO cash crops of today‚Äôs farmers. It was done to make plants disease  resistant so that the farmer uses less chemicals in productions. That brings us to whether we want GMO or heavily laced chemical  non-GMO crops. GMO wins hands down.

I think that the GMO conversation is often one that lacks subtlety. Technically all forms of agriculture engage in genetically modifying plants. Historically, the process was done in a field, rather than a lab, by those choosing which plants to continue to propagate. What the gentleman has done with the bananas can be considered a positive thing. When seeds are modified to a point where they are changed in size, texture and no longer have flavor or the same level of nutritional value but look lovely, that is a serious problem. Truthfully, I believe the concept of GMOs should be handled on a case by case basis. Intention and affect on those that eat these foods should absolutely matter. There are so very many negative things that have been done with and to our food that GMOs are boogeymen now. There is good reason behind that reputation. But context is hugely important as well.

In order to get new foods before genetic manipulation was available food plants were exposed to ionizing radiation. This produced thousands of genetic mutations in the plant, those that were suitable for cultivation were preserved and cultivated along with thousands of unknown genetic alterations of unpredictable consequences. So a human manipulation of one gene is bad but we've been eating random radiation induced mutations of unknown quality and quality for for years without even realizing it. But hey frankenfood bad.

Clicking a link now, in an article that is several years old, and showing it leads to a 404 does a great disservice to the article. Instead, you should use something like the wayback machine to see if those old urls existed in addition to just clicking the link. This is because sites migrate and links change, and some things get removed or moved to completely different link structures. Unless it is a doi, don't expect a link from 10 years ago to still work fine.  The first link is to a paper, better referenced by its DOI: 10.1016/S0925-5214(03)00103-0 This did not discuss ethylene, and instead was focused on polyphenol oxidase and phenylalanine ammonia lyase in banana peel. But it did have references which discussed ethylene.  The second is a link to NSW department of education and training on the completely different topic of enzymatic browning of apples.  The third provides perhaps the best way to keep bananas fresh (indirectly). It describes how the production of ethylene degrades chlorophyll and results in the fruit ripening, and that bananas are harvest immature, and they are treated with ethylene shortly before being shipped to stores to induce ripening. So if instead we bought immature bananas and treated them with ethylene ourselves, that would help with keeping them "fresh".
here's the reason why i typically don't *hate* anti gmo talk: Monsanto. this company is evil. straight up evil. they copyright their seeds, then they plant crops in a way that they are almost certain to spread in the wind. THEN they are about to seize any farmland that happened to grow some of those copyrighted seeds! horrendous what they are doing to privately owned and/or sustainable farming practices.
I am definitely in favor of GMOs in this usage. Especially if the modified plant is not gate-kept for profit of one company or country but access is freely given to the people of the world. After all, it‚Äôs to avert the mass death of a plant that we all want to keep alive do we can benefit from its food. I‚Äôm also in favor of GMOs developed to promote crop diversity and biodiversity, potentially protect native plants, increase nutrition of existing foodstuffs, cultivate food in places where we couldn‚Äôt before to combat hunger and improve local community resilience, etc. I go get a bit sad when GMO crops are used as a tool for one for-profit company to monopolize a market or keep their customers locked-in to repurchasing only from them, prevent farmers from propagating their plants, etc.
This is why it's so important that we're all learning proper information from reputable sources about GMOs. People talk about genetically-modified food as if it's necessarily bad for us and the environment, but that couldn't be further from the truth. Many foods are modified to make them more resistant to fungus and pests, meaning the crops need fewer pesticides and anti-fungal chemicals, and less back-breaking work for the farmers. Some can also be made to thrive with less water, so that's good. Others can be grown in poorer-quality soil or different environments, and with larger crop yields, hopefully meaning less deforestation. A type of rice has been modified to have vitamin A, meaning a lot less deficiency in communities that previously may not have had access to vitamin A-rich foods. GMOs have so much potential if there is proper regulation and oversight.

When I was a child in the 1950s, it was the custom to always peel the banana, and then to cut off the top and the bottom of the banana inside. Not sure if it was mentioned yet, but regarding the banana disease, this is the reason why banana flavoring doesn't really taste like bananas. It was based on the kind of banana that was pretty much wiped out (on an export level at least) and the new (well current) type tastes different.   I always wondered why they never made flavoring based on the current type. Or maybe they did and it was just not a thing where I lived.

My house is pretty cold in the winter and bananas take forever to ripen. Maybe store them in a cold spot to preserve them a bit longer?
Your fridge is just 3 degrees? Why? My fridge is 6 degrees, which saves tons of energy (good for the climate and saves money; as you need 5% more energy per one degree less temperature). 6 degree is cold enough to keep your food fresh for over a week and if you plan to keep food way longer than that, you need to freeze it anyway as then even a fridge at 2 degrees wouldn't do the trick then. Note that the temperature you set, 6 degree in my case, is only the average temperature, so it will be lower at the bottom (around 4-5) and higher at the top (around 6-8) and even more in the door area (8-10, which keeps butter spreadable and drinks drinkable directly from the fridge).
Cooked banana is not bad at all when done right. Peel the banana, cut it in half lengthwise. Heat up a pan, melt some butter in it and add some sliced almonds. When the almonds start to get some color, put in the banana halves, let them fry a bit in the butter, then cover everything with honey and make sure the honey gets heated up. Serve while still warm, combines very well with chocolate ice cream üòã

20:26 The point of the experiment is to see if covering the stem affects ripening, but the setup of the test already assumes it doesn't. This means the results will be identical regardless of whether the stem affects it or not, completely invalidating the experiment

People who are against genetically-modified food are ignorant and stupid, plain and simple. There's no getting around it with arguments of "personal preference," because it's the exact same situation as vaccines; it doesn't matter what a person _feels_ when they are objectively wrong. Genetically-modified crops are, by design, superior to unmodified ones in literally every possible way. They produce higher yield, use less space, take less resources, taste better, _and_ are more nutritious. Because you need less space, you need less trucks and tractors, which means less fuel consumption, and less pesticides, all of which is good for the environment. Because you produce higher yield using less resources, it's more efficient for farmers, and more food is available overall, meaning farmers benefit _and_ starvation is reduced. Without the benefits of genetically-modified crops, modern human society could not exist the way it does. There is absolutely _zero_ justification for being against it.

GMO has helped conserve agriculture and countless farmer economies, on a large scale, it benefits the populous greatly.

The heebie jeevies about GMO products is much ado about nothing. LIke you mentioned, the natural banana isn't palatable to us, so what did humans do? We genetically modified it. We didn't go in and change the genetics, but a farmer found a mutant plant that had little to no seeds and cultivated it. Same thing happened to apples and corn. Nothing we eat today has escaped the touch of humans messing with genetics. The idea that suddenly things are worse because we can now precisely edit the specific genes we want is lunacy.

I have no problem with GMOs if that means that the food itself wouldn't exist without modification.
I think people's aversions to GMOs is very similar to the topic that was covered previously about people being averse to "chemicals" in food, even if that chemical is just the scientific name for baking soda. Nearly everything we eat has GMOs in some way. Crackers, cookies, cereals, condiments, etc, so many have GMOs somewhere in their processing. Even things like bread and pasta. And more often than not it's things like this where fruits have been genetically modified to have a longer shelf life or something has been modified in another way to make things better or more convenient for us. Personally I have nothing against GMOs in general - I eat oreos, a scientifically bigger apple isn't going to hurt me any more than an oreo is. But in this case not only does it safe a favored fruit, it saves the livelihood of so many people. When it's framed like that, the US's aversion to GMOs feels trivial, frivolous, and privileged. We so often take for granted that our grocery stores will just have the things we need and want, with little thought as to how they get there. If genetically modifying bananas keeps them in stores for everyone and keeps their farmers employed and fed, I say bring on the science.

I do think an answer to plant diseases is making countries grow more local heritage varieties of bananas rather than impose a monoculture of cavendish ones around the world as monocultures make the plant more vulnerable to disease and has a wider impact (even can become extinct).  That way, even if a disease does take hold in one variety, several countries will have other varieties of the fruit to fall back on. You *can‚Äôt* do the experiment like that! Because the ethylene gas from the control banana that doesn‚Äôt have it‚Äôs end covered is going to affect *all* the other bananas and therefore they‚Äôre all going to get ripened because if those two bananas. üò†

Absolutely no problem whatsoever with GM foods - we do that anyway when we selectively breed and graft new organisms. Direct gene editing is just more controlled and targeted. I think there are precautions to take, to mitigate against unforeseen consequences (like the plant spreading *too* well and choking out native flora). Treat it like a pharmaceutical development stages:       Step 1: Discovery and Development.     Step 2: Preclinical Research.     Step 3: Clinical Research.     Step 4: FDA Drug Review.     Step 5: FDA Post-Market Drug Safety Monitoring. In any case, we need a system and regulation which avoids monoculture plantations - We need to build far greater resilience into our food staples. The fact that Cavendish has grown so ubiquitous is already a systemic failure.

a few things, one being that bananas are already genetically modified to not have seeds in em. the majority of the vegetables we eat today are genetically modified over centuries to breed out bad traits and keep good ones. a lot of people have this image of some shady scientist in a lab coat idk, doing freakish things to food when in reality genetically modifying the food we grow and eat has been done for centuries. i mean how else do people think we can eat stuff like almonds or potatoes without them poisoning us? come on!! i really hate the scaremongering and ignorance around stuff like "chemicals" and "gmos", it is so unhelpful and ignorant of the way things actually work.  about that extinct banana species, artificial banana flavoring in candies and stuff is based on that long extinct banana which i think is interesting, like that flavor is based on a long dead fruit, a flavor ghost!  whenever i have leftover bananas that are too ripe or black i peel them and put them in zip top freezer bags to save for banana bread or cake, etc. the most intense sweet banana flavor is when they're that ripe so they're absolutely perfect for banana bread!!
I used to work in a supermarket. At one stage I worked on produce. Bananas was one job no one liked to do... Except me for some reason. They came in boxes wrapped in plastic. When we unwrapped them they would be soaking wet from the humidity of the bananas inside a plastic bag. The smell was like bananas on steroids. The water from the bananas would make your hands feel very strange. When we put the bananas on display they would be green. Within a few hours they would change to yellow. Generally keeping them sealed up in the box was the best way to keep them in a better condition. However they didn't sell very well from a sealed box in the warehouse. One thing we were not allowed to do was to put them in the chiller. As it turned the skin brown. While this video shows that it is still edible the general rule of thumb on produce was that if you wouldn't eat it people won't buy it. There were daily checks for quality that we had to complete. Anything with bruises or skin going wrinkly was removed from sale. Bananas did make up a decent amount of our waste. However the waste was sent for anaerobic digestion. The gas was used to power one  of the companies depots fleet of delivery trucks.  Great video Ann I have been watching your channel for a couple of years now. Keep up the great work!  Actually I almost forgot about the exotic spiders. We had a few huntsman spiders as well as a couple of tarantulas. Sadly they got put in the freezer. As this was in the UK and they were essentially illegal aliens.

Fun info about cavendish bananas: they are triploid (have 3 sets of chromosomes) which makes them unable to reproduce sexually. As a result, all of the cavendish bananas are clones of each other (have the same gene). This lack of genetic diversity was probably why they were so un-resistant to a certain environmental threat (fungi). However, if they can reproduce sexually then they would apparently have the seeds and you can't eat them anymore. So it seems like GMO is the only solution :).
Oh! I know some of this about bananas! The Cavendish bananas that we eat are basically like mules. They're hybrids that are infertile and can only reproduce as genetic copies! There are multiple kinds of wild banana and the ones with massive seeds and little flesh actually have a good taste and are cross bred with something that has small seeds and lots of flesh but taste horrible to produce something good with nearly no seeds because it's not capable of reproduction!

In relation to that extinct banana variety that was replaced by the cavendish:   If you've ever wondered why a piece of what is ostensibly supposed to be banana-flavored candy doesn't taste quite like a banana that's because it's trying to approximate the taste of the cavendish's predecessor, not the cavendish itself.

I'd personally find a spliced gene that makes the plant more resistant to a fungus much less worrying than the widespread use of a hypothetical new fungacide, even assuming that GMOs are as dangerous as their detractors claim.
GMOs get simplified a lot as an issue. They are an ecological and farmer's rights issue. Unfortunately, the patent abuse by big corporations and the risk of a GMO strain becoming invasive, as with corn, tend to get overshadowed by fearmongering or those determined to debunk the fearmongering. GMOs aren't inherently bad, but the "ooh, eating GMOs sounds scary" argument is basically used because trying to explain patent abuse or the problems with yellow corn tends to make people's eyes glaze over.

Volume too low
Anne, I think I am too late to comment on this, but I just wanted to point out a few things about the future of bananas. There has been so much lot of panic-inducing misinformation circulating around, and I really want to convey this to you. There are actually many non-Cavendish cultivars of banana that are actually edible - in fact many of them are tastier than the Cavendish cultivar, like many varieties of red bananas, my favourites. The reason why Cavendish is mass produced and exported is not necessarily because it tastes better than others, but because it is more resistant to bruises and therefore is cheaper to transport. So even if Cavendish goes extinct, we WILL still have many cultivars that can be eaten. We will need to make some adjustments in order change to a different cultivar of bananas, but it is not the end of the world for bananas. In fact, if you are in one of the countries where bananas are locally grown and eaten (like Sri Lanka, where I spent most of my formative years), Cavendish is often everyone's least favourite variety of bananas.

As someone whose family owns orange farms, i can say that anti gmo people are whacks with no common sense.
GMO's are nothing to be scared of. Genetic modification of PLANTS (not living animals) can add increased nutrition to established crops (Such as rice and wheat) and in the case here, prevent an entire domesticated species of plants from being wiped out. We also have genetically modified cultivars of fruits and vegetables to be frost resistant, drought resistant, and have natural deterrents for insects.   People think GMO's make the crops bigger but that's a load of whooey; we have, for thousands of years, been selectively breeding for big, plus we do pump quite a bit of fertilizer into conventional crops (Which is a whole 'nother issue!)

Everyone take a moment to appreciate Dave for being the Guinea pig. I need a man who will also try all my weird cooking experiments.
About the chocolate stuck into a banana in the microwave: In Switzerland it's a fairly common campfire desert to make a cut into the peel (on the inner side of the bend), push in some pieces of chocolate. Then either put as is on a grill grate or wrap in aluminium foil and put them right on top of the embers if you don't have a grill grate.  Then just leave it for a couple of minutes and eat it with a spoon. I think if done well it's very tasty (I do like the flavour of cooked, ripe bananas) and it's a practical desert for a hike, since it's easy to bring bananas and chocolate with you. But I see little to no reason to do it at home in a microwave. If you're at home there are so many other options for deserts.
I don‚Äôt care. Food is food and food is good
The people worried about GMOs don't understand how agriculture works. Unless you eat exclusively wild game and wild fruits and vegetables, nothing on your plate hasn't been genetically modified. This is just a faster, more modern, method than selective breeding.

HAPPY BANANAS üçå:  This is the one trick that keeps bananas living longer, tasting better,  without much bruising either.  Turn the bunch upsidedown like a rainbow and putting the cut from the tree parts in a bowl of water (that won't tip over ) and leave them like a house plant. Just cut the one off you want ( it will be tough!) When you want one. They still get sweet like the banana bread flavor sweet but not all the ugly bruising. I started with a yellow bunch and my last banana lasted to day ten, minimal bruising on the peel and just a small bruise on the inside. Wish I could post pictures to show that it does work. I think the bananas are happier. They are drinking the whole time. üòä

The recipe you tried with the chocolate peices in the cooked banana is actually one of my family's favorite summer desserts, but we cook ours differently.  We peel back the peel on a triangle piece on top of the banana but don't take it completely off, then we cut a piece out of the banana like they do, and we fill the hole in the banana with chocolate chips and marshmallows, sometimes the nephews and nieces do cut up candy bars with nuts or caramel or even cookies.  Then we replace the peice of banana back on top the chocolate, place the peel back on top the banana, wrap the entire banana in foil and grill it on the barbeque for a few minutes.  On our grill, it only takes about 2 minutes per side, but as each grill is different, it might be different on someone elses.  You want the banana warm, but not cooked so much that it becomes liquid mush like the recipe in the video.  you can eat it by itself like that or add ice cream on top depending on your mood. When you actually think of it, pretty much everything we eat is GMO in one form or another.  Humanity has spent the last ten thousand years selectively breeding food crops and animals to be more suitable to our needs or wants.  It's just that up until very recently we've had to do it through old fashioned and imprecise unnatural selection.  My problem with GMOs is not the genetic modifications themselves, with the right precautions (which we already know) we can make sure they're safe, but with capitalism.  Unfortunately, under the current economic system ownership of the rights, patents and other intellectual properties surrounding GMOs will devolve down to a monopoly or oligopoly of private businesses who only care about extracting their pound of flesh as quickly as possible even if it dooms much of the world to permanent food poverty.

so the leaf in a banana in water is kinda stupid, but if you just get rid of the banana, that specific plant can easily grow new roots. besides, the root they showed in their video was an aerial root, those literaly dont even need water, they are just anchors to the plant. it is however important that you do cut the leaf beneath a node, so you have to have a piece of branch still attached to the leaf stem, otherwise it will just wither like it did in your video.
Regarding the gardening hacks bananas are a great sourcs of potassium for your plants but they also need other types pf nutrients. Potassium helps your plant flower (for example if your tomato isnt flowering but has a lot of leaves add some banana peels) but with only potassium the plant will suffocate and wont grow anything so greenery no flowers no fruit.

Honestly never understood where genetically modified plants got their bad reputation from (at least food wise). Like, the dna of things you eat don't affect your own dna (which some people seem to believe, idk), and GMO plants just don't do that either. The biggest issue I see is that with making those plants more resistant, faster growing etc etc you could heavily influence the biodiversity of the area they grow in. Which can be a huge issue, but it's a different issue than the "is it save to eat" question. Personally I'm all for GMO crops as they help stabilize food supply and also can help cutting down on the use of pesticides. And idk about you, but I rather have GMO plants with way less pesticides sprayed on them than "pure" (aka selectively bred) plants which require the use of a lot of those pesticides to actually be profitable to grow.

Using our technology to create a GMO of a food to protect it from disease and protect our food supply doesn't seem that bad in my opinion. I am opposed to GMO when it is used to do things like increase yields, make larger or more attractive products, and basically anything that is done to make a crop more profitable. Money and greed can cause companies to overlook health concerns if they can see a clear raise in profits. Even worse I fear that health risks may not be studied at all when creating a GMO. So even though the use of GMOs are a scary topic for our future I don't personally oppose making it a GMO if it is being used to save our crop from extinction. Back after a year. In my opinion, GMOs are usually fine. If you genetically modify a banana to become resistant to a fungus that would wipe out the crop entirely and reduce jobs and a common everyday food that most people eat then yeah, it's great. But GMOs like in GloFish (a genetically modified fish) where a gene makes them glow under blacklight can also have adverse effects. Many glofish bettas are virtually blind because of their light, green eyes which aren't able to capture 3D objects and light as well. Being blind certainly isn't better than seeing...  So, it depends. If it's created to help then we should wholeheartedly believe in using GMOs, but if they're created for looks like in glofish which causes issues then we should avoid them. Thoughts?

As a future plant scientist and breeder, GMOs have their ups and downs. On the positive end as stated in the video they help preserve the current farming practices when it comes to pest resistance and also adaptation to the changing environment. Especially in Cavendish bananas, the plant cannot produce viable seeds which are able to breed, so all bananas are clonaly propagated, meaning that basically all bananas are identical genetically and therefore are susceptible to the same parasites. GMOs would help in protecting the bananas we all know and love, especially since the market is so resistant in trying new foods. On the negative end, GMOs could have a negative impact on the environment, which is why it is mainly banned in most of EU countries. Certain genetic changes may affect the indigenous wild type of that plant altering the natural environment.

Old video I know, but people who are anti GMO shouldn't really eat bananas at all because Cavendish bananas and their almost extinct predecessors exist entirety because of genetic modification and inbreeding. The reason it's so easy for an entire plantation to get infected after one plant is infected is because bananas are so inbred their all almost genetically the same, so the infection spreads like wildfire. This is true of a lot of fruits and vegetables but none to the extent of bananas. The entire reason the Gros Michel banana almost went extinct and still hasn't recovered is because of how genetically similar they are. You'd think after the world's supply of Gros Michel bananas almost went extinct we'd learn to allow some genetic variety in our bananas, but no, we are simple minded and only care about taste and fruit yield so as long as we're getting the best taste and the most fruit, we'd risk losing the entire species. That said, the Gros Michel does still grow in some third world countries but unless you're willing to blow $60 to $100 dollars for a small bunch or "hand" then you probably won't have the luxury of tasting them, aside from when you eat anything with artificial banana flavoring because that taste is modeled after the Gros Michel not the Cavendish.

I'm not against genetically modified foods when its done in the interest of preserving a species, reducing the strain on soils, extending shelf-life of a product, and addressing global food shortages. in fact I think of it like this: we modify our bodies all the time with chemicals (from the complex vaccine to the simple caffeinated beverage) for health and safety and increased viability, so the logical reasoning is there. what's important is that GMOs are strictly regulated to safeguard against shady practices and unethical experimentation

Pretty much everything we currently eat is a GMO. Wheat, corn, and rice all have naturally occurring plants, but we don't grow those and haven't for centuries. The naturally occurring variation don't produce nearly as many grains or kernels. Our ancestors modified them to make them more profitable to grow and to feed more people.  I'm willing to admit that harsh pesticides and excessive antibiotics can affect our food, but for the most part GMO'S do gene splicing. It is simply a more advanced approach to what our forefathers did when they switched from hunter gatherers to agrarian societies.

Cavendish bananas would not exist if it weren't for genetic modification, people need to be less worried about the very natural process of making a fruit/vegetable/melon, what have you, more edible (or edible at all in the case of bananas and watermelon) and more worried about the amount of chemical preservatives and addictive substances (sugar, salt, and fat) in the food.  The mass-production scheme of the fatally wealthy is also a way to spread life threatening conditions (diabetes due to high sugar, hypertension due to high salt and obesity due to high fat) to low income communities by bottlenecking our food supply. Healthy food is expensive, unhealthy food is cheap. It's a real problem that not enough people acknowledge.
The plant hacks are cloning and techniques, the bananas and watermelon are high in sugar so good for quick starting roots and seeds. The problems were... The chilli: It needed to be opened, the seeds needed to be exposed to air and sunlight so they could dry and sprout. The aloe: You left it in to long, it needed to be transplanted into soil after a day. The leafy plant: It might not have even been able to get roots from that stem, not all stems can root, I didn't recognize the plant so I can't really verify if that was one or not. But if it was; you needed to change the water as soon as it started to get slimy instead of letting it sit in moldy water and banana mush, and like the aloe, needed to transplant way earlier. Regards from an amateur gardener! :)

Cavendish Bananas and seedless grapes/watermelons and virtually every other commercially produced plant or animal are GMOs. Selective breeding is modifying traits of that species. How is it any different if it's done in a lab, under a microscope? I agree that some circumstances involving them can be immoral, like seeds being given for free to an impoverished area by a company knowing the plants grown from them wont yield more viable seeds in order to keep farmers from just planting holdbacks and make them buy more seeds.(its a thing that happens look it up) but GMOs arent the big boogeyman people seem to want them to be. Most modifications made to gmo crops are to help them resist diseases while maintaining an expected quality, something more difficult to do when only using selective and cross breeding.

GMOs? There is literally no food on the planet that isn't genetically modified in this day and age. You literally don't have a choice. The edible plants and animals that exist today have had their genetics modified in some way in the past.
My mom actually used to make banana boats like the one that the lady was stuffing chocolate into! basically, if a banana is at the point where it's not super fresh but it's not rotten, she would make a little boat out of foil, put the banana in it, slice it open, and put yummy stuff inside, such as chocolate chips, peanut butter, marshmallows, etc. Then we would pop it in the oven (NOT the microwave) for a few minutes, not sure the temp. When it comes out, it's like a warm banana treat. i think it's a hold over from days when my grandma would make food go as far as possible without any waste.
The problem with GMOs aside from what we don't know... the legal issue - someone owns a patent to a PLANT basically. Plants usually spread naturally and neighboring farmers can't control if seeds get carried over by wind/birds/... and get planted on their fields. That company that owns the patent can now sue the neighboring farmer, potentially put him out of business or force him to buy the plant, because maybe it's an invasive species and doesn't let the normal plants survive.  Then the things we don't know... we don't know how this would affect our health, the health of wildlife and the health of the planet. It's like a drug, I'm sure the dealer will give you a free sample just so you can no longer go without it and are forced to buy it next... So I would look a gift horse in the mouth whenever we see something coming from a lab without years and years of research and experience with the tech behind it.
Guys! The shoving chocolate into bananas is actually awesome! Slice them in the middle, shove blocks of ypur favourite chocolate and put them in the oven (standard, not micro). Wait a bit, once they start turning black, remove them. It's delicious.

That wasn't an aloe Vera plant, and that leaf was from the wrong plant as well. It's important in your debunking to use the same plants in the video as you have no idea why these tricks work, or don't work. Aloe vera tolerates moister environments than other succulents, unlike the succulent you used. The tropical plant used in the video had root nubs, meaning the plant would have been capable of growing new roots. The plant you used does as well, but you cut it in the wrong place. This is a legitimate method of getting new roots to grow from a clipping.

so much banana bread. Also with the GMO thing, literally EVERYTHING we eat in this modern day have been genetically modified. Selective breeding IS genetical modification and that's how we have the banana we consume. Downside to creating seedless variants is that well, the seeds they produce aren't viable for reproduction. So new banana trees are just cuttings from a parent plant, which is why a disease or parasite can wipe out the whole crop, because it's the same plant there's no genetic diversity to withstand the disease. That's  how we lost the 50's banana, that and because it was so tasty. We actually have the ghost of this banana in banana flavored candy, in case you ever wondered why it tasted so different from modern bananas. GMOs are very good and keep the food we eat on shelves.

Genetic modification can be a great tool to help threatened crops, but flip side is just because you can add fish DNA to strawberrys doesn't mean you should. I support genetic modification in situations like bananas and Panama disease; were the modification I liken to a vaccine against a specific disease. A similar GM has been used to save papaya from ringspot virus. I am more concerned with GMOs produced by companies like Monsanto that insure sterile seeds are produced by plants so farmers can't collect seeds or their products produce a toxin that affects both beneficial insects as well as undesirable.

Only problem I have with genetic mofified crops is that they are often rendered infertile, thus forcing farmer to bought every yeas new crop seed, not being able to reseed from the old ones. It's less a problem for things like fruit tree, but defintely one for cereals. Also, when they hybrid with real weird things. Tree with tree? okay. But trying to reuse a gene from a snail that can digest infested plant, to give them protection against a disease? That's seem dangerous. And likely to go bad, since you know, not the same type of organism at all.

As someone who is always thinking about what I'm eating because of a sensitive system, IBS-D, and other conditions that improve or get worse by what I eat - I don't really care about GMO. A lot of food says "Non-GMO!" but if modifying something allows us to feed people, and it isn't making the food give everyone fatal diseases, why not? We are intelligent life forms with a curiosity and we need to use that to improve earth, not harm it. Modify a plant to not destroy natural resources but it doesn't give me cancer? Heck yea. Not have an entire type of food go extinct and allow people to thrive? Sure! Modifying things doesn't have to mean it is bad. Science is amazing and if things can be modified for the positive I say we should go for it, we want this world to last for all of those that come after us - make it better, not worse.

People seem not to understand why GMOs are ever considered a problem. It's not the tomatos with fish genes are fish or whatever, because they just aren't. The problem is that  the insecticides that were killing the non GMO crops -- shocker of all shockers -- are pretty toxic. Otherwise the problem is the monopolistic behavior that Monsanto engages in and the many other ways that they cause real damage to people's livelihoods, etc.

As someone who has a degree in biotechnology people need to stop spreading misinformation about genetically modified foods aka GMOs. Most of the food we consume is a gmo and it doesn't mean they are weird or something, they're just altering a trait to the level of desirability eg. Tomatoes in most countries are gmos because the parent or original plant tend to have bad shelf life and the skin is fragile so they are modified to give them a higher shelf live and thicker skin which makes it easier to transport. There are gmo livestock's like cattle which is altered to be disease resistant or provide more milk. They're altering this for easier production which in chain provides more employment and  less food short I could go on about this but the point is gmo foods shouldn't carry a stigma
I honestly don't care about GMOs at all. If you can make my food for cheaper (while still retaining the flavor and texture), go ahead.
What my thoughts are on a GMO? Well it's pretty simple. I eat food that was "made" (altered? created?) by bombarding it with tons of radiation (and so do you. It's known as "Organic" food). So why would I care if someone selectively inserted a gene that makes that food better without all the trial and error?

10 fun facts about bananas:  1. the reason banana flavoured candies taste completely unlike bananas is because they are designed with an artificial flavour that is supposed to taste like the Gros Michel bananas (26:05), as they were the main type of bananas when the flavour was created. That just shows how different banana varieties are 2. Cavendish bananas were actually bred specifically because most other bananas have seeds and don't taste the same. 3. related to the previous fact, monkeys actually don't eat bananas (in the wild, however they will eat one if it is fed to them). The reason they don't eat bananas and the reason this is related to the previous fact is because of the seeds 4. The most popular fruit in the US is apparently a banana, and the top fruit in Canada (where I'm from) is a blueberry (according to a quick google search). 5. Cucumbers are a fruit, not a vegetable, meaning both of the main characters on Veggietales (Bob the tomato and Larry the cucumber) are actually fruit. so it should be called Fruitytales or plant-tales. 6. Fact #5 is not a banana fact 8. bananas are not my favourite fruit, that goes to pomegranates 9. I skipped fact #7 10. I ran out of banana facts

I'm one of those weirdos who prefers my bananas slightly under ripe.  I buy them as green as possible so they will last longer, but I find that can be misleading.  I've had bananas that still had a lot of green on them actually turn out to be ripe to over ripe.  I'm not fond of the flavour of ripe bananas, and cannot stand over ripe bananas.  Genetic modification has been in use since we started farming.  "Breeding" is a form of genetic modification, because you are selecting for, or trying to get rid of, particular genes.  I think genetic modification is necessary for some things (the Panama disease is a perfect example of it being necessary).  Of course, genetic modification can be abused.   There is far too much misinformation about GMOs, and more education is needed about them.

Just to dive in here, a bit late I know. My problem with GMO crops is more a lack of trust in the ethics and motivations of the food industry rather than a rejection of genetically modifying plants. It is obvious that if companies could make a food/plant that sells well, needs to be bought regularly, lasts well in ships and shops but not well in the home and has high profit margins they would do it regardless of whether that food has any nutritional value, without testing the long term effects of the changes and without any care for the environment. I try to grow some food at home in the UK because what is available in the store, especially tomatoes for example, doesn't taste anything like the actual home grown fruit. AFAIK tomatoes are now grown for their uniform size, and uniform growing times, resistance to disease and pest, cost of fertiliser and water plus the  ability to resist bruising or spoiling, and ability to be picked green and ripened later with gas. The only things they are not developed for is their taste and nutritional content. Globally we need our food to be good for us to eat. In this case of Anne's, where GMO is  saving a food species from a globally eradicating disease? I have no problem with it.

I don't want to eat that genetically modified banana! I might become resistant to fungus!
Fun fact, cavendish bananas are especially susceptible to Fusarium infection because they‚Äôre clones! In a plantation, they (theoretically, because mutation could still occur and you wouldn‚Äôt know unless you sequenced the DNA), all have the same DNA. In non-clonal mono cultures, there‚Äôs genetic diversity and so that can help to where some plants may be resistant to a particular disease or have a naturally better immune system. So since one cavendish banana is susceptible to Fusarium, they ALL are because they have the same DNA and therefore the same immune system.  Also, fun fact, (I took a cell culture and genetic engineering course in undergrad) a lot of people don‚Äôt know this, but ‚Äútraditional breeding‚Äù for crops often includes taking a plant and exposing it to mutagens to, of course, force mutations to potentially get a new kind/slightly different crop. Often times, traditional breeding can seem ‚Äúmore scary‚Äù to people than GM, especially since you truly don‚Äôt know what will happen when you force a plant to mutate. With GE, we know exactly what DNA we‚Äôre using, and there are ways to figure out if the DNA has gone into the correct spot. There are also ways using GE to make it to where plants are sterile, making the chance of those genes getting out into native populations basically zero (I say ‚Äúbasically‚Äù because nothing is 100% in biology, there‚Äôs so much we don‚Äôt know, so there‚Äôs almost certainly an exception to a rule, just statistically speaking).  However, both traditional breeding and GM have been found to be perfectly safe and GM can actually produce plants that are better for the environment as we can insert genes (like the research Anne talked about) that boost a plant‚Äôs immune system, and so we can use less pesticides. Additionally, GM regulation is a lot more intensive than is necessary. There‚Äôs a very very high cost, both in time and money, in producing a single GMO (or event, as they‚Äôre called). This is largely due to the fear surrounding GM, and while it‚Äôs good to be safe, GM has a much greater potential for helping people and reducing the use of pesticides if it was better understood and accepted.
Here in Mexico the conflict with GMOs is they're planted and pedaled by huge corporations like Monsanto and threaten to wipe out both local economy and commerce and our native species of corn, for example, of which we have red, purple, blue, yellow, white... "Alimentary sovereignty" is what is being threatened. Also the genetic diversity protects species from threats like panama disease, which if they were all of the exact same variety, like the cavendish, a single plague can wipe them all out.

A thing that I'd like to mention, even if I'm months late to the party, is that there is no current scientifically shown drawbacks to GMOs in food, at least, in terms of nutrition, health, etc. There are a handful of problems that may possibly occur, and most of them have nothing to do with the GMOs themselves. There are potential biodiversity issues and similar problems, but GMOs solve those as much as, if not more than, they cause them, but the real issues with GMOs is that laws haven't kept up with the times, and, worse, have actively supported predatory practices and other negative behaviors from GMO-based companies. Monsanto, for example, is the absolute scum of the earth and has used their ownership of genetically modified crops to litigiously attack (in other words, sue for no good reason) countless farmers who are just trying to get by. They've abused GMOs to make it seem acceptable to use poisons that may be causing considerable ecosystem damage. They've done all sorts of other things that they shouldn't be allowed to do, but because there's no law against any of it or because they've paid people off and used their power as a massive company, they just... Keep doing it. Nobody stops them. And the farmers who they target may be anything from poor to reasonably well-off, but they never go after someone who could actually fight back against a gigantic corporation's level of lawyers. They have, on multiple occasions in the past, essentially destroyed someone's life because they thought that maybe possibly this guy could have been the one who found some corn seeds in a ditch and took them. They then decimate the guy with law suits, drive everyone away from his shop because everybody thinks he's a thief or something, and then spontaneously vanish with no further comment other than "guess we got the wrong guy" before the suit completes, leaving a completely innocent man out thousands upon thousands of dollars not even counting the losses of business from the reputation damage. The problem with GMOs isn't GMOs. It's corporations. Just like... Well, a whole lot of other stuff.

Genetically modifying crops could help save the world if done properly. Yes, if you buff up a plant too much, it could spread into the wild and destroy entire ecosystems. But there are several well-explored methods to prevent that. Yes, unknown biochemical cross-reactions could make the crop toxic for consumption. That's why you have to test it carefully before permitting its cultivation (just as you have to test any food and drug). I think the main reason for people rejecting genetic modification is missing knowledge on the topic. We have to embrace this possibility instead of alienating it. The latter will leave it to the Chinese and they are not known for taking the environment into consideration.

Most people who are anti-GMO are not uneducated Dillard's afraid of the "frankenfoods". Most of is have legitimate reasons that have little to do with the genetic altering of our food (though in some cases, for example foods that produce their own pesticides, have already proved to be dangerous to bees and people)...  For example, my major problem with GMOs is that most GMO foods have patents on them owned by large corporations (*cough* MONSANTO). If you are a farmer and refuse to use their GMO seeds, but the farms around you use it, your plants will likely cross pollinate. Your crops test as GMO and then YOU get sued by Monsanto because you did not pay them royalties to grow "their" crop!
In my opinion, GMOs are a very fascinating and powerful innovation by humanity in order to produce more food in less space; sweetcorn, bananas, carrots, and even watermelon have been selectively bred over centuries to look and taste the way they do. However, I think recent trends towards "anti-GMO" sentiment are misconstruing GMOs, which are plants we've had for centuries, with more recent industrial practices. Here stateside, we have a massive problem, as large farming/seed corporations have patented seeds/seed types, which grow fast, large, and so on. Where I am, it's mostly corn that is like this, and if it cross pollinates smaller, heirloom varieties, it out-competes/hybridizes and pretty much dominates until the heirlooms are all gone. And since the seeds are patented, or something like that, owned by the company, they grow in certain ways to inhibit regrowth, and even if you do, the corn is their property. Like, there's a MASSIVE issue with large, industrial farming, it's practices, and how it makes a monolithic crop out of a once diverse species, and makes it harder to farm varieties of corn. GMOs aren't terrible, it's how many are used in many places that are bad, Monsanto, for example, has a seed charity, but the seeds themselves require repurchase and don't regrow properly if at all, so it keeps the farmers they give the seeds to in poverty. This practice has made farming a complex issue, as there's not a lot of biodiversity in the different crops modified in this way, so there's no guarantee that these crops will be protected if a blight or drought wipes them out. I may not be too knowledgeable on this, but I do know for certain that certain types of corn are protected/proprietary of certain companies, and can harm the farming practices of heirloom/biodiverse varieties. A GMO that ensures a banana can withstand a blight that can wipe out entire fields is a massively beneficial GMO, a GMO that makes growing biodiverse crops impossible is a terrible one.

I love GMOs.  I'm a geneticist by degree (not by profession) and I think that GMOs are wonderful.  Especially when they can save things like the banana as we know it.  I understand the desire to eat "organic" "non GMO" foods, but what exactly IS non GMO?  When people think GMO they think of some frankenfood.  Something like injecting growth hormone into cattle to make them fatter and more desirable.  Injecting chickens with growth hormone or putting it into their food so that they grow unnaturally.  But when it comes to plants, often times it can be done just by cross breeding the plants.  And we do this naturally all of the time.  People wouldnt even recognize watermelon as we know it back hundreds of years ago.  Or strawberries as we know them today.  Even "organic non GMO" foods as we know them today have undergone some genetic modification.  Cross breeding to make a more desirable looking or desirable tasting crop.  I think GMO is perfectly fine and safe in plants and often times necessary to ward off pests or disease or fungus.  They keep us eating good food.  They keep the supply chain of our food in tact.  And they keep the farmers farming.  All good things!
I think the question is does bananas grow in Australia? of course!! Does the farmers from Panama depend economically from selling bananas to the world? yes! All this started when all these lands where brutally exploited by the Spaniards during colonial times. (remember the banana republic term?) so all these communities over the years had not other choice than keep selling bananas to survive. And that is the challenge for countries like Panama and many other countries in southamerica and central america... I'm not saying that Panama should stop drastically selling bananas to the world, but it is very crucial to start developing other sources of income for the communities over time. And also, protecting our lands! our planet, reducing the amount of pesticides and chemicals. My parents are small rice farmers from Peru, and the use of these chemicals had increased over the time tremendously reducing the fertility of the soil and increasing the risk of more unknown plagues never seen before to appear.  What about starting to transform our agriculture into organic agriculture, progressively, but doing it right! healing the soil, stop growing huge amounts of plantations of the same fruit or tree, is not right, please guys do your research about this. It is important to motivate all these communities to diversify their labor, work with our environment, see what else is out there for us to sustainable produce. There is plenty!! in my tiny little town in Peru, all the bananas we consume come from 1 hour away. There are so many opportunities right now for us to learn and to progress and that's on us :) All around the world, we need to progressively take action... there are so many farmers right now all over the world trying to do the right thing! let's consume organic.. let's support local farmers, I bet in Australia you guys are growing amazing bananas!  I guess is time for a change... love to all, I just wanted to give my opinion...

I don't understand the anti-GMO sentiment at all, honestly? Like, it's just what humans have been doing in both agriculture and animal husbandry since the things were invented but on a quicker scale, with a much wider variety of possibilities to explore. Like, for example, making bananas that are resistant to disease. As long as all food goes through the proper length and rigermole of safety testing before it's introduced to the market, there should be absolutely no issue. Like, nobody is suggesting we all edit a gene in our bananas and then start eating the first one grown before checking that the edited gene won't make the banana poison. But like, if you're taking a gene from one plant you know is not dangerous and tacking it onto another plant that's not dangerous, where does anyone think danger might come from? What's the difference between that and trying to cross-breed the two different types of bananas until you get a plant with the gene combination you were looking for?  That said-- I do think the legal problems of GMO are their own ball game, but corporations getting patents on plant genes and suing the shit out of local farmers who can't exactly just pack up and move when Monsato plants start cross-pollinating with theirs because Moisanto moved in next door... that's going to happen whether those genes were made unique through the old fashioned "selective breeding" or from more modern modifications, really, because corporations are greedy bastards. The problem is the legal system-- same with any issues of safety, the law is what's there to enforce that-- not genetic modification itself.
What I don‚Äôt understand about the anti GMO campaign is that most food we eat are only available do to genetic tampering and selective breeding of said plants. Prime examples being bok choy, broccoli, and Brussels sprouts. They all come from the same singular plant that our ancestors then selectively bred for specific qualities (i.e. Brussels sprouts are targeted for their enlarged flourettes, bok choy for the leafiness). By taking a gene from one variety and mixing it with a known variet of food it kind just feels like a short cut to selective breeding. Idk just my opinion
Honestly though who eats bananas yellow? They should be spotty, like a leopard.   Anyway,  in live with your channel and thanks for all those nice, informative and entertaining videos!
