To use GMO because we first created an unhealthy monoculture is just beyond... why not FINALLY use this as a jumping off point to create different strains of bananas? Like we do with almost all other fruits. Apples have diseases and they have not caused them to monoculture and GMO the shit out apples, but instead create new strains, new variants. In the end we now have a ton of great, interesting tasting apples. Why not go that route for bananas?¬†  GMO is STILL a potentially risky business for food. There are still questions as to the results of long term exposure to GMO foods. While GMO looks like we totally and completely understand it, there are side effects we don't yet fully understand. Like trigger one gene, totally isolated can have side effects on others. Like there is some kind of meta-layer connecting genes. Maybe "life" is not just Legos and we should not hasten to treat it like it is, feeding millions with GMO food.
I live in East Africa, we have absolutely dozens of amazing types of bananas - ones you pick green and cook like potatoes, all different sizes and colours for ripe fresh eating, and every single one of them is infinitely better than the cavendish.  I hated bananas growing up in Canada, but living here I love them, they have real flavour and different lovely textures.  (No seeds!).  So far as I know, most are not exported, they are all eaten locally, and none are nearly as susceptible to the disease you mention as the cavendish.  I would suggest that agricultural breeders look at not monocropping so much, and finding better tasting bananas in the first place to replace the blah cavendish. But I guess most of them don't ship as well or don't ripen as well under artificial conditions, who knows.  Anyway, I am glad as anything to eat tasty bananas of great varieties that have never been shipped halfway round the world and gassed, thanks!

One issue with separating the bananas as a *control* is that bananas _only ripen at the same rate *when kept in close proximity to one another*_, so you‚Äôd actually need what would likely be an unfeasibly large number of bananas to calculate average ripening rate, instead.  Most stores won‚Äôt let you buy say, 500 bananas (for non-scientists, I assure you that‚Äôs a *small* number for such a study, which I‚Äôm sure Ann knows) as a normal consumer, so you‚Äôd be out of luck pretty much.

A few thoughts on bananas:  I am not sure I'd be personally fond of cooking them, but try to fry them in halves in a little oil (or even without, if you have a very good non-stick), maybe sprinkle some nuts on top, maybe add sugar while frying (although for me they are plenty sweet once fried). - It might not look like much, but even just the sugar inside the banana will cause it to caramelize in places and the whole thing is delicious and super sweet. Does not take long whatsoever.  I am always mildly confused when people look at a browned banana and say it has gone bad. I mean, it can happen, but usually you cannot actually determine this from the condition of the peel. And to me bananas don't even taste like much until they are ripe enough to be at least a little spotted. In pure yellow they are just so... bland?  Lastly, about keeping them fresh longer (or just keeping the outer colour nice): Recently I picked up one of our bananas which had a large sticker on the peel for some reason. The banana was fairly brown (and delicious inside) but when i peeled off the sticker the peel underneath was deeply yellow and firm and thick with moisture, just as it had been a week before. Made me wonder about the exact why's of how this stopped the browning process. Was lack of oxidation? - Either way, the peel had zero bearing on the inside of the banana. The part beneath the young-looking peel looked and tasted precisely like the parts beneath the browned and thinned peel. Purely cosmetic, huh?

I managed facilities at a small (75 person) office for a couple of years in my 20s. We provided about 50lbs of fruit throughout the office every week. I cleaned out the baskets, filled them with fresh fruit, and added old fruit that was still good to the top. The baskets were an eclectic collection of styles, and I could put bananas in some of them but had to put them beside others. I observed that baskets with bananas in them tended to have more spoilage. I started putting all of the bananas on the side and that seemed to reduce spoilage.

Okay so I'm late to the party, but part of the reason *why* this fungus completely overtakes these bananas without fail is that they are all clones of one another. Seriously. That's why the fungus wiped out the last banana we all ate; the bananas were interbred to a point where they wouldn't make seeds, then did various other planting techniques to make sure all of the trees were exactly identical. So after that happened to that banana, of course the farmers turned around and did it to the Cavendish as well. Genetically modifying the Cavendish now is only going to work for so long, because the fungus in another 60-90 years will finally find a way that works and do that exact same thing over and over again because all the Cavendish trees are the same. So while the GMO will buy time, I hope that alternative food sources are found, because it's a terrible idea to patch the problem and then ignore it while it slowly gets worse.

Banana with chocolate is quite common to grill in Sweden, we eat it as a dessert, very common to have on hikes or camping trips, but also somewhat common for grill nights. On grill nights we eat it with vanilla ice cream (can‚Äôt really bring ice cream on a hike or camping trip, otherwise we probably would, because it‚Äôs really tasty). Not sure about putting it in the microwave though, it feels like it might not cook the banana throughly so it would mostly be just warm banana rather than ‚Äúmelted‚Äù banana, but I‚Äôve never tried it in the microwave so what do I know. I do recommend you to try it out on a grill though, or in the oven if you don‚Äôt have the possibility to grill it outdoors, and with vanilla ice cream. It should cook until the peel is black. I don‚Äôt know what types of chocolate you have in Australia, but if you want to make it with Swedish chocolate I would guess you could find some nice mj√∂lkchoklad (milk chocolate) at IKEA.

Crusaders against GMO foods need to do some reading and learn what a GMO really is. "Genetically modified" foods just means that they've been bred for taste and other desirable traits for hundreds of years. If you eat soy and corn (or ANY modern crop and their derivatives) you've been eating GMOs for years and didn't know it. If you understand the science you're less likely to  just latch onto a popular slogan or cause and run with it without even knowing what it is. Plus, farm animals bred for specific qualities (fast growth, fast weight gain, or other traits) are GMOs. Even special breeds of dogs and cats are GMOs!

The Cavendish banana (and Gros Michel) were stripped of all genetic diversity, meaning that a single disease could (and did) wipe an entire species out suddenly. Genetic diversity is vital for the long-term survival of a species. But having millions of genetically-identical bananas is appealing to consumers and so good for short-term profit. I can't really care about safely gene-spliced bananas when the old-fashioned way of genetically modifying an organism is misused and threatening the species

I don't have a problem with GMOs as a rule. What I do have a problem with is large companies not being forthright and ethical in their practices. Combine unethical practices with the GMO process,  and you get distrust of both the corporation and the GMOs from the general public.   Also the GMO process shouldn't be used for plants which already are diverse and has a great number of varieties (apples and potatoes for example). Since edible Bananas don't rank high in the variety scale and are in danger of becoming extinct,  I think this situation warrants a bit of help from the lab.   Though I'm not a horticulturist, a food expert,  or even a home gardener, my opinion doesn't amount to much

Oh no!  The VPN companies have even gotten to you.  Yes, VPNs offer some potential benefits.  They often tout privacy as one of those, but that is often iffy...  The VPN companies themselves often keep tabs and log your activity.  A better way is to grab an arbitrary server from a hosting company and run your own VPN on that.  OpenVPN or WireGuard are great open source and free options.  Of course hosting your own has some downsides (1- time investment to get things set up properly and 2- less flexibility to switch countries, as you would need to host a server in each country you wish to access, oh and 3- if you don't know what you're doing with the security you might be even worse off than having a VPN company spy on your traffic.    Granted, if you can trust your VPN company, then it helps.  Also, if your VPN company is unlikely to share that data with the whoever you don't want to see it, then it helps (e.g. a German company might be less likely to share data with the US government, or a US company may be unlikely to share with the Chinese government.    GMO food is generally safe... things get pretty broken down by our bodies before they're put back together.  I wouldn't say there are no exceptions, but generally speaking.  I think a much bigger concern is just with introducing new plants (and animals, etc...) back into the wild and how ecosystems respond to these changes.  In a case like the banana, where it is already a big cash crop, keeping it that way probably doesn't bring much additional harm, but the spread of cash crops in places like Madagascar has been massively destructive to wildlife and changes that increase the range where these plants can survive could be helpful or harmful (could allow them to be grown in less damaging places or may encourage people to go wild with them in places they were already wreaking havoc at). I don't think most people would mind GMO that adds disease resistant genes from similar plants.  After all, breeders and geneticists have been doing that with pollination and physical plant splicing for decades.  The disgusting GMO's are ones that allow huge amounts of herbicides to be held in the plants/produce or genes from completely different species....sheep genes in cantaloupes for example.
cavendish bananas r clones. They dont grow seeds, so they r easier to eat. Each tree is an off-shoot of a mature plant. If a disease wipes 1 plantation, itll wipe all of them, cuz they all have the same genes, same resistances and same weaknesses.  There r many different edible banana species, but they r localized to south america. Some r redder and stubbier than cavendish. SOme r grown by primitive jungle tribes and cooked, like potatoes. The fodder bananas didnt find mass market for their blandness  GMO is best shit - it makes useless plants produce vitamines they didnt produce before and can supplement that in diets of starving, poor peoples, like golden rice. They can carry bioluminescent markers for substance detection. They can turn plants growing tall and having their fruits unreachable, to growing short and easily pickable. I'm a fair bit annoyed about the ignorance surrounding genetically modified organisms or GMO's. Everything we eat nowadays has been genetically modified. There is no such thing as a non-GMO product. We simply have the technology now to directly insert genes rather than selectively breeding over a longer period of time - both which (eventually) result in the same product. Every single thing we eat has been selectively bred over decades, if not centuries. So to pretend that GMOs are in any way bad is utter rubbish, it's actually pretty great we have more than 3 grains on a wheat plant now. Or bananas without giant seeds. Or watermelons that have more flesh than seeds.

Thanks for testing and debunking these. A lot of people are getting into plants right now, and channels spread a lot of misinformation as a result... ü§¶üèº‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è Some background info, why these do not work: Plants don‚Äôt necessarily need soil. There are many plants that can root just fine in a cup of water. Wat is important (and what went wrong with the banana), is to make sure the roots do not start to rot (and if the banana around it is rotting, naturally, so will the roots). Roots do grow differently wetter they grow in soil, water, leca etc. Some might look thicker than others. Then, one last, really important ingredient to grow roots on a plant: you need a node on the stem. The node is the point where leaves grow from, and this is generally also where roots come from. If the plant (leaf) you are using does not have a node, it can never be its own plant.

I have no problems with genetically modified foods that take a gene from one species of plant, in this case, a banana that is resistant to something and put it in another type of banana to make it resistant, as this is something that could possibly be done over time with selective breeding, however, where I have a problem with genetically modified food is if you take say a tomato and put in a gene from a jellyfish to give it a property that tomatoes just don't have.  At this point, in my mind it's not a tomato any more, it's an artificial chimera as this jellyfish gene could never make it's way into a tomato under any circumstance in nature.

Horticulture student here: there is a big difference between taking non-plant genes and putting them into plants (ex: insecticide producing gene) versus crossing the genes of two plants. one is a scientific marriage of two plants while the other is inserting something unnatural or from a totally different species with a plant. I don't want BAYER (formerly Monsanto) tweaking the genes of seeds to make them produce their own insecticide that hasn't rigorously been proven not harmful to humans. Nor do I want the seeds altered so that a farmer can only grow the plant one season; GMO seeds cost farmers tons of money instead of allowing the farmer to save his own seeds from his crop to grow in a future season.  Most of the conventional produce we buy comes from plant seeds that cannot be saved because the gene inserted into them is owned by BAYER/ FORMERLY MONSANTO; if a farmer is caught or even just accused of saving seed with the patented gene, they can be sued for enough money to bankrupt generations of small family farmers. A farmer can grow an organic crop, save his own seed only to find his saved seed contaminated with patented seed from a neighboring farm that grew the patented gene containing seeds; The law only requires the patented seeds to be found on the farmer's property/in his possession for Monsanto to be entitled to compensation for patent infringement. The law does NOT take into account whether the patented seed was found because of unintentional contamination; if the seed is there, Monsanto's copy right has been infringed. Further you have to agree not to save seed in a binding contract at the sale of the seeds to be able to plant the GMO seeds. US law does not allow a company to patent a living organism, but they can patent the genetically engineered gene inserted into a living thing which allows them to control the living thing they genetically engineer. Mexico has seen the number of farmers in the middle east and India who have committed suicide after getting roped into using GMO seed; after the farmers harvest their crop all of the profit goes into buying more GMO seeds for the coming year and in a bad year the farmers lose everything, thus the rash of suicides. Because of this nightmare, Mexico is fighting to keep GMO corn out of Mexico. Once their various indigenous species of corn become contaminated by GMO corn, there is no salvaging the indigenous corn. Its about protecting the indigenous corn species, the farmers and the local economy based on the corn. so while its bad having a disease wipe out a crop and the livelihood of countless people, GMO seed/crops are not the answer to every horticultural problem.

Not all GMO are really as bad as everyone says and the research behind it works to making better food for everyone. In a few grocery stores here, they used to wrap the tops of banana bunches (usually of 6) in plastic to prevent folks from separating bunches into smaller groups. It's rarely done anymore because who wants 6 bananas if you only need 2? Perhaps they were remembering that practice and thought it was a preservation method.
People who fear monger about GMOs like to frame the conversation in such a way that they make it sound like scientists are slicing jelly fish DNA into food to make it glow or that the side effects result in people developing physical defects.  Which sure, I'm sure somewhere something like that is happening, but I'd bet my bottom dollar that 99% of GMOs are boring modifications to make food resilient to a pathogen or to make them produce more of the edible parts and/or less of the inedible parts.
There is absolutely nothing wrong with GMO produce. They could cross breed the plant anyway, but doing it in a lab is more efficient. This is a case of people fearing things they do not understand. Ofc there is a possibility to make a gmo food that is harmful, but no one would do that because you want repeat customers. People are in this for the money. There is no difference between cross breeding two different types of Roses together and genetically modifying a plant to be drought resistant, have a bigger yield or to be immune to fungal diseases. Billions or lives have been saved and sustained due to GMO foods. It's called science, bitches.

I always buy my bananas mostly green and let them rippen at home, lasts longer.
Regarding the banana hack: there is a similar technique that actually works to slow down the ripening. If you take a plastic produce bag and put the banana bunch in it halfway with the stem part (where they are attached) inside the bag. Place the banana bunch in there loosely and only halfway and it will slow down the ripening process. The stem part on the bananas releases a hormone or a chemical that actually speeds up the ripening and putting it in the plastic slows it down. I used this method all the time when I have bananas and it does work, although not miraculous, it does help to slow down the ripening process.

Isn‚Äôt most of our food GMO? Food industries are constantly cross breeding plants to make perfect tasting and perfect looking items to put in the supermarket
And on the topic of GMO - I'm for it, with adequate safety & testing but I'm also anti-patented/seedless GMO except in extreme circumstance (for the seedless part). It's such a broad topic that I'd recommend everyone who's a bit squeamish about the idea look into - "GMO" could easily be applied to most of the food we eat today, plants and animals, because of the selective breeding we've done for centuries to produce a particular taste, look, size etc. For history of that, look into corn and carrots!! GMO is a faster, more specific version of this process and is (for good reason) well regulated to insure that the modifications do not make the food harmful to eat, and also to avoid over-competition with surrounding habitats in the case of plant-life.  There's a lot of politics and ethics involved in the actual procurement of GMO seed-stock which I'd recommend looking into too - this might involve farmers struggling with the costs of seeds and being unable to propagate from their own crop due to infertile/seedless GMO plants, or because the GMOs are patented in such a way that it's illegal to have a cloning/breeding stock and they have to rebuy seeds every time. Deeply unethical imo, and the only times seedless might be acceptable is if the GMO plant is hyper-resilient in a way that seeds leaving the farm could result in local habitats being chocked out by the very competitive GMO plant.
Growing plants inside bananas is a horrible idea since ripe bananas produce a lot of ethylene. It's a plant hormone that promotes ripening of fruits, but also makes plants age faster, or die faster.  Dying plants also produce a lot of ethylene which is why you should keep your Christmas tree, if real, away from your live plants.

A couple of botannical issues/errors ruined your debunk of the plant propogation.  Mainly, their leaf hack was about monstera deliciosa, a plant Queenslanders will be familiar with. It is a philodendron vine, and generates aerial roots from the stem at leaf nodes which it uses to climb and grow. In a humid climate, it is very easy to propogate because of this. Unfortunately, using a different (unidentified) large leafed plant and trying to propogate it from that absolutely bears no comparison to the way the monstera vine grows, so nothing was debunked here.     Also, similarly, they used a very young aloe vera "pup" (which will sprout roots easily but not in the anoxic environment of a banana), while you used a mature (but not old) plant which was a different type of aloe, so you can't compare them well. The debunking was less convincing for this, but you still demonstrated the anoxic environment of the rotting fruit having a negative effect on plant growth.  One hack that does work is using bananas to ripen things like avocados and custard apples, I expect most people are aware of this. This is the reason you should store your bananas away from your apples, because they will ripen the apples too quickly! If you ever want a positive hack to test, you could try that one :)

I'm a Landscaper and I know for a fact aloe vera has very a shallow roots so they can get water a bit easier. I *think* they may have tap Roots as well, but it really could just be where she was growing them. Also for the leaf it will not grow any new Roots because‚Ä¶ well the proper hormones were not put on it. And a banana doesn't have everything that the plant will need. What we do sometimes is we'll take tomato plants and cut some of the stems up that are overgrown, then we add a root growth hormone to New growth and stick it in the soil and heavily water it. It's going to look like it's struggling at first but they'll eventually perk up. Every route has a slippery substance it's excrete so it can move better through the dirt. Roots are very strong, but I don't think they'd have a good time going through a banana. There wouldn't be enough water and nutrient in it. If anything I feel like you just clog up the xylem and phloem.

Modern corn, carrots, and many other things people consume on a daily basis are modified from their original state.  They aren't bad.  I giggle every time I see bright orange non-GMO carrots. I mean... the bananas we eat are not natural; they are a GMO crop in that humans bred them specifically to not have seeds in them, therefor altering their genetics from regular bananas to the point where they cannot be bred and are instead all clones (which is also why they are weak to disease), so complaining about 'GMO' bananas is typically a stupid argument that makes no sense. There ARE arguments against lab based direct genetics manipulation, but 99% of people don't even begin to comprehend that argument, and instead base their argument on their flimsy, corporate-created idea of what is "natural" and that "natural is good" etcetera.  Basically: "GMO is bad because it goes against my ethics or gives the wealthy an even bigger advantage over the local farmers." = An argument with merit. "GMO is bad because it's not natural." = An argument made from someone who hasn't learned anything since high-school.  My personal thoughts on GMO is that in theory I have no problems with it being done, but in practice it usually leads to the GMO manufacturers having a strict control of their crop, so any farmer who wants to grow their fancy wheat must pay their incredibly steep prices, but they can't NOT grow their wheat because then all the other farmers around them will outproduce them massively with the GMO crop.  For example: it's happening to a lot of farmers in north Africa right now; they have to buy new seeds every year because the GMO crops are purpose designed not to seed and the prices are very high for the return they get, but they can't NOT buy the seeds because the non-GMO variant is much harder to grow in the area, and produces much less crop in a year, so they're stuck in a loop of buying these GMO seeds and going into debt over and over because the regular crop doesn't pay enough to get them out of the cycle. All while the already wealthy GMO company laughs and rakes in the profits.

Sure we have different tools for doing it now, modifying it in a lab instead of through selective breeding but the concept is the same.  GMO's specifically the one's made with modern lab technology are a great opportunity to get rid of the need for pesticides, make foods more nutritious, and lots more! Its actually super cool. I wish people would see that instead of buying into all the fear.

I think fear of GMO from a scientific standpoint is wholly unjustified: every vegetable we eat has been genetically modified by selective breeding over the course of years/decades by humans. If there's a quicker, more efficient way to do that, then so be it! We need more fear of GMOs from a social, ethical standpoint. What's so important about food is that it is, by its own nature, accessible by everyone. You can plant them by yourself, get your own supply. Sure you can buy premium quality seeds, and some varieties are seedless or sterile exactly so you can't duplicate the variety, but the point still stands. You can plant an apple and get an apple tree. You can plant a potato and get more of them. But, hours of paid work is being put into efficient GMOs, and those who invested in them obviously will want their money back - and if they're so easy to "steal", the market would be over saturated in very little time! But, what if those GMOs are so competitive, they make the "regular" variety of the same plant outdated? Would small farmers run out of business? What about people in third world countries? Monopolies are scary. The science behind GMOs, however, is not! And I would personally love to see more GMOs on the market (my country has a history of being vehemently against them), as long as they're regulated in ways that make their production ethical.

Backslash is \ which is NEVER valid in a url.  Only slash (sometimes called forward slash) / is valid in a url.  It always bugs me when people say backslash when they mean slash. I myself am not against GMO crops, as I think that they aren‚Äôt any less natural than the other crops that we think of as ‚Äúnatural‚Äù which have been through thousands of years of artificial selection or selective breeding to make them look and taste like they do now, proven by the wild banana Ann showed on the video, which would actually be natural as opposed to the cavendish variety. This, of course, isn‚Äôt exclusive to bananas, in fact, all the plants that we eat nowadays have been through the same artificial selection process to make them have the most flesh and least amount of seeds possible, if any at all. The problem with GMO is purely an image problem, where natural foods are perceived to better for you than genetically altered ones or purely artificial ones, where in fact as long as GMO crops have been through sufficient testing, they are just as good, sometimes even better than the non-GMO varieties, as GMOs can be genetically engineered to be more dense in nutrients and more resistant to diseases, insects or fungus, as shown by the research done by Professor James Dale. For more on the topic of GMOs, I recommend Kurzgesagt‚Äôs video on GMOs and make sure to check the sources document in the video description.

for the banana with the aloe plant and growing roots:   well when a banana is left over the course of a few days and goes brown and mushy, it starts to de-compress meaning the things inside it break down and become looser bound together. what i find interesting about that with the longer roots is that when pulling it out you see lots of them when it only started with 2 or 3 at most and fairly short.   what i think happened is that the stringy bits when you peel a banana and they start to come off with the skin have been moved by the decomposition and then therefore clinged to the roots and making them appear bigger.    ann, feel free to correct this but did it feel like actual plant roots that were firm and structured in a way that made it be suitable for what the roots would do or was it quite soft and a bit of a sticky or slime -like feel. if so then it was more than likely the banana strings.   --Caden

Oh the topic of geneticlly altered food is driving peaple apart I think :D  I'm an ongoing Biotechnologist from Germany and was a bit astonished when I learned about the declaration of genetically altered food in the way they made it. So to disclaim this a bit, I can actually just talk about the regulations in the EU, but here it is like this:  If a plant is shot with radiation to force it to alter in the genome, there are several mutations that can accur and noone is specific for a certain kind of problem (like the resistance of the banana to the fungus) and this is declared as NON GENETICALLY ALTERED. So... If you have successfully altered a plant to be resistant, there will most probably be other mutations you don't know about and can be harmful (maybe, but of course it'd being tested)  BUT... If you just take a specific gene from the resistant banana plant and give it to the one that is not resistant (e.g with the CRISPR-Cas9 Method, you may heard of) then it's declared of being genetically altered food.  To summerize: Are genes successfully transfered between different plants, no matter how precizely (only the gene you want), then it's declared as GM Food. But if you just shoot a plant with radiation (or other mutagene methods) to achieve random mutations an may end up with one that is besides maybe hundrets of other mutations with the feature you want, then you can declare it as Non GM Food...  I think thats a bit ironic right? :D And that leads also to a lot of misconceptions of GM Food.  I'm interested what it's like in other countries :D

I think people against GMOs don‚Äôt tend to understand what GMOs actually are. Not many people know that almost all of the food we eat is genetically modified in minor ways and some food we eat (such as yellow corn) are heavily GM food. The main thing that we should be critical of involving GMO companies is manipulations involving the plant itself and whether or not it can be re-planted. Many GMO companies intentionally make their plants die after only one season and have manipulated them in such a way that they do not produce seeds and drain the soil more quickly of nutrients, which is devastating for third world farmers that rely on them. In terms of human health, at the beginning there were a few hiccups, but at this point the science is pretty stable. I wouldn‚Äôt worry too much about getting sick from eating a yellow corn.

Well, a real receipe. when the bananas seems just too ripe to be eaten as it. I cook flamed bananas : a little butter in a stove, make the bananas caramelize (without the peel). When cook enough, you can add a little of strong alcohol (Rum, Cointreau, etc... whatever you like). then  ignite the alcohol in the stove. serve warm... that's really tasty. and not fake. There's an alternative, in oven, but there you cook the banana cut in its length with its peel, and don't flame them in the oven.

The banana with chocolate is actually called a Banana Boat.  We made them in Girl Scouts/Girl Guides.  When you cut the wedge, leave the peel attached.  Add in chocolate, marshmallows, or whatever you like.  Put the peel back in place, wrap it in aluminum foil, and put it at the edge of a campfire (or in a microwave) for a few minutes to let it all get melty and gooey.

14:10-ish: We used to make baked bananas a little like that at guide camp on the campfire (and we were told if you want to do it at home, bake them in the oven (about 10 mins). Only difference, we peeled the banana, did just one slit down it and pressed in chocolate buttons (and occasionally sprinkles), then wrapped it tight in tinfoil to bake. In all honesty, when I've been short on money, or feeling very nostalgic, I've made it since, but it's not the world's greatest dessert (a baked apple is way better).

In principle I have no problem with GMO food. Earlier methods to increase rate of mutation (used since the 1950s) use radiation to induce random mutations and then kept mutated varieties that had benefits. This is not labeled as GMO I think (citation needed). So, I personally prefer this more specific introduction of the specific gene into the plant. My only problem with GMO is when they introduce a gene to make it resistant to a specific pesticide so farmers can heavily spray them, or modify a plant such that it can't grow without fertilizers from a company. It is the pesticide and the ability of farmers to afford seeds/fertilizers I worry about, not the modified plant.

I'm noticing lot's of people not understanding the difference between selective breeding and GMO's. Selective breeding is taking traits that are already present in the population and making it so that the group you want to use all has that specific trait. GMO's on the other hand is taking that trait and inserting it into the genome of the individual. It should also be noted that they use traits that are only found in different species and insert this foreign trait into the organism.
Id like to point out a few things regarding the banana peels:  1- "meat alternatives" do not necessarily need to be high in protein when its serving as replacement in a dish like a burger there are many ways of getting your protein it doesn't need to serve in the exact position an animal product was. there are many ways of getting your protein needs met 2- banana peels are actually healthy. Banana peels are packed with polyphenols, carotenoids, and other antioxidants that fight cancer-causing free radicals in your body which is very different from labeling them as "non toxic" or something you'd eat if there isn't enough food.  3- banana peels are clearly texturally and structurally different from animal flesh so they should be cooked differently. you should know that and the way they were cooked in this video was horrible and that was made clear by just looking at the end product. obviously I wasn't expecting a culinary masterpiece from a 5 minutes crafts video but its should be pointed out that the issue here is the the recipe and cooking method rather than the use of banana peels in itself.  I get that non vegans can be unfamiliar with meat alternatives and their cooking methods but if you're going to talk about it, the least you can do is not be so condescending.

RE: GMOs in food, I think I'd have to cut a lot of other things out of my diet before I had any right to worry about that.  RE: GMOs on the environment, I think the agriculture industry should probably worry about a lot of other things before they start in on that.  TBF, I know next to nothing about food science, agriculture, or environmental science. But same as Ann I live in Australia, where everywhere you look there's some invasive species messing things up. The difference between a banana plant and a genetically modified banana plant seems way less disruptive compared to what happened when they introduced foxes (for recreational hunting) in areas with no other predators that size.   GMOs in general seem actually pretty necessary to me. Just as a food supply thing, because human populations have become so massive, we really can't stand to lose any significant percentage of our agriculture. But Darwinism happens and all that, new diseases develop, old ones travel to new places, invasive species move in, and the agriculture which is supporting us gets messed up. I don't know much about it but I'm assuming selectively breeding plants is slow and has limited applications, which means you'd be looking at a pretty significant blip on the agricultural system that's supporting us. Genetic modifications are just a quicker way of patching holes. Even if GMOs did cause environmental issues, I don't know if most people would say that's worse than a significant food shortage. Which isn't to say that I condone sacrificing the environment for any reason, but the powers that be are probably going to make that decision and the percentage of the population that are willing boycott a product usually isn't significant enough to make them change their minds.  That's not a well-researched opinion though so I'd be interested to hear Ann's take on it, if she was keen to do a video.
These trolls are just trying to see what they can get simpletons to go along with. It seems deliberately malicious to me.

This is why I like this channel - the fun of debunking nonsense, the information about things that are dangerous. knowledge on how things are made/ripened for commercial use and even discussion about serious concerns like panama disease. As for GMO's, I would like to sit the people who have "concerns" over them and ask them why they have concerns and what concerns they are. The scientific consensus on whether GMO's are safe to eat is about the same as the scientific consensus on whether human activity affects climate change. So safety is not an issue. One argument that can be made is that by creating GMO's we are altering the biodiversity of the planet and interfering with the natural process of evolution etc. However, GMO is not the first time we have done that. We alter biodiversity through farming and gardening as well. We also do it when we urbanize areas. Now sure, we should be wary of it and limit human activity and preserve biodiversity but there are bounds of reason to it. We cant just stop farming now, can we? Another way humans have altered biodiversity is through making hybrids throughout centuries. Now, GMO's are often not that different. There are other problems with GMO's like GMO's can self replicate so they are costlier for farmers to grow (not regarding bananas but other crops that need to be sown and reaped seasonally), some use a lot of fertilizer and massive amounts of water etc. And sure, we can start having  a conversation about that and whether those particular kinds of crop need to be grown to begin with. However, when we are talking about a pandemic wiping out an entire fruit which is a nutritional source and income source to millions of people around the world, using this kind of GMO is fine, IMO. Here it is functioning to preserve the species. So, I would like to hear what concerns people have regarding it.

Actually, there is something called saba banana which originates in the Philippines which mostly used for cooking (even when ripe, the "meat" of the fruit is a bit tough, but exposing it to heat by means of boiling really softens it). While cooking it unripe is usually a common diet regime for people in the provinces, the cooked semi-ripe to ripe version of it is a common dessert favorite amongst Filipinos (ie. Banana-Q). I think Dave might like the cooked version of the ripe saba. Goes really well with chocolate, caramel and brown sugar, but it's good to eat on its own.

I've actually been looking for a forum to talk about this ~ thanks ann for bringing up VPNs and their effect on browsing.  I have been a very satisfied Nord VPN customer for several years now, but if you connect to amerikan servers and browse the web, youre going to run into the same 'speed-bump' again and again: recaptcha tests.  this is a direct consequence of the end of 'net-neutrality' in amerika, and a perfect example of what a biased internet looks like. when you access a page on the internet, the host server can tell if they are reading your home IP and seeing your actual personal info (for mining later) of if you are coming from a VPN IP, and they can't use that information for profit, so they force you to take a recaptcha test. (the claim is that the test is to test youre not a robot~ that's baloney. it's to force free labor from you or persuade you to turn off your VPN and let them have your real IP) so the amerikan net is biased towards non-private browsing, harassing VPN users with visual tests at every oppertunity

I personally don't have much issue with the environmental effects of GMO's, as long as they've been researched to make sure that they won't negatively affect an ecosystem if seeds happen to take root outside of a farm. Most GMO's significantly reduce the use of chemicals in agriculture--I mostly just take issue with a) the GMO's that are specifically designed to be resistant to pesticides and herbicides rather than resistant to pests and weeds; and b) when the patent on a GMO seed is so tightly held that farmers have no choice but to become reliant on purchasing the seeds year after year from a company (lookin' at you, Monsanto).

actually the chocolate in the banana is something we do in switzerland. We cut the banana open, put chocolate in, wrap it in tin foil and then put it in the fire. Then when the chocolate is melted you just take a spoon and eat everything out of the peel. we call it chocolate-banana.

Re: GMO bananas (or anything). My problem in general is that most issues of crop- or plantation-destroying diseases are due to mono-cultivation. If crop rotation or multi-crop practices were used, the soil would be healthier and many of these issues wouldn't exist.  Furthermore, we don't know how these modifcations will affect things in 50 or so years, and it's just as likely another disease will arise. It feels like kicking the can down the road, treating the symptoms but not the underlying cause.
GMO all the food we eat as been cultivated over Centuries to our preference. What I don't prefer is how companies are holding seeds to ransom.

There‚Äôs nothing inherently wrong with GMO crops. We‚Äôve been genetically modifying food sources for thousands of years through selective breeding. The issue comes in when corporations patent a specific genetically modified crop and monopolize that crop. An example would be Monsanto monopolizing the canola industry by patenting their roundup ready canola plants.

About bananas and chocolate: that's one of the favorite recipe of french scouts (https://www.latoilescoute.net/banane-braisee-au-chocolat). We wrap the whole thing in tin foil and cook that under the embers during summer camp. And it is delicious at that moment : a nice summer evening, with friends around a campfire anything edible is delicious. Of course, it's also one of those things you avoid to eat at home, because out of context, it's not so good. Personally i have no issues with GMOs, in most cases results are comparable to one you get with selective breeding but you get product much faster. That said since a lot of population do have an issue with it (which may or may not be warranted, its irrelevant for this discussion) i think that now that we know wild sort of banana thats resistant to disease theres an option to experiment with grafting it to our common banana. Obviously it would be more expensive to make grafted plantation then GMO one since each plant would have to be grafted while GMO plants can just be reproduced asexually but it does provide an option that is generally viewed as organic. Lastly i would like to add that similar issue happened when phylloxera parasite wiped out most European vineyards mid 19th century. That issue was solved by grafting European sorts of vines with resistant American ones, which is still done to this day.

I have little sympathy for whole-cloth condemning of GMO. Through breeding, we've been modifying the genes of the plants we eat since agriculture began. All apple trees are effectively clones. Look the B. oleracea plant, from which Kale, Cabbage, Brussels sprouts, Broccoli and Cauliflower are all derived. Current technology merely allows us to genetically modify plants and animals much more precisely than every before, such as preserving the bananas people like but getting the gene that makes the resist this fungus. The alternative would be to find another grossly manipulated banana that would likely look and taste quite different and have different nutrients.  And yeah, I think the objection really falls flat when you consider that we've got 7 billion humans to feed.

Let me go on record.  As a child of 14 I lived in Fl in the USA, and one Summer we had a Walk-a-thon for MD.  I signed up to walk, and stripped down to nothing but shorts.  Me and two high school girls I met at the first check in point (I was going to quit then, but the three of us decided to join up and make it to the second check point before quitting.  Turns out we finished the entire 26 miles.  We walked during the HIGH time for sun shine, and my skin was so burned that I was in pain for days (that was years before I discovered--after another severe sunburn--that aspirins will kill the pain of the sunburn better than anything else.  I peeled for days and before you know it after about a week I was fine.  Now, according to the 'reports' (as repeated here) I was no on the road to probable skin cancer.  As I alluded above since that day all those decades ago I have sustained a number of severe sunburns and nope, not skin cancer.  All I am saying is that perhaps there are people who do get skin cancer--and maybe they are just more vulnerable by their DNA--and it has nothing to do with the number of sunburns you get at younger ages.

To sum up what is below, GMOs are fine, but our methods of mass homogeneous aggriculture are what make them dangerous. And they arent dangerous to us for consumption, because for the most part they are from other plants.  GMO's i feel are for the most part okay, the concern for GMO comes from the knowledge that foods that are modified are ones that have these built in resistances and people misunderstand that for meaning they produce their own pesticide/fungicides and there are concerns this will effect our health. To really be against GMO's i think more people should be doing adequate research rather than assuming the most likely subjective information they have heard as being true. I had to write a report about GMO's in college and for the most part while the process can seem really absurd, its usually taking naturally found gene's, not always from plants, but usually from familial species like with the bananas here in the video and have no actual repercussions in the realm of consumption. Another major issue people may have with GMO's comes from the fact that it is possible these modifications can then create super pests and super 'bugs' that are resistance to these modified plants, and could result in even worse crop die offs. We have a global culture of growing crops on a massive scale of all the same produce, and these massive spreads of land are what lead to pests and disease killing off crops very easily. GMOs being the solution are really only staving off the problem.

It's edible but not a very pleasant experience. Not all of the bananas in Indonesia are like that, but just one type of them.

There was an experiment I used to love doing that involved placing a black and white photo negative on the skin of a banana. Then using a strong UV light I could develop the photo from the negative upon the banana skin. If done properly you got quite a good detailed photo on the skin but it only lasted for a few hours depending on how fast the banana ripened. Was a fun and interesting little project. 9:45 Never ever use ready ground garlic powder. Due to the big surface it oxidizes really fast (within days after production) and looses its taste. If you don't want to use fresh one, use freeze-dried granulate* which then freshly ground (with a pepper mill) when you need it.   *= Like https://www.amazon.de/dp/B00A3NEC9Y/ (or https://www.amazon.com/dp/B01HZY8VUO/  or similar) Basically, they diced the garlic into small cubes before freeze drying it.

My primary concern when it comes to GMOs is someone claiming ownership of a gene via patent. I'm a staunch anti private property person, and that includes intellectual property.  The genetically inserted pesticide stuff companies did when they first got the technology was ill-conceived and the consequences weren't properly thought out; but it also made the product unsellable leading to a massive loss, so I don't think we have to worry too much about monsanto repeating that mistake: but patenting the only way to prevent banana groves from dying out, and using that patent to establish a monopoly on the fruit resulting in more explotation of the people who grow them, higher prices in the store, and possible shortages?   Yeah, I could see monsanto doing that,... again.

In regards to Panama disease: This is one of the consequences of monoculture. When all of the banana plants are clones, ie genetically identical to each other, one disease is going to affect all of your crop. You're not going to have plants that are naturally resistant to the disease, and the plant will not gain immunity.   I have an example for you. You may or may not be familiar with the plight of the Tasmanian Devil, and the cancer causing infectious disease that's spreading through their population. One of the outcomes of this issue was a population of devils that are naturally immune to DFTD (devil facial tumor disease). I learned about a case that applied to trees as well, but I can't remember it right now.  For more information, I recommend checking out the film Hungry for Profit (and why Dole isn't a good employer in the first place), and work by Vandana Shiva or watching the Deconstructing Supper film.  Also, it is wildly the opposite that there are no other banana cultivars that are edible or replace the cavendish. There are over 1,000 different banana cultivars that are consumed all around the world. Weird Explorer has documented several of them, and Miami Fruits sells variety packs so you can try them yourself.  A very real outcome of introducing the Goldfinger banana in first world countries is that we have it for another 50-100 years, and then a disease wipes out the population just as it did before. Arboreal disease that threatens extinction of a crop is not a unique problem specific to the Gros Michel, or the Cavendish. It's a consequence of monoculture and the current state of agribusiness. It could affect any monoculture crop that we currently have today, such as navels and tangerines.   The risk factors are still present with the Goldfinger, and that is why people are upset. You can see how it doesn't provide an adequate solution to the problem if the possibility still exists that we end up in the same scenario as before.

The cavendish banana is seedless so it is sterile. Because of that, all the trees in a plantation will be clones with the same genetic material (obtained through cuttings of a mother plant). It's due to this lack of genetic diversity that fungal diseases can spread so fast and be so deadly. Using GMOs might save the cavendish from that disease... until it doesn't anymore. Or until another fungus comes along... I fear that using GMOs is a short term fix for a larger problem. What the banana world needs right now is more genetic diversity (so more varieties of banana produced) and probably the end of big monoculture plantations.  Also, caramelised bananas and melted chocolate are delicious together! You slice the banana open, stick a bar of good dark swiss chocolate in it, wrap in alu foil, throw it in a fire, wait a bit and enjoy a great dessert for your outdoor picnic!

Enough already people, protein is NOTHING but a group of 22 amino acids, 9 of which body cannot synthetize so we get them from food. aw I was hoping you might mention that the loss of the gros michel banana as the main banana crop is the reason "banana flavored" candy tastes so weird to most people who were not alive before the 1950s. that's actually the context I originally learned about panama disease from. most banana candy flavoring is still today based on the banana flavoring that was created when gros michel bananas were still the main banana, and is meant to replicate them, more so than the cavendish! gros michel bananas have a higher concentration of whatever flavoring thing the candy flavors use, so that is what makes it taste different.  it's mentioned really briefly, but the gros michel isn't COMPLETELY gone from the world, it's just not able to be grown on such a large scale anymore for it to be exported all over the world in the way it used to be, or in the way the cavendish is. from what I understand if you are actually IN the places that can still grow it you might be able to get one, but it's nearly impossible to find them anywhere else.
When I hear gmo I think completely man made in a lab. Such things as gmo meat or imitation food is what I would consider gmo. Now if breeding 2 different kinds of fruits, vegetables, animals, etc to yield a bigger or more resilient food than I wouldn‚Äôt really consider it gmo. Basically anything that doesn‚Äôt naturally occur in nature can be classified as gmo. If you breed 2 chickens to make a bigger chicken, not really gmo. If you pump a small chicken full of gh and other things to make it bigger, definitely gmo. Either way I still think home grown or locally sourced is the best option

I feel many who are against GMOs are fearful of what they don't fully understand. I'm not saying they are dumb, I just think it's easier to say something is bad when it involves human intervention. In addition, many people equate GMOs with chemicals, which is not the case. It's just cross-breeding... like what people do with dogs when they like certain features of certain dogs. Now, that has resulted in some dogs being more predisposed to certain issues, but they don't become radioactive, chemical laden entities. It's just a new breed. And you bring up exactly why GMOs are important (and necessary in some cases) as the number of people in this world make it nearly impossible to maintain adequate food supply without some sort of intervention. There are so many foods we wouldn't have without GMOs, and so many more people who would be without food. Still, they should be regulated as many do use GMOs to profit off of farmers and things like that, but they do not pose physical harm. We've been genetically modifying food since the first farms were made.

The Cavendish banana is already genetically modified. It originally had the same large, hard seeds that wild bananas do, but was gradually bred to be seedless for human consumption. It is no longer able to reproduce on its own, requiring humans to make a cutting, grow the plant, and induce it to produce fruit. Considering the sheer number of changes humans have put this banana strain through to optimize it for ourselves, it seems kind of silly to balk at a simple horizontal gene transfer that prevents fungal infestation. Plants share genes between strains all the time, so it isn't nearly as detrimental as the mass sterilization we already did.

I'm not arguing against GMO but there are actually several edible varieties of banana other than cavendish. They taste different from cavendish (some even sweeter and honey-like) but can be eaten as they are with no seeds. There are also some other varieties that aren't suitable for raw consumption but can be cooked into edible and tasty foods such as flour-coated fried banana. Some of these types are really starchy and still have seeds which are why they aren't suitable for raw consumption.  Source: I'm Indonesian. Bananas grow everywhere here, including my backyard, and even most of the wild ones in the towns and villages can be eaten raw (after they are ripe).

13:45 - that's like an indoor version of a campfire treat we called "Banana Boats". Just pull down the inner peel, leaving it attached at the bottom. Make slits along the length & poke in chocolate chips or a broken bar & mini marshmallows. Some of my girl scouts liked to smear peanut butter on all that. Cover with the peel flap, wrap in foil and bake in the coals of your campfire for about 10 minutes. It's an upscale s'more.

If you have overly ripe banana...but not rot...you can have banana fritter with it.  Cut up the banana, add flour, a little bit of salt, baking soda, milk, sugar and honey. The texture should be heavy. Like pancake batter but a little heavy.  Deep fried them in hot oil with small fire.  It will take a while. And if it started to look like its burnt, don't worry it is supposed to be a little dark brown/black. The sugar in banana and the batter will start caramelized and turn darker.  The outside texture will be crunchy and sweet. The inside will be very soft.  ... Or you can browse any video that tittled "pisang goreng madu" This recipe works better with overly ripe banana as they contain a lot of sugar in them that will caramelized as thet fried. And that'll help to get the sweet crunchy texture on the outside.

People misunderstand a lot of things including GMO. There is nothing wrong with GMO foods - we have been genetically breeding plants for many years. What you are eating today as corn or watermelon or carrot is not what wild plants look like. Look up what carrot looked like before we bred it to look the way it does today if you are curious.  If you want to take GMO entirely out of your diet - stop eating most of the vegetables present in today's grocery stores because they are all genetically modified. Even if the label says non-GMO - cross breeding plants is genetic modification. Issue with GMO could be corporations forcing farmers to purchase their patented cultivars like in this case with banana industry which not all farmers can afford. So a better way to say this would be - support your local farmers vs "I only buy non GMO" or "GMO vegetables/fruits are bad for you"- that is just not making any sense at all.

Here is what they tried to do with monstera leaf (poor monstera lol).... They took a cutting of monstera with a node and stuck it into a humid banana. 1. Banana itself has to decompose for a plant to actually be able to absorb nutrients. 2. Leaf tissue does not absorb nutrients in monstera, air and ground roots do.  3. Monstera are tropical species and like humidity in general and to propagate in.... So, what they were lucky that monstera did anything and did not rot. They probably took a node with a leaf that had a beginings of the aerial root growth. Therefore that node attempted to survive by shooting the aerial root. Reason why your experiment failed is - your leaf did not have a node. However, hehe, chances it would have worked are about 50/50, banana is only a hinderance here to propagation, not a hack or contributor to success by any means. I am so tired of these channels spreading misinformation at large - it is at the worst dangerous and at the least just plain misinformation causing folks to stick things into bananas that dont belong there... lol.
Why are people against GMOs?? We artificially synthesize so many things, plastics and medicines and so many every-day items are entirely made by man. Human beings have always done things to control crops. I have never once heard a sound argument against eating GMOs. Even the term "GMO" has only a loosely agreed upon definition; a genetically modified organism. Pugs are genetically modified organisms, so is every single ear of corn you've ever seen. Even if an ear of corn says it's "Non-GMO Verified". Those little tags are more of a marketing scheme than an honest effort to inform the masses. Modern day corn has been selectively bred for so long that we wouldn't even recognize what it used to be.  When a farmer cross breeds two plants by hand he's hoping to get the genetic result he wants. When a genetic engineer sees a certain disease ruining people's livelihoods- he has the ability to cross breed with precision, and we generalize his lab techniques down to "Genetic Engineering" and suddenly everyone's afraid of it? What are the dangers? Can someone please explain to me why so many are turning away in disgust at some of the most amazing scientific leaps that could end world hunger?

As I understand it, all of our cavendish bananas are genetically identical clones. They already only exist by human intervention. I don't see why GMO bananas are any creepier (or dangerous) than that. I'd eat a GMO banana, unless someone provides evidence that it isn't safe for me to eat.
GMO is just a hyper-speed timelapse of selective breeding. Instead of cross breeding pea plants for 20 years to get the traits you want, you can have the same results within months or less by isolating the genes and introducing them to the subject at hand. Thats literally ALL it is. People hate gmos because it's the new buzzword- they have zero clue what GMO means, and assume it means that theyre putting pig DNA into pineapples or bear DNA into pears or whatever else. They don't know that pretty much EVERYTHING modern is the reslt of GMOs. Watermelons, tomatoes, corn, peas, freaking DOGS. Those were just the longer-term versions done through selective breeding. I always laugh at how every single plant in the springtime says, "Non-GMO!" Like.... Yeah, Bonnie, your heirloom tomatoes are definitely not modified in any way. They're definitely not from modified plants. That's why they're poisonous, because they're still their original nightshade variants. Oh wait, no- they are edible because we used SCIENCE to produce a beautiful, edible, Adonis. ü§ó
In our hometown, we actually do eat banana peel! It's just that it has to be a certain type of raw, green bananas (locally called jahaji kol) and it can be used to make tasty chutneys, koftas, deep fried vegetables balls and even dumplings!
Ive not finished the video yet, but apples CAN help others ripen more quickly as they produce a TON of ethylene gas. It's why they encourage you to keep apples with good contact to air so they dont ripen too quickly. Hence why they have air in the bags and they tell you not to put them in the fridge. Of course, it won't work with all fruits, but it is a thing! Alton Brown has even talked about it in the past.

Genetically modifying foods, in and of itself, is not where my problem with it lies. I am not "creeped out" by the idea, I don't think it somehow magically becomes monstrous, it's not going to sprout legs and run around squealing or eat my cats. Like any other science, responsible and ethical application is the biggie. A huge issue with Monsanto's genetic modifications, as an example, is that they modify crops to be resistant to specific pesticides so that they can then literally just DROWN them in pesticides and the crop plant won't die. Doesn't prevent the pesticide from remaining on or even partly in the harvest, doesn't keep hundreds of thousands of gallons of pesticides out of the water table or from devastating wild local flora or beneficial fauna. And that's not even touching the practice of forcing GMO strains of a crop on someone contractually in such mass quantity that it alters the environment and pollinates heirloom crops many miles away, ruining those. So...tl;dr like any other science GMOs can be used for good or evil and usage is what we should examine, not their very existence.

I wanna point out that with the Gros Michel and Cavendish are basically all clones, hence being seedless. So there is no genetic diversity in these. my problem with the whole anti-gmo thing is the same problem i have with the anti-vaxxers... a lot of misinformation and very little Actual common (or rather Uncommon at this point) sense behind it. if you looked at the history of man, Everything's "gmo". humans Had to modify All their wild agriculture in order to Have one in the first place. oats weren't like we have now, nor were Any of the grains we survive on. none of the animals we use to survive on are any where Near what they were when we first started to domesticate them. it's just how things Are. if you want to survive on something more than roots and berries you Happen upon instead of growing yourself, it's going to have to be tweaked to grow when and where you want it to. from the coffee we drink to the bacon we eat to the meatless stuff we ate instead of meat. it's all been tinkered with. there's absolutely Nothing that Is Completely Natural &/or Organic (which is a misnomer... if something grows, it's organic. if it's made of something nonliving like plastic Then it's inorganic. oi.) or at least in the sense of being free of our influence on it anyway. even the throwback grains people are glomping on to these days... do people think that the seeds for these things were just conveniently laying around somewhere... neither touched by man nor beast? no. they had to be reverse engineered. so even Those aren't "true copies" because chances of being able to get an Exact copy of something that only exists in the guts of some long dead critter is between slim and none. i get the movement away from highly processed food stuffs. i do. and i think it's a good thing. but people need to understand there's a big difference between something that's made sustainable through tweaking the genetics and something that's little more than a can of spam. people really need to educate themselves better if they're serious about doing things the Right way instead of just whatever a fad Says to do.

I've done the chocolate one before, it is really good imo (but we don't heat it so long that it actually cooks)
I generally have no problem with GMOs as I don't view it as being too different from the human directed selection processes that have lead to basically all of our modern fruits and vegetables even existing, and in cases where genetic modifications will protect subsistence foods, I think there is little reason to be concerned about them. However, I think that cases in which varieties of food-crops are being genetically modified for the express purpose of allowing corporations to claim sole ownership over them, or to prevent the crops from self-seeding so that farmers MUST repurchase seeds every year, show complete moral bankruptcy.
Even if GMO was something I was leery of, and it is not, splicing a banana with a banana to create a slightly different banana really is the extreme shallow end of the practice. I can't imagine anyone reasonable having a problem with that, especially when the alternative is no bananas at all.
Okay, bananas are literally sold with a taped top in our stores, so...
Imagine seeing someone rub a banana peel on their face in public
The real problem with GMO is that it's usually left as a black box process that companies use to make more money. You only have the companies assurances that they have been diligent and tested the new product extensively before they sell it.  Having a researcher doing long term experiments on the process makes it much much better, the process is more open, it's less likely to being rushed due to investor concerns.  The old method of modifying crops and animals involved having said products surviving naturally for a number of generations before it was considered a new breed (10 generations for a new dog breed, for instance). In other words, you are forced to test it properly, and you know they don't have a fatal flaw that will wipe out the product. And it's less likely they have some sort of unintended effect like adding a compound that kills your kidneys by eating them.  Afaik CRISPR has been proven to add unintended genome changes in some cases, resulting in completely random changes. Combine this with a pressure to get it to market asap and to hide the process entirely and you have a huge problem. Sooner or later a product will go into stores that has long term negative effects, either to the ecosystem or to the consumers. As long as the companies actually are as diligent as is necessary that won't happen. But the longer it's allowed to be a black box without any oversight and extensive testing the higher the risk is to everyone.  TLDR: properly done GMO can be safe, life saving and has no negative impact on the ecosystem. Improperly done it's mad science with a veneer of respectability and someone is sooner or later going to make this obvious, though we can hope the positives outweigh the negatives during at least our lifetimes.

Basically all of the plants we eat are genetically modified in one manner or another. In addition, genetically modifying plants doesn't make them any different other than that they have different DNA, which is what makes all varieties of plants unique. The science is very clear that there's nothing about GMOs that makes them inherently dangerous or bad and there's nothing about naturally occurring plants that makes them safe. There are plenty of very dangerous and poisonous naturally occurring plants. Since you've garnered this pro-science persona (which I love and I think is very well deserved), I hope you do a video sometime in the future educating your audience about GMO food and why there's nothing wrong with it.

Banana's have already been GMO plants thanks to selective breeding in order to get rid of those large seeds and to select for a more sweet taste. Replacing a gene within them in order for them to be resistant to TR4 will not make them any more "dangerous" to eat than they already were. The debates about GMO plants should focus on concerns surrounding biodiversity and the selection for fungicide and herbicide resistant insects, NOT whether they are unsafe to eat because there is absolutely no evidence of that at all. :) In this case it seems like a no brainer to switch to these new GMCs in order to help the low income farmers and communities who rely so heavily on growing and selling bananas. :) -  Singed: a microbiology student

GMO is great. Where the problem comes in is capitalism and trademark where there is one type of GMO crop and the seeds are sold through one cooperation and individual producers are prevented from breeding their own crops. Okay, the banana and chocolate thing? That is an old recipe I learned in girlscouts. You peel off part of the banana like you did, scoop out part of it, add in hershey bar pieces and marshmallows cover with the peel, wrap in foil and put in the  coals of a fire. After a few moments, you take it out with tongs, let it cool off, remove the foil and eat with a spoon. It is called Banana Boats. And warm banana is good, but maybe it is a matter of a texture issue for Dave. Here is a wikipedia article about it https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Banana_boat_(food)

RE GMOs: technically most if not all food is a GMO due to humans inventing agriculture (dogs, cows and basically all livestock and domesticated animals, potatoes, corn, peaches, apples, etc etc) and practicing selective breeding to create species with the qualities we needed/wanted, now we can just do it faster with gene editing technology. the problem is when companies patent the genes of something they developed, or make sterile seeds so farmers have to go back to them every year to buy more seeds instead of saving seeds for planting next year as has been done since we figured out farming, and then companies sue farmers for saving the seeds, and sue farmers for saving seeds from cross pollinated plants. so i don't have a problem with GMO as people use the term today, I have a problem with what companies do with it that negate all the good that could come from using GMOs if things like sterile seeds and suing over cross pollination didn't happen

Anti-GMO propaganda a is big hoax to make you pay more money for "natural" (which legally doesn't mean anything btw) products. Humans have been genetically modifying plants and animals for millennia through selective breeding. Doing it by using direct gene editing is not all that different once you understand it. Should scientists proceed with caution? Yes. Obviously. But GMO's are one of our best tools for tackling issues like world hunger, malnutrition, and economic instability. Don't let new wave "holistic health" gurus whose only research credentials are biased google searches fool you.
One bad sunburn when you're young doubles your risk of melanoma??? Aw man, I got a really bad sunburn when I was 18...
The issue I have with GMO food isn't that I think they're evil, there is no such thing as a "natural" food stuff because almost everything we eat like corn, wheat, fruits like watermelon, and many other foods are selectively breed over thousands of years by our ancestors to make them edible! We're simply doing what our ancestors have done, just a lot faster. The issue with GMO foods is the idea of a company owning an entire species of foodstuff, it's no longer food, it's a copyrighted product that they control down to a cellular level. We've seen this happen with Monsanto suing farmers because their crops cross-pollinated with their copyrighted property and, if they want to withhold their property to keep prices high, then what's to stop them? But, because of this, I'm not anti-GMO, I actually think that we need EVEN MORE GMO research that it done through public funds so that these new foodstuffs belong to everyone, not just one singular corporation. GMOs are not inherently evil and can actually bring so much good to the world, but, as with all technology, what matters is why it is being done and who is doing it.

I realize I'm not the most educated when it comes to GMO's, but there is a certain complacency that comes with not fearing something. When I was first introduced to the concept, I compared it to a practice as old as agriculture itself: when choosing which crops to replant, pick the seeds from the crops with the most desirable qualities. Size, flavor, ability to withstand cold nights or other climate factors, etc. While I don't think people should be seeking glow-in-the-dark hamsters, essentially cross-breeding crops (through a process which is just a more exact science compared to traditional cross-breeding, from my limited understanding) is nothing to be afraid of or look down on. A uni near me does (or did when I was first learning of the practice) GMO-related studies on apples, I believe comparing the practice to traditional hybridization (I was quite young, so memory is failing me here, but I believe the results were delicious). It just never seemed that weird to me, at least in terms of making food that tastes better or survives better.

/ is a forward slash. \ is a back slash.
As for the supposed "Genetically modified" argument... what the professor did was to take two variants of the same overall thing, i.e. a different banana, to create the new hybrid... I think there is also a type of rice that got spliced with a non food producing cousin that had a desired resistance and produced a more robust food producing grain... a further variant of this is long term selective breeding for specific traits as evidenced with various domesticated animals, vegetables, fruits, etc... nearly **ALL** of our food has had that done over time and is not a problem...   The next stage is when plants from the same next higher level or "further separated" are gene spliced together... I can't come up with a specific example off the top of my head, but it is similar to combining a plum with an apricot for a "pluot"...  these are close enough to still be somewhat compatible and continue to reproduce on their own once combined... these are far rarer occurrences, but are definitely happy accidents when discovered and are also not a problem.  The issue is when genes from wildly divergent species like the corn genome is combined with say an insect gene, essentially something that is completely different, and then used to produce foods with a specific trait... much like the corn that must be grown with a heavily used pesticide and is used throughout it's life cycle... it also cross contaminates anything and everything nearby in often unknown ways, is quite often a sterile species that does not reproduce well without that assistance, and finally is very heavily and aggressively policed and sued over by the originating companies.... Now **THOSE** are a real problem... these companies are very much like a drug dealer in that once you are "hooked" by their product, it is very difficult to get away from using it for the rest of your life... the farmers become essentially serfs to the company involved with very little to no further choices available... these companies are also rather disapproving (if not downright nasty) about farmers maintaining "legacy" of their own from several decades before their product.

I don't have a problems with Cisgenesis GMO
The UV experiment was really cool! I never would have thought of using the color changing beads that way.
I'm fine with GMOs unless a specific one has been proven to be dangerous. I don't see it as that different from the selective breeding people have been doing with fruits and veg to make them more abundant, easier to grow, and more nutritious for centuries. The fruit and veg we eat today are so different from what the fruit and veg people had even one hundred years ago. For the most part, the changes have led to more nutrition for more people and less land required for farming, meaning that most countries who have had an industrial revolution are now able to give more land back to nature. If GMOs mean we can use less land and feed more people, I'm all for them. It's only those of us with food security privilege that get to be picky about eating "organic" or not. Worries about pesticides and GMOs go out the window when you're starving.

GMOs are the only way we'll be able to feed the entire human population. The only time they become unacceptable is when we genetically modify animals such that it negatively impacts their quality of life. The idea of organic and non-GMO food is overwhelmingly a marketing ploy and absolutely does not represent higher quality. In addition, saturation of the market or social pressure to buy non-GMO produce actively makes it harder for lower-income people to afford healthier diets as affordable produce becomes less accessible.   TL;DR: GMOs (in the plant world and with rigorous testing of foodstuffs to ensure safety) are good

GMOs are fine - it's megacorporations misusing and exploiting them that is the problem. Literally every crop we eat is technically a GMO. The case you mentioned here reminds me of the now-in-the-FDA-approval-process GMO American Chestnut tree produced by the labs up at SUNY ESF, since they spliced in some genes to make it cooperate with the chestnut blight instead of suffer from it. GMOs are amazing innovations that can change the world. It's the misuse of them that is the problem. When people claim things like "GMOs are evil" it really grinds my gears, as an environmental science student partnered to an agriculture major. People: don't look at Monsanto and think that their practices mean that all GMOs are bad. The tech is not the enemy; it's the people using it to make money while driving other people bankrupt and holding the tech ransom from the rest of the world. Sorry this got a bit long! but I have extremely strong feelings about the incredible technological marvels that we've created with genetic modification (the fast kind, not the slow kind that is selective breeding and is what has been used to create every single food crop we consume en masse) and also extremely strong feelings about the corporations that misuse these marvels for the gain of a very small percentage of people.
