We do eat peel of raw banana (not the ripe yellow one but the green one), you boil the banana for some other recipe but don't discard the peel. Heat up a little bit of mustard oil and fri a few whole red chillies and 2 cloves of garlic till they start releasing aroma. Add the whole concoction to the boiled peels and grind them in morter and pestle with some salt and black pepper. Viola there you go, a spicy dip.
I'm fine with responsible and kind GMOs, but the companies are sometimes really scummy. There are companies that have produced plants that have negatively impacted wildlife and the environment. There are also companies that do shady things like suing farmers for "using" their crops without a licence, even though it turned out to be an issue with bee transferring pollen from one farm to another thus transferring the genes of the companies' crops to other farms that didn't have a license for those crops.   Most food we eat has been modified genetically either over generations by plant growers or over the course of a few years in a lab. I don't have an issue with the food. I'm surprised you didn't mention the reason the main edible banana the world eats doesn't have seeds and is uniquely edible is because.... it's all clones!   They were specially bred to be edible (it's odd to be against genetically modified food considering before we had science to do it, we were meddling in plants like this), and every single cavendish banana is a clone of the others genetically. Plants are super easy to splice and clone without any science, and people have been doing it for hundreds of years. However with bananas, it's really pretty ridiculous how we only have ONE edible one! It makes it very susceptible to disease because we bred them to all be identical, asexual (no seeds means no natural reproduction) plants. So one bad disease easily spreads. I live in a semi rural area in South Africa and can confirm that wild monkeys will eat the peel of any fruit along with the fruit and normally eat up to the pip and throw it away. This is one of nature's way of spreading seeds. If a fruit has small pips or no pips they will still eat up to 2/3 or more but never 100% of the fruit. They prefer fruit over veggies.

As far a GMO goes mankind has been genetically modifying food sources since the beginning of agriculture, look at the tomato, potato, corn, apples, even animals. Any food source that has been "bred" for a higher yield than the "original" is Genetically Modified.  Majority of people think its a fairly recent thing, past 50-80 years, but it isnt, Archaeologists and Paleontologists have proven that. To me, GMO is too blanket of a term. People have been selectively breeding animals, or cross breeding plants for thousands of years. I don't consider this to be genetically modifying a plant. To me, it is only an issue when you are taking genes from a completely different plant, or species and inserting it into another. Like making cats that have bioluminescence, or putting genes from a bacteria into corn to make it drought resistant. Crossing/adding genes from one banana plant into another, is not really an issue. This could happen in nature.

Not sure if others have commented, but the one where they microwave the banana with chocolate is very similar to something made by a lot of people on camping trips in the USA.  We slice open the banana and then you add add stuf f such as chocolate chip (or other baking chips), marshmallows, nuts, coconut, or whatever else you have laying around that sounds good.  wrap in Aluminium foil and put in the coals for a few minutes.  It is a fun camping dessert to do with kids.  Each person makes their own so they can make a banana mess they like.
There's only one true banana hack: Got brown bananas? Make banana bread. Banana bread's good  Also, I'm just gonna jump into the breach for good ol' wilgubeast. I've tracked down the studies, a)"Relationship between browning and the activities of polyphenoloxidase and phenylalanine ammonia lyase in banana peel during low temperature storage" from Postharvest Biology and Technology, b) "FRUIT AND VEGETABLES: ENZYMIC BROWNING" by the Institute of Food Science and Technology, and c) "Ethylene" by Margaret Sauter of Hamburg University. a) mentions " As [chilling injuries] developed, [enzyme] activities in the peel increased, and total free phenolics decreased." b) "[W]hen the fruit is sliced, or squashed, or when the fruit or vegetable begins to break down with age, the enzymes come into contact with oxygen in the air." and c) "Many climacteric fruits such as apple, banana and tomato show a strong increase in ethylene levels at the late green or breaker stage. [...] Ethylene levels are especially high in the separating tissues resulting in abscission of the fruit. [...] Biotic and abiotic stresses frequently result in formation of ethylene. [...] Ethylene is neither actively transported nor degraded." So, there's definitely a thread that could be spun from those cherry-picked quotes, and the statement that there's no mention of bananas isn't _quite_ right (if I'm assuming correctly that Ann's referring to the Hamburg study, they explicitly mention bananas, that the enzyme concentrates around broken tissue and that it doesn't spread inside the banana). Not saying I'd agree with it when it's demonstrably not a feasible way to preserve bananas, but I can see how the idea formed. Sorry for being so nitpicky, but I'm just a sucker when it comes to scavenger hunts like finding badly sourced articles xD  PS: Oh real quick, the first article also explains why bananas turn brown quicker in the cold, quote: "The results indicate that low temperature stress induced concerted activities of PAL and PPO, which resulted in browning."

About the modified bananas: I am against genetically modified fruits, but having a modified one is better than not having bananas at all anymore.
Thank you for explaining about the banana process and the problem with the disease. I would eat the genetically modified banana because it uses other banana plants/cells to produce it. I have a problem with genetically modified foods when they take something completely foreign to the fruit/vegetable, like sea creatures, without being aware of the side effects. But to be honest, the thought that castoreum is still used as a food flavouring in America and is only labelled "natural flavouring" horrifies me.
This reason that diseases are so good at wiping out bananas is because bananas aren't grown from seeds. Indeed, most cultivated bananas aren't fertile. We instead clone them, and because they're clones, and therefore exact copies of the original plant, they can't evolve to build up a resistance to the diseases. So yeah, the best option is to just genetically modify bananas in order to build up a resistance to it.  As you mention, wild bananas are chock a block full of seeds. Because the job of a banana is to convince a chimp to crack open a yellow one with the boys and shit them out, not to give humans a tasty snack.
With regards to GMOs, I think the dichotomy of ecology and technology is a false one. The use of GMOs isn't much different from other ways which humans have been using to interface with plants and animals for thousands of years. And so the question becomes how one would define "technology" and if it's possible for humans to interact with "nature" without creating a "technology" The problem really comes when companies like Monsanto use this technology in ways that create horrible situations for people in the name of their own profit (copyrighting Genes and such). There is also this issue of preserving genetic diversity, which is the issue that killed the gros menage banana, is is currently killing the Cavendish. The banana crops have become genetically homogenous and vulnerable because of selective breeding, and if we can save people from starvation by doing a targeted rapid version of selective breeding than we should obviously do it.

4:40 I fact checked this claim and uh it's not entirely accurate "While experts often focus on childhood sunburns as the primary risk factor for CM, our pooled analyses found increased risk of CM for sunburns experienced in adolescent, adult and lifetime number of sunburns as well as childhood. However, analyses per decade suggest a stronger association if individuals continue to experience sunburns at the same rate per decade into adulthood, and thus over a lifetime. Ultimately, these pooled data show that sunburns, regardless of timing, affect the risk of CM." https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2873840/ *CM = Cutaneous Melanoma  In short, sunburn at any point in life increases the risk of melanoma. Frequency seems to be a stronger factor than timing.

We‚Äôve been genetically modifying plants and animals for centuries through selective breeding. Now we can be more precise, bananas can beat a disease and golden rice could save hundreds of thousands of lives and loads of other cool stuff I can‚Äôt think of right now, but can‚Äôt be bothered to look up.   The only real downside is the potential for people to circumvent checks and balances, carry out sloppy research, be poorly regulated in the first place or fund politicians who will reduce regulation for you, or straight up fabricate data, or bribe people, or a load of shit I can‚Äôt think of right now!  But the point is all of those risks exist in all human endeavour. Genetically modified food exists, it‚Äôs now among the things we have created. We can‚Äôt go back, so all we are left with is how we manage it, like any other knowledge or resource.   Sadly, we don‚Äôt seem to have a great track record when it comes to managing our resources, but I think we are getting better. Too slowly, but better, and GM food seems to be a good contender for part of the solution.
Another wonderful video, dear Anne. üåª Just one quick note regarding eating fruit peel: the insectizides and pesticides they use for bananas, citrus fruits etc can not be washed off. Those substances penetrate the outer layer of the peel, so you just shouldn't eat it.

NICE HAIRSTYLE DAVE!
Given that the Cavendish banana is already so heavily modified for human consumption via artificial selection, I really don't see a problem with using tech-based horizontal gene transfer to give them a resistance to a blight.  The thing that would worry me is that if private companies are allowed to patent that one scientist's work, they would use it as yet another profit vector through which to extract more money from the labor and resources of those communities that rely on banana farming.  I can easily see large companies suing to keep those farmers from propagating the plants themselves without licenses from the corporation, and lobbying the power of the states those people live in to force the issue.
I don't have an issue with GMOs conceptually, but I don't think it's a good idea to use them to create a new monoculture to replace a failing monoculture. Part of it comes from consumer expectations of consistent products, but if we had many different types of bananas, grown where they're best suited and sold where they're most easily shipped, the food supply chain would be much safer. As it is, who is to say the exact same thing won't happen to Cavendish 2.0 that happened to Cavendish 1.0 and the Gros Michel? We don't have this problem with apples because consumers like having varieties. Nothing saying we couldn't foster the same love for other produce.
If you ever wondered why banana flavored candy doesn't really taste like bananas, its because the flavor standard used is  the 1950's Gros Michel that was wiped out.
Half of what we eat is GMO? Like orange carrots aren't like that, and we wouldn't even have Cavendish bananas or Ghost Peppers without genetically modifying them.

Gmo crops absolutely have their place in food imo  Especially when they're yk Preventing a fruit to go extinct and help keep a food shortage at bay
For my thoughts on GMO, people misunderstand the different kinds of genetically modifying and lump them all together. It should be obvious to anyone that even imperfect, this sort of banana-saving research is also LIFE-saving research and very important. (Genetic modifying really is just a more purified form of selective breeding in a lot of ways, anyway.) They should not be mad about this! The kind of GMOs I think people should be upset about are "seedless" and "exclusive" breeds that companies like Monsanto make, as well as the whole concept of "seed copyright" and what have you. GMOs can absolutely be dangerous or used to hurt people, but the problem with that is in the companies doing it deliberately, and not in the whole concept of genetically modifying an organism. We've been doing that in one form or another for as long as selective breeding has existed, after all.
GMO issue is basically a non-starter... Every crop and cultivar we eat are GMO. In fact the wild banana you showed illustrates this very well. The difference is that we're now actively putting in the genes we want instead of waiting for mutations and then selecting based on the ones we want. Its still mostly the same process, the difference being we're speeding it up by decades or even centuries.  Portugal (Madeira Island) actually has a different-ish banana cultivar from the regular ones. I've seen it described as a Dwarf Cavendish (and it is basically a smaller, sweeter version of regular bananas).
I actually think that GMFs are beneficial because it benefits us far more than it harms us. Many fruits and vegetables could've been gone extinct if we didn't have such technology. Also you can modify a plant's genetics to make it taste/look better. I wouldn't want to eat a tasteless or ugly looking fruit myself (sorry for body-shaming fruits). Yes, it might cause some health problems rarely, but GMFs help farmers earn more money since plants are their main source of money. I wouldn't mind the possible health problems. I don't even want to make it past 40 so yeah. we stan GMFs <3<3<3
Hi :) I'm a follower from Costa Rica. Actually we grow bananas and plantains. The root problem with deseases is monoculture. We don't need expensive bio tech, we need Global North banana lovers to stop buying bananas from unsustainable semi slavery plantations.

@HowToCookThat You are 100% wrong about the "Zombie" banana hack. They did NOT use erasable ink. The trick to this is just freezing the banana long enough that it starts to turn brown. Then use the hair drier to warm it up and it goes back to yellow again (For a few hours at least). Your channel is starting to turn into those fake ones, like you are making fun of....

I always thought that hanging bananas was simply a convenient way to store them for easy grabbing. It can be awkward to move a bunch of round items (apples, citrus, etc) out of the way to get one off the hand. That's why I got a fruit bowl with a banana hanger.
I am a big fan of Ann Reardon and think she does an excellent job for science education and debunking through these videos. I have to say, though, I'm a little disappointed by her noncommittal stance on GMOs here. I think she set up well to make a hard point on the safety and importance of GMOs in our world, and make people question their fears. GMO is a process, a tool. It's no more inherently harmful than Mendel messing around with his peas. And, thus far, there have been no safety concerns with any commercialized GMO-made crops.  GMOs are important and can do so much good in the world. The idea that our bananas are "natural" and new ones would be made from "playing god" is a fallacy. There's a reason that Cavendish bananas don't have seeds, and grow to be large and sweet, and it's certainly not from random chance. We've selectively bred them to be that way, which is as "unnatural" as adding in a gene that will let many continue have access to this important crop.  Ann, you're an amazing person and I love the job you're doing! I hope you read this and think a little more in depth about the importance of GMOs! (Also, a really great article that goes through a lot of these points in more depth: https://jcom.sissa.it/sites/default/files/documents/JCOM_1504_2016_Y01.pdf)
I used to work at Whole Foods, I was once almost denied a promotion for a pro-GMO stance. GMOs are how are able to feed whole nations that would otherwise exist in a perpetual state of famine.

I think with GMO, the way the US wants things labelled is part of the problem.  Lab GMO is usually what concerns people (as opposed to assisted cross breeding + active selection), but in the US labelling requirements mean that regardless of method if you change the DNA it's GMO, but it's not well regulated. Many producers thusly use GMO free on their packaging regardless of where it's being exported to, and some things that were modified using non lab techniques are vilified. Now for an actual banana hack: if you're like me and enjoy bananas with green ends, the stems are sometimes a huge pain to open. Dig your fingernail into the other end of the banana and peel from there. It will open so much easier.
I am a chemistry master student and we get a lot of talks about current research. One of the big questions that someone asked during a lecture about genetically modified cyanobacteria for biofuel production about the risk of these GMOs negatively effecting the environment. This professor said that many GMOs are actually designed to not survive outside of the environment they are modified to survive in. They always add a fail safe.  This is of course bacteria and not a plant. I'm not a biologist by any means, but I can see the merits of GMO. I think this technology can allow us to solve issues like this. We can use these to help maintain biodiversity. I think a lot of people are worried about the impact of these foods on them or the environment. All they are doing is adding pieces of DNA to change how the cells act. They are tested and done in a controlled manner. It takes years for this stuff to come onto the market. And, like I said earlier, they are also often modified with a fail safe to help maintain biodiversity if the GMO is a crop or bacteria. Scientists are really not trying to kill people or the environment here. Promise

What I'd love is for the resistance genes to be put into some of the old variety of banana plants-- I've heard there are some still around, just not enough for a wide-scale industry. And artificial banana flavor is supposedly a better imitation of those bananas than most artificial fruit flavors are of the fruit they're meant to represent. I'd really like to be able to test for myself, see if that's true, potentially have bananas that aren't bland and boring like the current variety often seem to me... Even if they aren't actually anything like the artificial banana flavor, it would still be great for a number of reasons to not be relying completely on a single variety of bananas, which we pretty much are, aren't we?
From my experience having worked in the food industry, GMOs at least in my opinion represent a crucial solution to food security from the point of view of plants and vegetables. We need to understand that some plants often face the threat of extinction or are classified as poor yield crops that have been revived with the help of genetic modification. I do believe that legislation and regulations should help ensure good practices, however, with the current scenario we face, without GMOs, the entire global population will break down if crops are not resistant to newer virus strains.

The chocolatey banana is actually a quite common dessert dish in Sweden, especially if you're on a forest hike and start a fire. Then you wrap it in aluminium foil and put it in the embers for the banana to cook and the chocolate to melt. We call it "Scout Banana".

The probability of the cavendish banana going extinct like the Gros michel is exactly why monoculture is bad. Almost every country has a seed gene bank where a store of all native seeds of a country (and any seed that works for a country's specific climates) are stored and yet, especially in America, we don't rely on the diverse seeds or many types of crops. Instead, our foods all look the same across the nation, and occasionally, world-- foods such as carrots, oranges, potatoes, corn, tomatoes, apples, etc. There's less and less diversity and if a disease comes along, it can easily wipe out a monocultured plant (like the gros michel banana) on a global scale before we can figure out a treatment. And the problem with that, apart from loss of land/soil, and jobs, is by that point, a country may have become so dependant on that monocultured food as a resource that there's is no proper replacement and it will affect food accessibility. Plantains and bananas are absolutely necessary to some communities because they are cheap and nutritious. If the plant was wiped out, people might struggle to find a replacement in their diet for the same price and nutritional range. So this problem would disproportionately affect low income classes both in taking away their work and their food. Sustainability is such an important topic and as much as I do love to watch you debunk hacks, I'm glad you found time to talk about it in your video.

GMOs are just a tool, neither good nor bad. golden rice is a very good use of the technology that helps millions of people get enough to eat. monsanto patenting their corn genes so they can dump pesticides on them to increase profit? not so much. the technology has wondrous potential for the world if we use it properly. fungi that break down plastics, trees that suck up heavy metals, algae that cleans oil spills, food that's more hardy and more nutritious, and making things resistant to blights. the problem is not with the tool but with who wields it. cavendish bananas have been bred for smaller and smaller seeds and have no genetic diversity since they're all clone plants now so they are very vulnerable. we have the tools to fix that and we should (and maybe make some more kinds of bananas while we're at it so we don't need to).

Being scared of GMOs is people being scared of what they don't understand. You're eating GMOs all the time. Bananas are GM'd. Apples are GM'd. Watermelons are GM'd. Hell, if you have a pet your PET has been genetically modified. Genetically altering foods isn't new, it's why we have wheat and rice! Giving a plant a gene to make it resistant to, say, flooding, is why rice farmers can still farm rice! The only thing I would be wary of is genetic modifications in unborn children in order to change their physical appearances. If there was a way to make humans immune to certain diseases, or for example to destroy whatever gene causes altzheimers in kids if it's prominent in their family, then yeah I'm all for it. But it should never be used for frivolous aesthetic reasons. In conclusion: GMOs are not even close to being bad.

I was once assigned a college business paper on GMO crops and if it's ethical or not. Based on the research I did, there was a lot more concern about "what ifs" whereas the actual evidence of GMO food being bad for us is very little. Here in the US, I'd say companies offering tools to modify foods are more unethical than the crops themselves. Overall, if there isn't any evidence of GMO foods being dangerous or unhealthy, then I believe it's fine.

The banana in the microwave is a take on a super common campfire recipe here in the US called a banana boat! They‚Äôre generally sliced down the middle but not through the peel in the bottom and stuffed with chocolate, marshmallows and candy. The whole thing is then wrapped in foil and put in the campfire ash for like 10 minutes. Then you use a spoon and scoop out the mix! I used to make it all the time in Girl Scouts. I still make it today for a dessert but usually i make it in the toaster oven not the microwave.

I always assumed hanging bananas was done to avoid bruising, though my parents might have been just saving some precious space in the pantry. As for GMOs, I think it's important not to lump all of them into one category of either good or bag. Surely, there's a difference between growing GMO crops just because it's convenient without any care for the environment ("crop is resistant to roundup" really doesn't count as a good reason in my opinion), and making sure a mass grown monocrop that is both important source of relatively cheap nutrition for a lot of people and single-handedly keeping some economies running doesn't actually go extinct (which includes making it impossible to commercially grown them).

The banana is already manipulated because every banana is a clone. So what's the difference between that and gene modification? It's the same with dogs. Selective breeding is just a less sophisticated method of genetic engineering. All that matters is that the correct protections are put in place to ensure safety.
i think the issue that many people(me included) have with GMOs is the legal ramifications. large corporations can create a GMO crop, plant it in a field next to a small farmer, and, then sue the small farmer for patent infringement if the GMO plant ends up pollinating or effecting the small farmer's crop. the large corporations can also get basically a monopoly on a whole food group if they control the food itself. the issue is regarding societal and legal ramifications, not quality. GMO foods are not generally lower quality than organic.  i'm not sure if the resistant banana will be patented or not, but if it is just imagine how much worse it will make the situation. instead of losing the ability to make their main crop, and being able to move on to try to grow a different crop or diversify their economy to not rely so heavily on one crop, they would be basically forced to buy from the patent holder, who would have a monopoly. banana republics are called that for a reason, and i don't think adding on top of that would be helpful.

The Cavendish banana is already GMO. When the bananas were wiped out by panama disease in the 50s the Cavendish strain was cultivated due to its resistance to the fungus. Every single cavendish banana is a clone of this strain. Every single banana is the EXACT same banana, that's why scientists when they're feeling cheeky can measure radiation levels in bananas.  What makes panama disease so much more devastating this time around is because the fungus adapted to the cavendish strain, and there ARE no other strains left (Not counting the wild ones obviously). All of the bananas are the same so the fungus is tearing through them at a much more devastating rate than they did in the 50s. While the work being done by the Australians is admirable, it is nothing more than a stop gap, as its already been shown that the fungus can adapt, and so most likely will adapt to the new resistant cavendish at some point.

The banana stuffed with chocolate is a common Girl Scouts recipe where I live, in northeast USA. You put mini marshmallows, chocolate chips, bits of graham crackers, etc in the banana. Then you wrap it in foil and place it in a campfire until it gets all gooey and melted inside. It makes for an easy campfire dessert. Bananas are extremely vulnerable to blight and disease since they're cultivated to be seedless. Only a small number are grown with seeds to create an offspring plant, while the majority are clones grown from parts of existing banana plants. This means that they have very little genetic variation and they evolve and adapt very slowly.  The anti-GMO movement usually hurts people in developing countries. If we can grow more food, with better nutrients, and better disease resistance, then we can feed millions of people. Most arguments against GMO crops are based on ignorance and fearmongering anyway. Bananas are such an important and vulnerable crop that we need to take measures to protect them.

The most important thing about sunscreen is that you need to reapply it regularly, especially if you're sweating or getting wet. I've gone on long bicycle rides over a weekend, and I can get pretty badly sunburned if I don't protect myself. GMOs are problematic when they‚Äôre being used to keep people dependent on industry‚Äîsuch as crops being modified not to bear seed for replanting. When they‚Äôre being used to address a problem like crop blight and empower people long-term, they‚Äôre very helpful. It‚Äôs science, not witchcraft and, as always, only problematic when we apply it in harmful ways. Most of the produce we enjoy today has been genetically modified via breeding selection. If you don‚Äôt like the idea of fungus-resistant bananas, you should likewise refuse all produce or seed commercially available today and start sourcing teosinte, wild carrots and crabapples to grow at home.

Most foods are GMO. The original banana, carrot, etc. isn‚Äôt really edible.  Most fruits and veggies have been modified to a certain degree to either grow bigger, or made a colour that‚Äôs more appealing, or more nutritious etc. and these genetically modified foods are 100% fine for consumption.  BUT: there are certain GMO foods like corn and others, that has been modified to grown quicker to feed the masses, these GMO foods may have (but they‚Äôre is no definite proof) caused some populations to have Heath issues. I've got no issue with GMOs. Its not some scientist creating a synthetic Frankenstein zombie from plastic, uranium and banana skin, its taking genes from one and putting it into another to get the best of both worlds. We aren't breaking ethical boundaries doing it on humans, and the plants don't suffer, in fact they end up flourishing. Pretty much every food we eat has been genetically altered for our benefit. Whereas we used to rely on selective breeding, now we can expedite the process and cut out a lot of waiting for successive generations. Many foods are already GMOs and they have been lifesavers in developing countries.

If time were not of the essence I would guess the resistance from the wild banana could be bred into the Cavendish naturally. This kind of breeding for desirable traits is done commonly with everything from flowers and shrubs to fruits and vegetables (Did you know carrots are not naturally orange? Most people know that the¬†¬†is a root vegetable that is usually orange in most grocery stores. What some people might not know is that¬†¬†can be other¬†, as well. They can be white, yellow, red, magenta, and purple.¬†The origins of the cultivated carrot is rooted in the¬†¬†carrot in the region around modern-day Afghanistan.)¬† ¬† ¬† ¬†So my resistance to a Frankenbanana would depend. Has the geneticist checked to find what other changes this tampering with genes might have done?¬† If resistance were the only trait affected that would be one thing.If the genes were changed to produce fungicide for this resistance then that would be very upsetting.¬† GMO corn is already on the loose. Corn was modified to make insecticide within their genes.It turned out the bugs got sick from eating the corn--So did people. Yeah, people aren't meant to eat insecticide, Who would have thought.¬† ¬† And the "containment" of the experiment was basically distance miles away from other corn. Unfortunately, Bees and other pollinators can fly for miles so the nasty GMO genes were bred into the natural corn. On GMO: it is just a modernization of techniques used in hundreds of years: look at apples, carrots and potatoes. By cross breeding and selection, we get the efficient and nutricioys foods we have today. So on the health front, they are basically the same. Hello Ann, I absolutely love your channel and its contents.I hope you can forgive any gramatical mistakes made in this comment. That being said,  I'm actually from Panama and  I absolutely love that you talked about the Panama Disease because funny enough ,even though it has our name it  does not originate from our country. Here, we have three provinces ( there are 10 in total) whose  economic stability used to depend and for some it still actually depends on the cultivation of the fruit. Its role on our history is such that back in the 1921 in the Coto War with Costa Rica the US (who back then owned the banana plantations in both of the border provinces with said country) purposely, for their sole benefit,  made us renounce area being disputed even though we had actually won the war. The third province I mentioned is actually one of several indigenous territories in the country and the bananas make up a good portion of their daily caloric intake. You can pretty much find a banana plant anywhere in the country if you look hard enough. Banana cultivations in just one province usually generate about 7 thousand jobs for people and therefore it is also the main income for thousands of families that live in remote areas where other jobs are nonexistent. The fruit itself is actually one of our main export products so you can imagine what a complete wipeout would do to our economy.   Its starting to get long so I`ll wrap it up. I believe I once saw a documentary that said that bananas as we know them are doomed. I can try to find the link but its been quite a while since I saw it. The problem is that they are simply not a stable produce that we can maintain, and when the Panama Disease appears its almost unstoppable and can end with about 60%  plantation it a matter of years because even if you cut the tree and burn it  its already been weeks or months since its been sick and therefore it just a waiting game until the next plant starts showing signs. However, burning them does slow down the plant death rate and infection for obvious reasons. Also its quite difficult to differentiate from another sickness with causes the same wilting in the leaves that is one of the main visible symptoms. Another problem is that we as human beings have gotten so used to our cavendish bananas that changing to a resistant variety is simply not an economically viable option because most either don't look or taste the same and therefore the demand will not be the same.¬†  In behalf of our country I would like to thank every single scientist that is trying to find a solution because it¬¥s a silent killer that could end with bananas as we know them. I hope we can save them so that the world can keep on having as many delicious bananas as they want.   Love, M.   pd:Sorry for the long post.

For me personally, I don't care if they modify the banana as long as it is safe and helping the banana survive.
With genetic engineering, I think it's a great tool, but just like any tool it can be used for good or bad. We don't call chefs knives bad just because they could be used to stab someone, so why call genetic engineering bad just because you could do something bad with it? I think the technique is fine, and our focus should be on what uses we allow, and improved safety testing for food in general.  There's a lot of disinformation and misinformation about about genetic engineering out there, but also about conventional farming.  Many people have the idea that conventional farming is very 'natural' (itself more of a buzzword than anything meaningful), when in reality us taking things from the wild and breeding them into things we like isn't all that natural.  But to go even further, conventional agriculture (including organic) also uses mutagenic breeding techniques, in which a plant is exposed to mutation-causing chemicals or radiation, hope for the best, see if there's any new mutations which have preferable characteristics, and then breed those into the supply.  Again, that's not genetic engineering or GMO, that's accepted as part of conventional farming.  It's how we get things like seedless fruits and ruby red grapefruits (which absolutely exist with organic labels as well).  This technique is safe, but surely it should sound more scary that we're just blasting our fruits and veggies with mutation causing radiation and chemicals, and then just hope for the best, compared to genetic engineering in which a specific part of genetic DNA is taken from one organism and put inside of another so that it takes on the desired characteristics (usually that's at least within the same kingdom, so from one plant to another; although sometimes DNA from various kingdoms is also inserted into micro-organisms to have them rapidly produce certain organic compounds which can be used for various purposes including natural food additives and medicine; there is also a distinction between heterogenesis and homogenesis; with homogenesis, DNA from a similar plant is being transferred, which would for example be the case in the banana example, whereas heterogenesis concerns transferring DNA from a non-related species)  The problems with genetic engineering aren't with the technique itself, and anyone who tries to make you think otherwise is either misinformed or trying to mislead you. There are however problems with the way it might be used, but they're related to how the technique is used, and business practices of the companies that produce them, but tackling those problems isn't a matter of outlawing genetic engineering, it's about making clear laws on what it may be used for, clear laws on the business practices involved with it, clear laws on testing and validation requirements.   My university has a good overview which could serve as a good starting place if you want to know more https://www.wur.nl/en/Dossiers/file/Genetic-modification-1.htm (For those wondering: I myself am a student in BSc Food Technology; genetic engineering is outside of my scope, as we focus more on everything between the harvested crop to the products you eat, trough various disciplines such as chemistry, physics, microbiology, process engineering, and quality design; genetic engineering is however a personal topic of interest for me, which is why I've read up about it more than I need to)

I have no problem with GMO foods. We humans have been genetically modifying our food for millennia. The only thing that has changed is the methods. The modern genetic modification techniques  are done in laboratories and are MUCH more precise and therefore MUCH faster. How could anyone think that is a bad thing?
While there are certainly some legitimate concerns regarding genetically engineered foods (government regulation, corporate copyright abuse, creating monocultures, etc), when people discuss GMOs it's never about those things, it's always just "it's so unnatural," which is scientifically speaking a non-argument. By that logic, we should all still live in caves as hunter-gatherers. Saving a staple crop, however, is the sort of thing food engineering should definitely be used for. It's not changing the genetic make-up of a wild population and since cavendish bananas are already a monoculture there's no need to be concerned about a lack of genetic diversity. The new gene is from another banana type (species? cultivar?), so it's not what I think of when I hear "frankenfood." I'd much rather eat a practically identical engineered version of a thoroughly domesticated crop than eat the "non-gmo" version except it's been laced with fungicides which may harm me or, more likely, the banana farmers. The argument is kind of moot, however. The banana industry won't let the cavendish die out, and the fruit is too cheap and popular for the majority of consumers to completely boycott a perfectly safe food because it has science in it. I hope when these fusarium resistant bananas become mainstream, it will open up real discussions about how to regulate genetic engineering, rather than more useless fear-mongering.

I am not specifically anti gmo, my main concern with gmo is biodiversity. When all of our crops are from the same few gmo stocks, we lose the diversity that keeps our systems working. Gmos are not inherently bad, but our use of them poses many risks that need to be addressed.

ok there are a lot of banana hacks lol. anyway thank you for seriously showing us what happens and debunking videos online. you are amazing and doing wonderful work. great feedback and honesty too, its refreshing. i love your channel and cant wait for next video
The main question with GMO is who owns the IP? Monsanto and the like really screw farmers over in both the affluent and more impoverished countries. Not only do you have to re-buy seed every year, but Monsanto are very law-suit happy, suing for all sorts of nonsense, some of it just ridiculous (eg your crops get pollinated by a neighbouring GMO field = stealing their IP), some of it provably false, but they drown the farmers in legal fees until they give in.   Even if the variant is created by a university, and that university manages to do that work without outside investment getting involved, and make the patent open to everyone... where do the seeds come from? Who is producing them and what do they decide to charge? How are new plants propagated? From cuttings? From seeds that are gene-edited individually each time? From stock gene-edited stem cells? Do the resulting plants produce seed? Do they breed true?  I *think* with bananas they are mostly clones anyway (hence their susceptibility to disease) so possibly the question of propagation wouldn't be an issue. But you have to think about who sells them and under what conditions. Also whether they need special treatment eg the application of specific pesticides/fertilisers etc possibly sold by that same supplier.   If its a single gene edit, that's probably not going to affect the taste, plant behaviour, allergenic proteins etc. But it might not be that specific. Does the banana we are taking the gene *from* have any negative properties we don't want?  It's a complex bio-socio-political issue.
People who are against GMO don't really understand what it is in my experience. I'm certainly against corporations patenting seeds, but that is not the same conversation.

I oppose rapacious engineering of GMO seed crops designed so that farmers can't use some of their product to reseed their fields, but must pay the GMO seed producers for more seed because the seeds are designed to be sterile. I can see why people are so skeptical about GMO foods (like with the tomato that has genetic info from a fish ü§¢) but so much has been done with using genetic information to fix problems. For example, one type of the COVID-19 vaccines (vector vaccines) uses genetic information from the virus that causes COVID-19 and inserts it into another weaker virus. This weaker virus is inserted into the body and "tricks" the body to believing it has the real virus that causes COVID-19 and so the body learns how to defend itself. If genetically modifying organisms can save a whole industry and people, I'm all for it!!

I think alot of the hubbub that surrounds GMO is the notion that it's somehow unhealthy for you. This is frequently untrue. Genetic modification exists in many more things than we realize and isn't unhealthy at all. It's simply a way to make the vegetables and fruits we consume either better for us, more readily available, bigger in size or taste better. I think alot of people hear GMO and think that it's done with chemicals and hormones and then think that because we're ingesting them that they're the cause of many health problems that we experience. When the reality is that GMO is just taking one gene from one plant and splicing it with the genes from another plant to create a better plant. Just like you said in the video, genetic modification has helped save the banana from extinction several times and continues to do so. :)

The reason "wild bananas" have so many large seeds but farm bananas don't is because pre-Columbian Americans bred them over thousands of years to be as useful as possible. The same can be said for tomatoes and corn and so many other American plants, many of which died out when the US government began pushing people off their ancestral land. Either they couldn't take their plants with them, or the plants couldn't survive in the new climate. This trend of farming one kind of a plant for the entire global supply is relatively new, and it's very dangerous. Not only did it wipe out one kind of bananas in the 50s, but it was the cause of the Irish potato famine as well. And just like the current kind of bananas is at risk because every farm has the same kind of banana plant, nearly every plant we grow is a monoculture. Indigenous people spent thousands of years cultivating so many different kinds of wonderful plants, and we threw that away in favor of a farming model most easily exploitable by capitalism.
Banana peels contain fluorescent chlorophyll catabolites, which are fairly good photosensitizers and, when exposed to sunlight, may actually actively cause oxidative damage to your skin and make your sunburn worse.  This "hack" is so irresponsible!
i am a huge fan <3  u explain stuff so well, i wish u vr my teacher!! u shuld satrt teaching, students will love you <3
The chocolate-banana-microwave "hack" looks based off of a campfire/scouting recipe called a banana boat. It's pretty common in girl scouts in America. Basically, you cut an opening in the banana, stuff it full of chocolate, marshmallows, peanut butter, etc, wrap it in tin foil, and put it near warm coals for a few minutes. If it's done right, everything gets melty and delicious, but it's really easy to burn it (cause fire and also the nature of sugar). Can't imagine it tastes good in a microwave tho, that's like microwaving a smores and calling it a day
ann in every debunk video: "I would not recommend anyone to eat that also ann: Let's give it to dave
I really think people have gotten the wrong idea about what GMO actually is and means. There are no crops that are grown and sold in stores that aren't genemodified through either the help of lab techniques or just breeding the plants over decades. Both of whom are a form of GMO. Imagine the amount of landmass we'd have to cover with crops in order to sustain all the people on this planet if we DIDN'T have GMO crops... we'd really be out of rainforests by now if we did. GMO crops are for the benefit of making more without taking up more of our already limited space. also Gene modification doesn't end with just food, take a long hard look at your pet. This also applies to cows, pigs, chickens, and sheep, all of whom have been modified to produce as much meat and other products as possible through breeding over centuries.
As a biologist doing research on the topic of UV-light and skin cancer I highly appreciate your debunking of the banana sunscreen myth. Going in the sun unprotected is dangerous. But even more dangerous is putting stuff on your skin that can make it even more sensitive to the sunlight. Commercially available sunscreens have decades of research with thousands of scientists behind them and still ongoing studies to improve formulations, all in the name of protecting the consumers. So before you burn a hole in your skin by using untested all-natural remedies, trust the scientists a bit.

Love the videos, but for the sake of science I have to call you out.  The temptation of slipping into pseudo science from science is always there, we all slide down it at some point and need to be called out when we do.  I know I expect to be should I ever stumble.  Using a logical deduction to justify a slip up in an experimental method is a violation.  Additionally, the logic you used was faulty.  Ripening is a chain reaction that results in more and more ripening compounds being released throughout the entire the process, with the most being present at the end, not the beginning, but don't take my word for it, ask a fruit fly.  Funny enough, you actually disproved your own logic in your video by showing the banana sealed off from the rest was the only one that didn't rapidly ripen.  You'll need to do them all again in isolation to see what is really going on, but since you already showed the bag didn't ripen as fast, you can do them all in one view again, just put them all in their own bags.  I look forward to the follow up ;)
I think the fear of GMOs is just pure and simple misinformation.  It's easy to be against them when you're well off in a wealthy country and can easily afford the extra cost of non GMO food, but for a lot of the world GMOs are the solution to food shortages and poor access to nutritious food.  There's no evidence that GMOs are worse for you, and it helps make food more available for a lot of people.

I love GMOs. I wasn't aware it was an ethical issue until I took an agriculture class at the university. GMOs are helping feed people and grow plants in areas where food couldn't normally grow. Like the scientist in the video did, we can BREED plants to be bigger, better, and more resistant to diseases, instead of ingesting chemicals that are sprayed onto the crops and can flow into water sources. He crossed a breed of plant that is naturally resistant to the fungus with our bananas to achieve the fungus resistant bananas without spending the time, money, or hazard of spraying fungicide on each crop.

I think GMOs are fine, but the thing that is not fine are the monocultural crops. We're just going to run into wide-spread disease and food shortage if we keep the industrial model and only grow the same few plants everywhere in vast, genetically identical fields. If we can figure out ways to grow different kinds of food all mixed together, the genetic diversity will protect them from diseases. The trouble is just making it efficient enough to work out.

I believe all sub tropical and tropical countries have many kinds of edible banana. I think the main problem is the global banana business. Now, don't quote me on that, but as far as I am aware, what that scientist guy did was not GMO-ing but more like selecting or breeding genes. GMO is more like let me take this fish gene and put it into an orange to get oranges that don't bruise. One definition that I remember hearing about GMO was "mixing genes that wouldn't naturally mix" or something like that, I hope you get what I'm saying. While the scientist mixed bananas with bananas - something that technically could happen.
I am a PHD in banana preservation and I declare that the only place where the bananas stay fresh for longer is your stomach.
I think the GMO terror is a bunch of bunk. People latched onto one or two GMO items that ended horribly - thank you to Monsanto for making a corn that makes its own pesticide, I think it was? and can make people very ill - and decided All GMO Bad because that's how hippie dippy internet raw water oil pulling stick a crystal in your vagina culture works. Like anything else made by SCIENCE, individual creations need to be researched individually (and for a lot longer than Monsanto bothered with because $$$). The cavendish banana is a GMO food item - just, it was GM by breeding rather than direct gene transplant. Most of the produce we eat today is absolutely nothing like the wild versions in taste, texture, shelf life or looks; they've all been modified over several generations by breeding specific individual plants with desirable traits together until the genetics have changed enough that the undesirable traits have been stripped from the sequence. GM is just doing that faster. Because gene research is still in early stages, it's harder to know what the further effects of direct genetic transplant are because of a variety of factors including epigenetics (e.g. environmental factors like temperature affecting genetic development (such as sex characteristics in some fish)). GM requires longer post-modification research to see what happens after several generations of breeding the modified organisms together to make sure there aren't unhealthy consequences from gene interactions we don't yet understand, as compared to bred organisms which are generally observed during the breeding process and bred out over time. GM is faster, and shady companies have tried to push their products past the research stage to save further cash on top of it. The truth is that GMO is STILL faster than natural breeding _even factoring in time for post-modification research_ - but because companies like Monsanto screwed up early, public conception is biased against GMOs. There is a lot of potential in the GMO field to do many things from eliminating world hunger to curing cancer... it's just going to be a lot of work convincing the general public that well-researched GMOs can be trusted. (Maybe once there's a cancer cure people will shut the hell up.)

I have never met an educated person who understands the actual science of genetics at all who has an irrational fear of GMOs. Please for the love of God just read a science textbook on genetics and explain to me the point at the DNA transcription level where modern genetic modification techniques are so vastly different from selective breeding, that has been done for thousands of years, that we need to be worried about the safety of the food. Not to mention the fact that all GMOs are tested for safety and certified by the FDA and equivalent agencies internationally before ever being sold to the public. The same cannot be said for dietary supplements! They are not certified for safety by the FDA! If you take a dietary supplement you very well could be just taking ground up lawn clippings packed into a pill, there is literally no testing to ensure you aren't. Since I‚Äôm not a scientist I can only really talk about how I feel when I hear ‚ÄúGMO‚Äù. I am, however, a gardener and know a little bit about heirloom vs hybrid. So from my (very limited) understanding it seems like genetically modified foods come in vast spectrum. While on one hand we could call most modern corn gmo nobody seems to be upset by it and will eat them without fear. On the other hand people are afraid of modern wheat and claim that it isn‚Äôt the same as ancient wheat which is why more people are having digestive issues with it. I am not uncomfortable with the idea of cross pollinating something over and over until you‚Äôve basically ‚Äúbred‚Äù something with traits you like, but I think it seems less sustainable, and possibly bad for our health (maybe?) to create genetically modified plants in labs and then grow them to eat. I FEEL uncomfortable with the idea even though I don‚Äôt understand how it works enough to really have an informed opinion. In my readings over the last few years on the idea of permaculture I have discovered that one of the main contributors to crises like the one the cavendish banana is facing right now is that it‚Äôs grown in a monoculture so a disease spreads easily. When more diverse ecosystems are grown over the same amount of space they tend to be more resilient. Interesting topic to be sure :)

According to a study in the Journal of Applied Biochemistry and Biotechnology, the banana peel contains magnesium, calcium, vitamin A, B6 and B12, which help strengthen your bones, your immune system and boost your mood - all without adding extra calories.  How to use the banana peel However, you do not need to eat banana with peel on to get hold of the good healthy things, because the banana peel is not just like digesting for human stomachs.  If you want to get the most out of the banana peel, you can instead blend it and use it in smoothies, for example, but remember to go for the organic bananas, so you do not get pesticides in the smoothie.
You forgot to mention that bananas also go through chill damage. The process of cooking them to refrigeration temperature causes the cells to breakdown rapidly if there's even a slight increase in temperature. So if you keep them in the fridge, it's better not to take them out and let them warm up before eating.

I don't really care about GMO foods, because humans have been genetically modifying food since forever via selective breeding. That makes all food genetically modified. I'm more concerned about the overuse of pesticides, personally.
The thing with the banana and chocolate in the microwave, that reminds me of how we do it in Sweden. On campsites and such, it's common to put a banana in aluminium foil, put some chocolate in the banana and then pack it up and put it...close to the campfire, I suppose, and not directly into it. Can't remember if one peels the banana or not. Can be quite tasty if you do it right. - one can also do it in so many different ways.
In this instance with the banana plant disease is why GMO development should exist. If you're against these specific and devastating instances of resorting to GMOs to save their livelihood and prevent malnourishment then maybe you could choose to not eat it and starve? I'm all for regulation or discussion of what would constitute an appropriate use of GMO, but all I'm saying is... what would be the alternative if you were placed in those corners of the world? You would starve. Some places don't have the luxury to refuse food and some even a choice of food varieties. It's an area within food purists that really has become a pet peeve to hear because a lot is coming from a privileged perspective.
The sad music over the time lapse of the plants rotting really drove the point home. I'm actually quite interested in cooking banana peel for consumption, though. It was surprising to see the banana peel sandwich work out nicely, and it's so heartwarming to see Dave get some good food out of one of these experiments. As usual, lovely work!  On the GMO conversation, I agree with you 100%. I've had a lot of friends who are anti-GMO and I was too myself for a time. The thing about GMOs is that they can produce plants that grow in areas where they usually can't, offering greater food diversity to people who may have only had a few simple crops that provided insufficient nutrition. Likewise, as in the case of the banana, GMO technology can save communities where people depend on a single crop for the majority of their income and local food supply. My views turned around when I realized that for someone like me who lives in the middle of a food-rich area it's easy to be unaware of the struggles faced by people who live in food deserts (no local access to sufficient food sources) or who depend on one staple crop for the majority of their food source. For me the choice is between GMO, imported, locally grown, organic, bio-dynamic, hydroponic, communal garden, etc. For people in the later two situations the choice is often between GMO and nothing at all. It's so easy to demand everyone go organic when you have a stable, comfortable income and live in the middle of farm country. For those who have few choices (due to poverty or local food scarcity) the choice is to eat the high-yield, hearty GMO crops or watch your family starve.

Banana peels and vegans‚Äîthere‚Äôs a reason for this. lol  One of the main concerns about a vegan diet is a lack of Vitamin B-12. A few years ago, the claim that banana peels are high in Vitamin B-12 started circulating, even being written about by some credible sources. The problem is, all those sources link back to just one person, a nutritionist named Laura Flores, and nobody (last I saw) could figure out where she got this information. The vegans I know, as well as the ones I watch on YouTube, do not eat banana peels. However, new vegans who are just starting to read about nutrition can stumble upon all those articles and think they need to eat them. It‚Äôs unfortunate and potentially dangerous if they think, based on those articles, that they are getting their B-12 needs met, when they should be taking a supplement or eating B-12 enriched foods.

We've been genetically modifying food for hundreds of years, it's just now we can do it in labs as well as in greenhouses. I think I read somewhere that the reason we have the Cavendish banana that we do is because we bred it to reduce the seeds in it until it's basically infertile. I have nothing to back that up though, so could be incorrect.  People hear 'GMO' and get scared that it's scientists tampering with our food and that it's going to be introducing something harmful or foreign, when most of the time it's about selecting for different seeds amounts, or certain shapes and colours, or making food grow more easily or making it more resistant to disease. We're going to NEED GMOs to continue surviving and adapting to the world we're creating for ourselves, as I'm sure a lot of varieties of food will need to be adapted to grow in different climates due to climate change. The bigger issue is the companies, like Monsanto, who put resistant plants or nutrient rich ones beyond paywalls and will do anything to protect their profit margin. Hate the company, not the gmo

Poor poor Dave (hope I spelled it right)
Like Alex Shafer said earlier on in the comments, GMOs have been part of the process of making our food more edible since humans started cultivating food; there's nothing inherently wrong with modifying our food.  Like others mentioned though, it‚Äôs the issue of companies patenting and controlling seed production that is really dangerous aspect of our food industry.  This issue with the banana disease is actually a great example of what can go wrong when a small number of companies control the business of developing and selling our crops. Businesses are logically focused on cultivating what will make the most money. They only develop the number of varieties that they think are necessary for issues like weather variations and known diseases, and then, they try to sell them to everyone on the planet. Which means an entire industry (and culture) can end up leaning on one variation of crop to support them. Sooo, when something like Panama disease or (similarly the Irish Potato Famine) occurs the entire species is devastated because of one new fungus.    Supporting wild and heirloom should not be about the fear that a GMO food will hurt you. It's not really about avoiding GMOS as much as it‚Äôs about encouraging more genetic diversity; just as our banana scientist did when he created a new variation of the dominate banana species with the help of its wild (and terrifying) friend. o.0;;;
Honestly for the sake of saving plants and making them have nutritional value, GMOs are fine by me. Nature changes the genes of plants all the time but that's based on what survives and what dies. We're just speeding up the process and preventing, as much as we can, the extinction of plants. On a side note, I find patenting certain genes pretty dumb considering a bean or what have you can "infect" another, spreading more of that gene unknowingly. It's the one thing I dislike as, well, no one owns genes, or in other words, Mother Nature lmao.

The bananas stuffed with chocolate and put in the microwave is not too far off from a summer camp treat I grew up with that we called "banana boats." We would open up the banana and sprinkle chocolate chips and mini marshmallows in it, then wrap it up in tin foil and roast it over the campfire for a minute or two. I was never a big fan because I'm also not big on the texture of mushy bananas but most people LOVED them, and that summer camp still does it every year. So I don't think that one's too far off, but it definitely loses it's charm when you stick it in the microwave instead of over a campfire.

My position on GMOs is that I don't care if things have been modified to make them more tasty or disease resistant, that's just speeding up natural processes. What I find concerning is when large companies modify and patent seeds, allowing them to sue farmers for patent infringement.
I have no issue with GMO, I have an issue with everything being tagged as ‚ÄúOrganic‚Äù and charging double and triple for it.  Technically, all grown food is organic, so it‚Äôs just a scam for the gullible.
GMO within the species (like Banana + Banana = better banana) is good imo, but when u start crossing species I'd be concerned about allergens. For example, I've recently found out that I'm allergic to Nightshades, and now can't eat anything with GMO soy because it could've been crossed with the DNA of a petunia (why tho lmao, like, what did that improve??)  If GMOs get more mainstream, I hope we can KNOW what DNA things have been crossed with, and that it becomes required to list if an ingredient is GMO on the box (not just "you can say it's GMO free if _ _ _", but the other way around)  Other than allergen concerns, I see no problems with GMO
about GMOs... i am a molecular biology and genetics student and i defend GMOs to a degree. As stated in the video, the wild banana has large hard seeds and not much flesh, which is understandable because the main purpose of a fruit is to protect the seeds until they find their way into the soil as well as providing the first "compost" boost for the seed growth. As far as i know, the bananas we eat today are genetically modified to have tiny seeds or no seeds at all and maximum flesh. Also, genetic modification of crops allow the crops to survive diseases and/or pests, all while NOT being significantly harmful for consumption. If GMOs didn't exist, we wouldn't have this much variety in grocery stores.
Wow, a species of fruit scientifically designed to have no seeds, only grown by cloning, and therefore unable to adapt to a disease is dying? What a shock.  Sure would be bad if that completely artificial species was replaced by a GM one lol...

Anyone who screams and clutches their pearls about "Genetically Modified" bananas; wild bananas look like the example you showed, with large, hard seeds. Over generations, bananas have been cross-bred and genetically modified by ancient farmers to get the modern, seedless banana.  The same thing has happened with wheat, maize (corn), apples, cabbages, broccoli, cauliflower, potatoes and citrus fruit, not to mention with generations of domesticated animals. The only difference is now we can actually tell which genes were modified and what the effects of that modification is.  In earlier generations they were just shooting in the dark using trial and error.
Yay GMO! (I haven't seen a single claim against GMO that isn't either false or valid also for "conventional" agriculture.)

I have noticed that the temperature in my house really affects how fast my bananas ripen. I keep my house pretty cool most of the time, and I find that makes bananas last a lot longer than they do when the temperature is higher. As for GMOs, I think there are different ways to genetically modify organisms, and that matters a lot.  Farmers have been taking plants and modifying them with other plants, probably for as long as there's been farming. I think that's fine. However, then there's big companies that are chemically modifying plants, and adding pesticides right into the plants, and I think sometimes that's really dangerous and damaging. Like the type of seeds a company made with an insecticide in them, that ended up killing any bee's that pollinated those plants. Then it got into the soil, so it affected any plants planted after the original plant, that were planted  in the same soil, and because of the water run off, it  started affecting any plants surrounding the modified plant, and so those plants would also kill bee's. I think those types of GMOs are damaging.

I have a PhD in the biological and biomedical field. While my field of study is not agronomy, I understand molecular biology so I think I can give a somewhat informed opinion on the GMOs topic. I think there‚Äôs a lot of misinformation about this subject. Many people think that they are unhealthy, but the modified vegetal shouldn‚Äôt be unhealthy per se. However, one problem could be if those crops are combined with pesticides that are bad for our health and/or the environment. I think the introduction of GMO crops needs to be analyzed case by case because they could have potential environmental and cultural consequences, but there‚Äôs no need to see GMOs as bad as a whole. Also, all the vegetables that we consume today hace been genetically modified through selection, just the method was different.

Study after study after study has shown that they are safe. Add to that the potential for solving *some* of the food scarcity issues around the world - I just don't understand why it's still so widely debated.

The beginning of these videos: Haha let's laugh at the ridiculousness of some of these ideas! Kids, don't try this at home, you could get hurt! The ending of these videos: This is what's happening in the world and we should all be aware of it.    Personally, I think some GMOs get a bad reputation. My uncle blamed GMOs for everything from cancer to autism (but he was not a very informed man and had a tendency to take conspiracy theories as truth). Maybe I just don't know enough, but I'm of the opinion that making plants more resistant to diseases, pests and other factors - *so long as it isn't causing serious harm to the consumer or environment* - then it isn't a terrible thing. Of course, I would rather if we didn't try to play god if we could avoid it since it's better to know the long-term effects before putting it out into a population (that and why fix what isn't broken?), but this scenario seems like one where intervention is necessary. Bananas have a very bloody history, but the simple fact of the matter is that so many people, including good family businesses, rely heavily on bananas to survive. That, and if it really is making up 25% of a person's diet, then losing it doesn't seem to be an option. Could we eventually adapt? Of course, but putting millions of lives on the line in the interim isn't an option in my opinion.

You asked for opinions so here's mine based on logic: Growing one crop in mass quantities continually in the same area is what causes strains of these diseases to evolve and then attack the entire crop. Better to rotate crops and create a more self sustaining system by also varying the type of plant grown beside each other. Instead of acre after acre of the exact same thing, which is also the equivalent of putting all eggs in one basket. Genetically modifying the plant merely perpetuates the problem and creates stronger and more deadly diseases due to the fact that bacteria, viruses and fungi can quickly evolve since they can reproduce so quickly. Whether the disease is to plants, animals or humans will remain to be seen in each case - consider studies done on the effects of feeding GMO corn to livestock - if you can still find the independent peer-reviewed research. Thank you for the informative video!
Omg you actually chose Greece, I‚Äôm Greek !!
Literally every single modern day food is Genetically modified in some way. Usually to make the plants taste better, like Broccoli for example. Watermelon was modified, bananas are already modified so they don't produce the typical large seeds found in wild bananas, not to mention all of the "seedless" fruit varieties, etc. Quite often, like the case with these bananas, it's necessary to keep crops around. It literally saved the life of these plants that could have otherwise been wiped out by disease. But like with seedless fruit, it can be bad for the crops as they can become nore prone to disease, like with our modern "seedless" bananas that we're all used to. Genetically modifying food is not always a bad thing, as I said there isn't a single food that we eat (at least in the US, can't say for everywhere else, of course) that hasn't been modified in some way. And I have to say, people have a lot of nerve, being against genetically modified food when they have no issue eating frozen/microwaveable food or fast food. The exception would probably be wild caught fish/seafood and animals that were hunted for food. But

Unless the research on GMO has changed substantially in the last few years, my only "safety" concern was from the ecological and predatory-capitalist angles rather than the human-health angle. There's nothing inherent to the GMO process that would impact a human or other random animal eating the resulting produce. It's swapping one banana gene for another banana gene, making a new banana.  It's like a really fast version of normal selective breeding.

The biggest issue with GMO foods is less the foods themselves, and more that companies like Monsanto essentially copyright their gmo crops, and farmers end up having to pay them huge amounts of money to grow them, or starve - if the usual wheat the farmer grows is in a field next to monsanto wheat, they will crosspolinate, and the next year, monsanto will say "actually, what you're growing there is OUR wheat, pay up!"   it's a lot more complicated than just that obviously,  but as usual, huge companies who value profits over human lives are most of the problem.

GMO: my view is that it depends on what exactly has been changed, so adding a gene from a wild variety of the same species like this one: no problem. Making a plant herbicide-resistant (so it can be sprayed without killing it) or even making the plant produce herbicide itself: absolutely not! The problem is that most GMO crops are of the latter variety :-(

We have lakatan and saba bananas here, they are delicious
The issue with bananas is that all of them are clones. The type of banana we eat have no gender and do not 'reproduce' as regular plants, so the plant that'll produce fruit is just cut and transplanted endlessly to make more of it. The fruit is already genetically engineered by humans because it is infertile and simply cannot exist the way we know it without outside influence. This is also why bananas we eat, both the old and the new type, are so susceptible to fungus/disease/insects. They would have been wiped out by nature long ago because they are all a copy of the same plant, and that plant was being killed by a natural enemy. None of them had the defences to combat that and they can't produce any defenses themselves.

GMOs have already saved millions of lives with no credible evidence to suggest they are unsafe to eat.
GMO and selective breeding are the same thing, just at a different time frame. Selective breeding can create hybrids, that are resistant to specific conditions, but this can take several generations or crop cycles, maybe even more. GMO does the same, but we can help it along the way. Something else I think is often misunderstood about GMO, is that, combining genes from different species will affect us. But we don't eat genetic material, we eat the proteins, carbohydrates, fats, etc. Our stomach can't extract the genetic information from our food.

Even monkeys peel bananas!, üòÇ
I am pro-GMO for exactly this kind of situations, GMOs are often used to breed disease resistant or drought resistant or flood resistant food and so on. This can be a real life saver for many people with less than ideal soil for agriculture. Of course I do want to point out that GMO companies can be quite immoral, some only sell sterilized seeds so that farmers can't use the seeds from their harvest for next years crop and have to return to the GMO company for their seeds. This drives some farmers, especially in poorer areas, to bankruptcy.
The practical totality of foods that humans consume are genetically modified, either through mutation and artificial selection, directed crossbreeding and even induced mutation and selection through things like UV light, all without getting the dreaded "GM" label. The only difference is that now we can be a LOT more specific about how we modify our foods, whereas in the past we modified them with a lot less control. The fears around GM are largely based around fearmongering and scientific ignorance, or are arguments that while legitimate have nothing to do with the technology itself (ie. pesticide resistant GM crops may be bad for the local ecology, which is is legitimate but has to do with the use of pesticides, NOT the technology that gave them that resistance, it would be exactly the same if it were a random mutation that wasn't "GM"). Directed genetic modification has been an incredible tool for reducing world hunger and it's no coincidence that those who agitate against them are almost never those who experience food insecurity or the possibility of their entire livelihoods being wiped out by a plant disease.

Regarding GMOs- there is zero evidence GMO foods are harmful and humans have been genetically modifying food since we invented agriculture (bananas are an excellent example). Furthermore this case isn't like liberty corn where the corn is being modified in a transgenic manner to make it resistant to chemical pesticide. This is much more akin to a very specific type of cross breeding where only the desired trait has been moved.  GMO panic is a reaction of under informed people to a process that sounds scary.

3¬∞C in your fridge?! That's way too cold. Usually 8-12¬∞C is absolutely sufficient and saves energy. Only the coolest zone in your fridge should have around 2-5¬∞C (and this is were you keep raw meat and fish for short term). But that would be too cold for beverages, fruits/veggies, cheese, eggs etc. That's why fridges have different temperature zones to begin with.

I used to be pretty wary of GMO stuff, but then I realized that it costs a lot of extra money to buy (which I do not have to spend anymore), it's been around a long time and we don't really have any evidence supporting the idea that it's harmful to us to eat, and it really is important to keep our crops safe because one major food shortage for the developed world will effectively bring everything to its knees. I also heard somewhere that a farmer in Canada was anti-monsanto, and was only using heirloom seeds, and then monsanto sued him (and won) because his seeds had been cross-bred (likely from birds dropping seeds and such) with their stuff and now were technically GMO seeds. I don't remember any of the particulars as to why there was a lawsuit or whatever, I just remember the outcome of the cross-breeding that he wasn't actually aware of nor actively involved in changing his heirloom seeds into something else; and that made me think that we probably cannot guarantee, without DNA testing, that anything we eat is GMO free 100% so why bother worrying about it?

The gmo banana thing: many of these diseases can spread because of extreme mono culture. All these bananas are clones! Because they cant reproduce (since they have no seeds) they are grown from cuttings and are all genetically the same. If we as a society keep pushing the way we do monoculture more and more food crops will have a silimar fate. Disease resistance is often a chance happening with normal fertilisation, and the therefor impossible with this method of reproduction.
