Bananas are not fully ripe until they are partially brown. Putting bananas in the fridge will cause them to turn completely brown faster, I've tested this myself and found it true, but the skin is the only thing that turns brown faster the inside stays yellow/white and firm for much longer than keeping bananas at room temperature. Bananas are also not at their peak nutritious-ness until they are partially brown and slightly soft on the inside. They just don't look as good nor is their texture as appealing, so most actively choose to ignore this fact.   And the people that are fiercely anti-GMO are usually just largely misinformed. The vast majority of people who are fiercely anti-GMO just don't know what it actually means or hear it as a buzz word and just have to agree with the people they want to 'fit in' with. GMO crops could actually eliminate starvation. Heck, thanks to GMO's the vast majority of lumber mills in North America no longer chop down wild trees, they instead chop down private tree 'fields' that are filled with GMO trees that have been modified to grow much stronger, stronger trees means stronger material; much faster, instead of 40-100 years for fully mature trees it takes less than 10 so that by the time they harvest the last of the oldest trees the oldest of the new trees is fully matured and ready to be harvested; and they resistant to both insect and fungal/mold infestation; and they can grow is much less nutrient rich soil than their wild relatives can. These GMO trees combined with reforestation efforts has actually resulted in the USA having more forest area/tree area than ever before in recorded history so the GMO trees are not only producing better lumber but they're helping the planet as well.

GMOs get a bit of a bad rap. Humans have always modified their crop foods, which is a sort of genetic modification, just nowadays instead of spending countless generations of plants trying to get a disease resistant one or bigger crops, it's possible to do it faster. I think people are scared of the concept because it's been passed around that genetic modification is akin to injecting weird chemicals into the edible part, or akin to harsh pesticides, when in reality the modifying occurred long before the plant that produced what you're eating was even grown. And in a lot of places, this is a more environmentally conscious way of stopping invasive pests than just bug bombing a field with inedible stuff. Sorry for the rant though :)

Most people have no idea why they're against them, they just are because they heard from someone or somewhere that GMOs = bad and it makes them feel superior and intelligent to parrot the information. Genetically modifying food can aid in curing world hunger and poverty, and as with the banana, can keep entire foods from falling to disease. Remember the Irish potato famine? That was caused by a fungus, too. It also wiped out around A MILLION PEOPLE. That was what, something like 18-20% of the Irish? Hot damn, 20% of the population??? If we can prevent something like that from ever occurring again by genetically modifying foods, then I don't see how such a thing could possibly be construed as negative. It could be the literal difference between the death or perpetuation of humanity. GMOs? Bring 'em on!   I think the only bad thing about GMOs is the potential for corruption. Company A makes a potato saving modification and wants to make money off of it more than they want to end world hunger, and end up squandering the positive results while the rest of us starve. That chocolate banana thing is an actual thing! At least, I saw it once when I was young. We were camping, and visited some family friends who were camping nearby, and they did something like this. They cut open the bananas (they might have peeled it entirely, I honestly don't remember too well), added chocolate, then they wrapped it in tin foil and cooked it over the fire. I don't remember what they called it, but we all liked it. It's effectively chocolate-covered-banana. Not that hard to see why people would like it imo. I think it's actually a fairly popular thing in Japan? But that's an actual peeled banana coated in chocolate.  Anyway, yeah, chocolate and banana is a thing

Modifying the genes actually can help better yields of crops and maybe even more nutritious. Not sure about nutrients one but as far as I know GMOs help with food production.
The banana and chocolate are called "banana boats" and in my experience were usually eaten at camp (with marshmallows sometimes added as well). The reason they were cooked in the banana skin was that we would cook them in a campfire wrapped in tin foil. Looking back, it was an ingenious dessert as it tasted good but was also gluten-free, nut-free, dairy-free, and (arguably) healthier than other options like ice cream.  I do have to admit I haven't eaten them as an adult, and probably wouldn't just make one in the microwave. Like smores, the location/setting you eat and how you cooked it really affects its enjoyability.
The news media in China is censored, but one can still get a glimpse of the Chinese Communist Party's brutality from the filtered reports that conform to the CCP's narratives.  A Chinese woman living in Japan flew back to China for a heart transplant. Within 10 days, she was provided with four hearts, one after another. As this news was widely reported in China boasting the ample supply of organs, medical professionals began to question the source of these organs, as reported by National Review in an article on August 13 titled ‚ÄúMore Evidence of ‚ÄòOrgans on Demand‚Äô System in China.‚Äù  ‚ÄúChina has been repeatedly and credibly accused of organ harvesting the Falun Gong and other political prisoners, usually for the black market, in which rich foreigners needing a transplant travel there and buy their lives at the cost of ending someone else‚Äôs,‚Äù wrote Wesley J. Smith in the article. ‚ÄúIt is an evil trade, and one for which China should be shunned by the international community.‚Äù  Citing an article titled ‚Äú4 Hearts in 10 Days: China‚Äôs ‚ÄòOn Demand‚Äô Organ Bank Raises Concerns of Forced Harvesting‚Äù published in The Epoch Times on August 11, the National Review article considered the aforementioned woman's on-demand organ supply as new evidence of the forced organ harvesting in China. Torsten Trey, executive director of Doctors Against Forced Organ Harvesting (DAFOH) said patients in the United States usually wait around 6.9 months for a matching heart. This means that finding four hearts for the same person would require over two years in the U.S.   But that was not the whole story. The Epoch Times article noted that half of the U.S. population, or over 156 million adults, have given donation consent. But in China, people in general are reluctant to donate organs due to cultural reasons, and the voluntary organ donation system hardly functions in China.   The easy access to four hearts for one patient in a short time indicates that the organs were provided through an ‚Äúon demand system,‚Äù Trey explained. This is further supported by the double-lung transplants that were broadly reported by Chinese media. Ethan Gutmann, a China analyst in this field, said that the message from such media coverage in China is that, ‚ÄúWe have the organs. It‚Äôs safe. Come on over. China is open for business.‚Äù  In his 2014 book, The Slaughter, Gutmann documented testimonies from top-ranking police officials and Chinese doctors who had confirmed or participated in the organ harvesting crimes. During an interview with DAFOH, he said that many people have asked why the CCP would commit such atrocities. To answer that question, Gutmann conducted extensive analysis and documented his findings in the book.   ‚ÄúThere is nothing stupid about such questions; in fact they are the central dilemma that my book investigates. Six of my ten chapters are devoted to how and why the repression of Falun Gong spun out of control,‚Äù he said in the interview.   Similarly, Smith also believes that ethics plays a crucial role. ‚ÄúThe leaders of a despotism that eschews the sanctity of life, engages in forced labor/slavery to run its industrial manufacturing sector, and crushes religious minorities, aren‚Äôt going to worry about (to them) petty limitations such as morality and basic human decency,‚Äù He wrote in the National Review article.  ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs on them. What‚Äôs on us is that we allow them to get away with it,‚Äù he concluded.

personally i don't think there's any problem putting a gene from one banana into another banana. All domestic crops have been genetically modified though selective breeding anyway, is there any difference between inserting a gene from a closely related species and cross breeding the two species? I don't think so. What i would like to see is a greater variety of banana types in grocery stores. The average grocery store in the US has five or six different types of apples, but maybe one or two (counting plantains) types of bananas. Where is the banana version of the Honeycrisp? or the Gala? or Fiji? I know that there are many other commercial varieties out there but we never see them in regular stores. If you want a Java banana or any of the others you have to special order them for a lot of money. I think there should be more varieties of bananas in stores. Not only would that be more interesting and yummy, it would be good for the industry as well. Right now it's a monoculture, which is vulnerable to disease. if we broke that up and had many banana varieties available the banana industry would be more robust and could more easily switch to more hardy varieties if something came through

Well, about GMO, I don't think it'll be harmful for our health if it's done by inserting a gene of interest (in this situation, TR4 resistant gene) into another organism's genome (Cavendish banana). It only involves using a vector or a "gene courier" (usually for plants, Bacillus thuringiensis is used), where it carries the gene and inserts it into Cavendish banana's cell. Most GMOs in the market usually use this method. It's like your traditional selective breeding except that we use recombinant DNA technology.

He genetically modified it with a gene from the same species... that's a fairly minimal change. Plus, a quick look at the Nature paper says the introduced gene is 98.6% homologous with an already present gene in the Cavendish varietal - the Cavendish just doesn't express this gene at a high enough level to naturally confer resistance. This is a great example of effectively implementing biotechnology for plant conservation.
I was taught to cover the tops of the banana [where it is cut from the bunch] b/c it's "open" to the air - and the air getting into the banana makes it age faster. ...But I also learned that it's the same for avocados...that the tiny stem being "open" lets air get inside so it goes bad faster.

actual spoiler alert: the 'normal' banana we eat, the Cavendish banana, is ALREADY highly genetically modified, that is why it does not have seeds inside. Without seeds the plant can't reproduce so all bananas that we eat are 'clones', and this breed of bananas will quickly die out if humans stop cultivating and planting it artificially
GMO is probably the only way we as a species would be able to survive and feed ourselves + the potential of GM technology in medicine is incredible. imagine people could be immune to diseases without having to take medicines or vaccinations, imagine you  could treat people with currently untreatable disabilities. there will always be people who are afraid of science and progress and just new things in general, but genetic modification is not even a new thing. selective breeding of agricultural plants and domesticated animals is the same thing: goal is the same and result is the same, just a different method, we have been doing that for centuries. If you are against GMO please read more studies about it and reconsider. "all natural" is no more than a marketing trick, we would all starve if not for GMO produce

Edit about GMOs: Personally I'm fine with them as food (so long as the modification has a valid reason i.e. disease resistance) because I see it as essentially the same thing that plant/animal breeders have been doing for millenia, but with faster results. Most of what is accomplished using modern genetic modification techniques could be achieved using traditional breeding methods, but it could take hundreds of generations to achieve the same results. However, I do believe that there need to be limits on it (or rather the results of it) due to lawsuits bankrupting small (and some not so small) farmers due to inadvertent pollination of crops by a certain strain created by a truly terrible American based company that has been recently acquired by Bayer.

To be fair I've heard that banana tops being wrapped years ago. I used to be a fruit and veg saleman back in the late 1980s in the UK. I live across the road from what used to be one of the biggest banana importers too - Geest. And they had tested these things YEARS ago and found them to be crap. What does help though, is that they gas them in large ovens.  But from your own point of view the easiest way to keep bananas (and to buy them) make sure they never get below 53 degrees. So if you are shopping in a supermarket especially at this time of year, if they have boxes laying around, stick your hand in. If they're warm, they'll be fine, but if they're cold, avoid them. If you buy them and keep them warm at home, they'll still turn horribly grey and grainy.  Of course, as Anne points out, this is mostly for aesthetics.

CAUTION: TRYPOPHOBIA WARNING @ 27:53 - 28:00!!!¬† Ann shows us a picture of a wild banana with a crazy amount of giant black irregularly shaped seeds popping up through the fruit ü§¢ I don't even have the phobia and it grossed me out (Please like this comment so Ann can see it and pin it/ add a warning)
The biggest question about the channel she debunked in this matter is: why on earth would they waste perfectly edible bananas for absolute bananas of planting method?? Seriously.
What bugs me about GMOs is the ones that are purposely made sterile or when they try to control who can grow a plant to keep people dependent on external sources for food. You replace a plant with a sterile GMO version and if you let the wild variant go extinct due to lack of market value, then if anything wipes out the GMO the plant is just gone. GMOs aren't inherently bad and have greatly broadened the variety of foods available to us, but capitalism causes them to be used and made in ways that prioritize selling a product even if that comes to the detriment of consumers or the plants themselves. It reminds me of how the wild counterparts of many domestic animals have gone extinct from over hunting or habitat loss. What would happen to domesticated species should we cease to raise them? GMOs aren't just the things we modify in a lab but what we modify through breeding too. How many of them both plant and animal could cause harm if they found their way into the wild?  Farming in general warrants a lot of responsibility in ways that companies don't want to bother with unless legally obligated to, in addition to stuff like the ethics of allowing the trademarking of living organisms due to a particular genetic sequence and subsequent suing or farmers whose crops were unwillingly contaminated with a trademarked GMO crop.
Here are my thoughts on "genetically modified": We are modifying the genes of our crops since the beginning of the agricultural revolution. Neither grafting (which is the genetic equivalent of "hey, let's find out what happens when we combine A and B -- we can not predict the results, but it sure is fun!") not any other method caused humanity to be eradicated by Killer Tomatoes or Kamikaze Bananas. While one could argue that there is compelling evidence of a cross between Homo sapiens and various vegetables. And if we'd absorb genetic material of our food, as some people seem to believe, there'd be a lot more talking potatoes around.
Not many people realize that everything we eat is genetically modified. The only difference between GMO and Domestication is the speed in which it happens. Through Domestication we made strawberries that are more resilient to pests like insects then their wild versions. GMO is just the insertion of the gene that makes it resilient without the hundreds or thousands of years in-between the start and end points.

Related fact, when you talk about how the banana groves were killed off in the 50s this is related to why banana flavored candies don't taste at all like the bananas we're used to. That artificial flavoring was designed to taste more like the past banana species as opposed to the one we eat today.  So assuming we do get a different breed of banana because of this fungus, there's a good chance that it will not taste the same as we're used to now.
My only issue with GMOs is when huge corporations patent seeds and then sue small farms and plantations for using second gen seeds that naturally develop instead of buying new ones from the corporation every year. If we're going to rely more heavily on GMOs, we need to figure out an ethical way of handling seed patents.
I understand the fear of GMO's, but I can't say that I get it. Genetic modification has been occuring since human's first developed farming and agriculture, with selective breeding of crops and animals. And the 'frakenstein' argument is thinner than rice paper as the practice of grafting plants to each other is more akin to Mary Shelly's depictions than anything produced in a lab. The amount of research and testing that goes into genetically modifying a plant is astronomical, and I'm sure more things remain within them then we will ever see come to market. The fact of the matter is that our current farming practices are not sustainable, we are killing the plannet. And anti-gmo people are only contributing to its expediation. Unless people are willing to change their diets and adapt to changes -like gmo's- there won't be a planet to argue over these things about on anymore.   Sorry if I got a bit intense there, I watched David Attenborough's netflix special the other day and I am still wired from it. The biggest issue that I have seen with GMO's is corporate greed, some companies have been producing hardier, higher yeilding crops but making them unfurtile, or less effective with subsequent generations to force farmers into continually buying new seeds from them, rather than becoming self sufficient. Similarly, they have been sueing neighbouring farms for encroaching on 'patents' when natural cross polonation occurs. It's disgusting, and as with any emerging market, is in dire need of regualation from people who understand the science and scope of the issue. That person is certainly not me, and I definately don't think it should be someone with an unhelathy fear of new technology. It's when people think information is being hidden from them that they start to become suspicious and look into conspiracy theories. So, thank you.

Genetic modification of food crops is a brilliant idea that offers the potential to improve our lives in all sorts of ways.  It is great for the environment, because it allows more crops to be grown on less land with less use of pesticides, herbicides, fungicides, and fertilizers.  It also prevents food wastage by delaying spoilage.  It improves nutrition by allowing vitamins to be added to foods.  It has the potential to improve flavor and texture as well.  Genetically modified crops are furthermore subjected to extremely rigorous testing for health and safety before being allowed onto the market.  They are not at all dangerous.

Nothing wrong with GMOs.  It's basically doing what we've already been doing for millennia but more quickly and more precisely.  Seriously, just about everything we eat has been genetically modified, we've just done it through selective cultivation or selective breeding rather than direct modification of DNA through, for example, CRISPR.  And we've gotten hood enough at gene editing to change things like crop yield, environmental sensitivity, and vitamin content (such as golden rice having beta-carotene, a precursor to Vitamin A absent from white rice while being as viable and as high-yield as white rice in the same environments, potentially mitigating the malnutrition that plagues those regions.  Or, it would, if groups like Greenpeace didn't push this narrative that GMOs are the devil and that using genetically modified staple crops to reduce famine and malnutrition is somehow racist and imperialist because we need to make the regions richer before we reduce starvation and vitamin deficiencies - putting the cart before horse, there - but I digress).  The people tinkering with genetics aren't idiots, they're not risking turning wheat fields into entire hectares of Audrey 2s from Little Shop of Horrors.  The GMO phobia is in the exact same camp as anti-vax, it's just straight up technophobia is most cases.  Tgere are genuine reasons to be cautious with the technology, but that goes for _every_ technology, from the first time we banged rocks together right up until now, and right up until sapient life dies off in the cold, distant emptiness of the universe's last hours.  Also, fun fact: most bana flavoring is based on the Gros Michel, not the Cavendish.  If you've ever wondered why banana flavor doesn't taste like banana, that's why.

People have since they figured out how to do so been selecting and combining strains of different plants for their hardiness, or flavor, or size, or any number of other characteristics. IIRC, banana peels do have UV-resistant properties... but as part of the overall peel, you know, the comparatively thick rind of the fruit. You can't just dry the peel and rub the oils on your skin, you'd have to craft a suit made entirely of woven banana peels. GMOs themselves are not harmful. A lot of produce we consume have been steadily modified over decades to be edible and look good to eat. The actual problem with GMOs is the fact that big name companies will try to use GMOs against pesticides that will harm animal life around it or harmful to the planet itself. GMO is simply as Ann said - using a DNA structure from one plant to help promote a quality of life on another. People do something similar all the time - when a person gets an antibiotic or is resistant to something, the chance that it'll be passed on to their baby will be significantly increased via either DNA recombinance or via breast milk.   I believe a lot of the GMO fear is from misunderstandings and actual promotions of false information. It's an anti-science propaganda tool which should actually be used against corporations and money mongering machines instead. Pesticides and mass production and waste as well as refusing to give away food to the hungry is the problem. Not GMOs.

GMOs are not dangerous and aren‚Äôt any more unhealthy than organic alternatives. If anything, they actually might be better that selective breeding, etc. A scientist who studies GMOs said this analogy: If the navigation in a car is broken, wouldn‚Äôt it be easier to replace the navigation if you‚Äôre familiar with everything else in the car and everything works well rather than buying another used car that has a working navigation and you know nothing else about it. Having something with GMOs means it‚Äôs controlled what you change. If something is organic and selectively bread for that specific trait, you don‚Äôt always know what else is affected. But again, both GMOs and organic foods are perfectly healthy but GMOs have been used to help populations that have minimal access to certain vitamins and nutrients by increasing the amount of those vitamins in the food they eat. Also GMO goods are usually bigger and sometimes cheaper.

I like to think that with any kind of technology or advancement, there is a good way to use it and a bad way to use it. This seems like a good way. GMO, in essence, similar to grafting. We take one characteristic from one plant, and put it into another. Why should that be a bad thing if there are no adverse effects? Another interesting factoid: according to Jewish law, jewish people are prohibitied from performing grafts but there is no restriction on enjoying the results if the process was performed by someone else. So Jewish people can still enjoy nectarines and pomelo!  Did anyone ever figure out the point of stuffing a chili pepper into a banana?
We do the chocolate in the banana as an easy desert going camping, in aluminum foil on the campfire, quite nice.  About the GMOs, In my opinion, not all GMOs are created equal. When a crop is modified to withstand great amounts of herbicides or insecticides etc, which leads to excessive spraying, hurting ecosystems, native species and humans it is obviously a problem. When a thorough risk assessment and prior research is done regarding the consequences of the specific modification, I think it can be a very good thing. I was considering studying plant genetics, but because of the stigma of GMOs I have the impression that there are not many jobs in Europe to be found. I think this stigma is so unfortunate because GMOs could contribute in solving the climate crisis.

Here's a banana hack that actually works. Slow-fry banana slices in salted (aka table) butter over a low flame. The sugars form a caramel skin on the outside, encasing a lovely, cloud-like interior. While handling these delicate morsels can be tricky (I use a silicon spatula), once you get the hang of it, they make the perfect garnish for hot or cold cereals, waffles, pancakes, or the core of a bananas Foster.

GMO itself is fine.   My issue is that when farmers purchase GMO seed, they sign contracts with seed companies with an agreement to purchase new seed each year and not save seed from their crops to plant the following year. The seeds gotten from the genetically modified plants don't all carry the gene that made them desirable, and I'm not well-read on the issue. But I feel this could definitely be abused in favor of the seed distributors. Anyone who has a better informed opinion is appreciated.

So, a fun little fact about wrapping bananas into cellophane/tape.  My father was a sailor in the 50s, and he often delivered fruit from Africa to Europe. He never mentioned any specific countries, and I never asked, so sorry for the lack of info on that part. Of course, when they delivered hundreds of tons of fruit, no one would miss a few kilos, so they always took a bit for the crew. And he told me many funny stories about that, however, the one about bananas went that they actually wrapped them into cellophane *to* make them ripe faster. As, of course, they got a load of green-ish bananas, making up for the travel, so the fruit would be ripe when it gets to the destination port.  He said that at some point one of the sailors would have one of his bananas ripe and with black spots. And when that happened, that banana was confiscated, cut into small pieces, and those pieces were added to other sailors' banana packs, making them ripe perfectly overnight, ready to eat.  The story is true, but I don't know if the method actually worked, but it sounds plausible.

GMO foods are fine, we have been modifying foods for millennia.  I'm Anti-GMO only in the case of businesses exploiting people. In Canada Monsanto sells seeds to farmers who farm adjacent to farmers who don't use GMO seed, then when the wind picks up and spreads the seed over to the neighbouring farm, Monsanto sues the non-GMO farm. The business of GMOs is currently not ethical. However, things like Golden Rice and this new banana breed have a place in our world, I just hope that predatory businesses don't take advantage and bleed farmers dry

So a few more bits about the GMO stuff: If you're in the US, about 90% of soy crop is genetically modified. The first genetically modified food hit shelves in 1992, Flavr Savr Tomatoes, which had an added gene from fish that made them more shelf stable. Additionally, most GMO foods are just scientists speeding up the natural process of evolution. From the second humans starred farming, about 12000 years ago, we were modifying the genetics of plants, though perhaps unintentionally. If you were a farmer, you would probably want to only use seeds from your biggest, most successful plants, right? THATS genetic modification too! You are directly altering which genes get represented in future generations of the crop. Most genetic modification in crops today is focused on pest resistance or disease resistance, so we can reduce the need for external chemical spraying. And, there's been no study of GMOs which can demonstrate adverse health effects. The main issue with GMOs is that people don't understand them, and general anti-science and anti-intellectualism attitudes turn this misunderstanding into fear. (Good article to get you started: https://www.sciencealert.com/review-of-6000-studies-over-two-decades-delivers-its-verdict-on-GMO-corn-safety) ALSO with the bananas, one of the reasons they are so susceptible to disease is because they are tetraploid, which means they have 4 copies of each chromosome (humans are diploid, which means we have 2 copies). Because of this, the bananas can only reproduce with other similar species that are ALSO tetraploid, and on a plantation, there aren't any. Modern bananas are basically so inbred that they have NO genetic resistance to disease and no ability to adapt that resistance on their own, which is why the story of the scientist finding wild bananas and genetically modifying them is so cool!
I feel that GMO is not that bad unless it has any side effects. Besides, why are people against this specific genetic modification if it has no side effect and are safe for both us and the environment. Is there any harm? If yes pls reply and tell so that everybody comes to know!

Thank you for the information Mrs Reardon, God knows what would've happened if people like you didn't debunk, breakdown and explain the science behind "Lifehacks".
Bananas we eat used to look closer to the wild ones - with a lot of seeds and not a lot of what we like in bananas. Similarly with a lot of grain plants - they used to look more like grass, with smaller seeds. Selective breeding got them where they are today - more suited for how we exploit them. GMO is basically selective breeding speedrun. You could try naturally crossing two bananas and then through decades of breeding achieve a plant that is edible and also resistant to fungi. Or you could do it million times faster by just handpicking the gene you need and inserting it in a plant. Food DNA has no effect on our internal DNA because of two reasons. One - we simply digest it as we have no need for external DNA. Two - our cells are extremely resistant to accepting foreign DNA and have multiple barriers preventing it from entering and cutting it if it does somehow get in. Viruses need a whole set of mechanisms to be able to merge their DNA with ours - mechanisms that plant/animal cells dont have. GMO food has no effect on our bodies. We've been eating GMO soy for years and years now - theres basically no 'natural' soy anymore, and we managed to survive. The one study I've seen cited, that 'proves' higher cancer rates in mice fed with GMO, was redacted because of biased lab practice. The test was conducted on mice who are already more prone to cancer - because they are a type of mice used in cancer research. So making any conclusions about higher rates of cancer in mice who were bred to get cancer in the first place is incredibely cherry-picky. Nothing to worry about, if we internalised food DNA, whole Italy would be half tomatoes by now ;)
I love informative you are at debunking fake information. People who make miss information should get in trouble because it misleading to whoever watches them and sometimes it not always about viewed or money. Keep up the good work. Kind of surprised Dave has agreed to eat bad hacks. Lol.

I am a scientist (currently doing my PhD in molecular biochemistry) and for me as I know a lot about GMOs it is totally fine and I think GMOs should not generally be seen as a threat. There has been a massive amount of studies showing that GMOs created via for example CRISPR are having the same properties as if you would have cultivated certain strains of vegetables over years trying to make them "bigger and more fleshy" so they give more to harvest and sell like they did for cucumbers etc with normal cultivation. I think the risk that GMOs might be a competitor for normal plants is way higher than health risks for humans so the question is more in that direction than into "will it be safe". Then again I have not been up to date with newest developments so maybe there is some new research I havent looked into, but as I am involved in basic research of lysosomal storage diseases it is not really my field. But in terms of the discussion I recommend to look into the "golden rice" debate, in case you have not heard of that. It is rice with high provitamin A levels that turns it yellow or "golden" which might help with the health issues in poorer countries where vitamin A deficiency is often an issue. The researchers developing it tried to keep prices low and prevent companies from redeveloping it so it would be affordable to plant and cultivate but people still scream about it being GMO and try to sabotage is massively without any proven health risks since development in the 90s.

Well the Cavendish banana is already a genetical modified clone, I don't really see how you could get worst XD Cavendish banana, so basically all bananas in the world, is the result of years of artificial selection, so that's genetical modification without the help of a computer, and it's been a century since they reproduce, all these crops are just clones of one plant. And that's why this mushroom is so devastating, in nature a plant have a bunch of individuals with different resistances, and a disease or a parasite can't kill them all because they can resist it. In mono-culture crops with GMO clones, like humans do, one disease, one mushroom can kill all the crop.  The problem is our method of growing bananas, if we adopt this new Cavendish, in 20 or 50 years, a new mushroom or a new disease will began to destroy it and we would need to find new genes to save the bananas ^^' And it's the same for the persons that grew bananas, before they were imposed to grew these bananas, they had normal crops, with variety, it's not normal that some persons rely so much on one plant, or that some farmers have only one plant to grew, once again the problem is our method of agriculture ^^

It's a clone plant, which means all the bananas we eat are cloned from a single banana back in the day that we keep cloning. This is another reason why Panama disease is so devastating because our bananas dont have much resistance BECAUSE we bred as a cloned fruit. Have you turned into a debunking channel now lol
I'm not against GMO nor am I all for it. GMO is a technology, it's what you make of it that decides if it's good or bad.   When GMO is used to achieve the same ends as you would by normal plant breeding I am all for it. It's simply a way to shave off several years of the process to achieve the final result.  When GMO is used to introduce genes across species things can become a lot more complex ethically. But I'd say that I'm generally positive. A good example of GMOs in medicine is insulin production in bacteria. However when it comes modyfing (human) embryos to cure genetic diseases it becomes hard to make a distinction between cure and enhancement.  Another example of effective transfers of genes between species is the gene for producing BT-toxin (it only affects insects) introduced in crops from Bacillus thuringiensis. BT-toxin is because of this produced in the plants that we aim to protect. This eliminate the problem of affecting more insects than the pests themselves. However my opinion on this is that the best way to limit the risk pests on crops is to aim for less large monocultures and  higher biodiversity in the agricultural landscape.   The big problem I see with GMO in agriculture is the risk of one or a few companies gaining a monopoly because of how patents on superior strains.   In short: When GM is used to cure illness and reduce environmental impact its good but with it comes problems of patents/monopoly and drawing lines between cures/enhancement, that we have to tackle.

Dave: cooked banana isn't really that good Indonesian: hold my pisang goreng a.k.a. fried banana üôÉ
I agree with @Very Lost on the GMO question. It's not the principle of GMOs in themselves that's the problem, it's the motivation for creating them. In the main, the motive is profit, and so the organisms are patented and licensed to farmers on terms which prevent them saving seeds / cuttings to plant next year (increasing their costs and so the cost of food), and the modifications are tied to the use of particular companies' pesticides ("Roundup Ready"). Alongside this, there is the history (in the pharmaceutical industry among others) of suppressing negative findings in safety testing.  Where genetic modification is aimed at the public good (e.g.  solving problems of hunger, reducing the needs for pesticides), I fully support its use, and particularly public funding of the research. It looks like the research to which you referred is supported by an Australian Research Council grant, and I hope it will be made available to the farmers who need these new cultivars, not to a corporation to licence to the farmers.
The banana and the apple is something that I learned about in Highschool in the chemistry class, our teacher showed us a video about how bananas shouldn‚Äôt be kept close to apples as they will ripe much faster due to the apple realising some gas, but I don‚Äôt remember what it was. Only if I could find that video, I will try and find it and then put the link here. Edit: it is Ethylene from both the bananas and the apples, basically the video which our teacher showed talked about how both fruits produce Ethylene and shouldn‚Äôt be kept together as the bananas will ripe faster. The video is in German, but if you still want to watch it, here it is: https://youtu.be/U1fbeyocWvU . I can help with translation, you can contact me on my Insta page @alexia_gabriela_muntean.

People who like cavendish bananas but dislike the idea of GMO bananas resistant to disease are probably not well informed. The reason why cavendish is so susceptible to disease is that they‚Äôre all genetic copies of each other because they aren‚Äôt capable of seeding. Two of the biggest legitimate complaints of GMOs is that it might lessen genetic diversity and that they might spread into the wild. Neither of those things apply in this case. Other perceived cons of GMOs are either demonstrably false (them being nutritionally worse for example) or nonsensical in nature (being less ‚Äúnatural‚Äù for example).

I have no problesm with certain types of GMO; using the DNA of a wild plant to improve disease resistance in a cultivated strain is an excellent use of the technology - even though we cannot be certain of side effects down the track, it's less dangerous to health and the environment that other uses, like putting jellyfish DNA in fruit to make it glow in the dark. I think gmos are fine. If it allows us to access foods that are otherwise inaccessible. Then why not!
A GMO isn‚Äôt inherently unsafe, although you could certainly create something harmful through a GMO process. Overall, foods with GMO‚Äôs have yet to show any issues. Genetically this makes sense. If we know the genetic makeup of the organism and how it was created, it should be easy to tell if there is anything harmful in it. Genetics is both much simpler than many think but of course there‚Äôs a deep level of complexity within that. Genes can be easily switched around and spliced through CASPR, but adding a 10 segment difference in a promoter region could also have severe effects. Fascinating stuff, but as I said, most scientists in the field or related to it have no issue with GMO‚Äôs, nor is there much research agains them. People don‚Äôt realize how much they‚Äôve benefited from GMO‚Äôs that‚Äôs for sure though since so much of our modern food supply chain relies on GMO products.

I think another reason that Banana myth has persisted so strongly is because (where I live, at least. In FL in the US) bananas very often come with taped up stems. I actually explained this to my niece the other day. They don't do that to keep them fresh, they do it to keep the hands together and discourage people separating and ripping the bananas apart. My guess is that people would pick the best bananas from each bundle and leave the bad ones, and rip off bananas tearing some of them open making them inedible.   Gullible dorks see that tape on the top and take it as evidence and confirmation bias runs rampant!

GMOs are developed to solve problems like these, it's like a better controlled, sped up version of selective breeding, it isn't attack of the killer tomatoes or whatever it is people are afraid of, "mad scientists" and "evil scientists" only exist in fiction. Genetically modifying plants has been happening for over 5000 years. It's the only reason our species hasn't had a major food shortage and suffered mass starvation. We need it, and there is no evidence that it causes any issues. There are plenty of studies showing that GMOs have absolutely no negative effects on the body. The one single study that said GMO's were bad, was discredited by 10 other studies who actively tried to replicate the results of the initial study.  GMO's do not effect fertility, foetal health and risks of mutations, organ health, cannot modify or mutate genes, or decrease lifespan in any way.   We are all alive because of GMO's. It's that simple.  http://sitn.hms.harvard.edu/flash/2015/will-gmos-hurt-my-body/

We make ‚Äúchocolate bananas‚Äù when we go camping. Cut a slit in the skin, shove pieces of chocolate inside the slit (on each side of the banana), wrap the whole thing in foil, then place on the coals in the campfire (making sure the ‚Äúbanana boat‚Äù stays upright so the slit faces the sky, otherwise all the melted chocolate and banana juices will fall out and burn).   The chocolate melts, and the bananas cooks - changing the flavour from raw banana to something more like banana bread. It‚Äôs delicious!  It won‚Äôt be anywhere near as nice trying to do it in a microwave though üòù Think of a microwaved potato compared to a potato cooked in foil in the coals of the campfire. Totally different flavours and textures!

My main concern with GMOs is mostly about the economics of it - e.g., some populations around the world are reliant on companies selling them the seeds, so it creates an unhealthy and arguably unethical dependency which can entrench and reinforce aspects of poverty. It's a very complex and long conversation, but in short there can be some nasty development-related repercussions for certain countries. I don't think GMOs in of themselves are an environmental concern, it's more the pesticides that are a serious worry. I actually wonder if GMOs might be the answer to using less pesticides.

Seeing the banana harvesting and packaging process there - is anyone else thinking about Harry Belafonte?
I worked in supermarkets here in Australia for nearly ten years, largely in produce - the logistics behind fruit and veg growth, transport and preservation is fascinating. Most of our apples throughout the year come from carefully controlled storage with low oxygen and temperatures. Bananas were particularly interesting - we'd normally sell at least one full pallet a day, with overstocks needing to be re-stacked in open containers with passages between the boxes to allow airflow. When held at room temperature, they'd release gas and heat and cause the entire pallet to over ripen within a day or so.

Love watching this.... How to not waste banana peels.. specifically plantain peels... For traditional green leafy vegetables here in Kenya, our tribe dries the peels together with some stalks and legume pods till totally crispy dry then burnt on the jiko/grill. We then soak it water for ten minutes and filter. We gut 'munyu'/ liquid salt super strong and nice for the veggies, packed with vitamins/minerals...hack that

As a  food scientist, I can say that I know how GMOs work and I consider most of them are safe to eat and will eat them without hesitation. GMOs are great when they are used to ensure everyone has food, but they're bad when they're used to control the propagation of food (suicide seeds) or make plants resistant to herbicides or pesticides, allowing those crops to be sprayed more heavily, putting the farm workers at risk of cancer. So it's not the GMOs, it's the intentions of the people developing them: are they humanitarians, or capitalists?

) Several major media outlets in Finland gave front-page coverage on a forum discussing forced organ harvesting in China held in Helsinki on September 19, 2019. Finland‚Äôs most popular newspapers, the Helsinki Daily (Helsingin Sanomat) and HSL (the top Swedish newspaper in Finland), reported on the forum.   The reason for the rise of organ transplantation in China, the response of the international community, and people‚Äôs indignation at the Chinese Communist Party‚Äôs (CCP) state-sanctioned organ harvesting from living Falun Gong practitioners were all discussed during the forum.    Helsinki Daily's online and print reports on the forum held in Helsinki on September 19, 2019  HSL (the best-selling Swedish newspaper in Finland) reported on the forum.  The reports stated, ‚ÄúThe CCP started the persecution of Falun Gong in 1999. Since then, the rate of organ transplantation in China has risen rapidly. The country‚Äôs voluntary organ donation system was not established until 2013.  ‚ÄúThe CCP acknowledged the use of organs from death-row prisoners for organ transplants and stated it had stopped doing that in early 2015. However, the extent of executions has not yet reached a level that explains the high rate of organ transplantation.  ‚ÄúHuman rights lawyers, doctors, and activists investigating live organs collected multiple pieces of evidence. According to them, China conducts 60,000 to 100,000 organ transplants every year through organs taken from prisoners of conscience. Most of the organs were taken from Falun Gong practitioners.  ‚ÄúIn recent years, people suspected that the organs of Uighur Muslims living in Xinjiang are stolen. Uighurs are undergoing health tests and blood tests. According to [Enver Tohti, a former Uighur surgeon who witnessed the Chinese regime‚Äôs harvesting of organs from prisoners], the purpose of the test was to form a live bank of human organs along with information about Tibetan and Christians of underground churches.  ‚ÄúHowever, most of the evidence proves that the organs are from Falun Gong practitioners. There are 800,000 to 3 million people in Chinese concentration camps and prisons. The limited transparency of these camps means that there are no exact figures [about] the seriousness of the problem.‚Äù

I think GMO has good and bad applications. Obviously disease resistance on food sources we rely on are good. However- we've tied ourselves, economically, with things like mass exports and reliances on certain mass produced and exported foods and this has in many ways taken over local produce and production everywhere- but we can't simply stop doing it because as you say some people are entirely reliant on the mass market to feed their families.  On the other hand- GMO can and has been used to do things like reduce seeds in things like lemons and grapes, which consumers like, but means we are reliant on human intervention to continue these plants survival rather than the traditional methods of spreading seeds without human input. I have very little issue with GMOs, pretty much every single vegetable or fruit we eat today has been Genetically Modified in some way, whether that Modification be from selective breeding (which is actually what I am working on studying to potentially make a career out of) or from gene splicing. I think people are just generally hesitant because they dont know the processes behind GMOs so they automatically think it is bad.
Something i think more people need to realize is that humans have been genetically modifying plants for as long as we‚Äôve been farmers by selectively breeding wild plants. The native tribes of north america selectively bred maze and  squash, those in the middle east bred rye, and asia domesticated soy and rice. It was only a natural progression to insert genetic material to get desired traits quicker. The only problem with GMOs in my opinion are greedy companies trying to snuff out local farmers and monopolizing on a certain gene strain.

The problem with genetically modified organisms is not that they are ‚Äúunnatural ‚Äúor ‚Äúunhealthy‚Äù. The real issue is that genetically modified crops are able to be patented by the company that is able to pay the scientist that made them. After a crop is patented the company can put laws into place that prevent small farmers from being able to save their own seeds to re-plant the crops. This means that small farmers are reliant upon buying a company‚Äôs seeds year after year after year. This puts small farmers into financial strain and places a monopoly upon a certain crop in the market. We see this with Monsanto round up ready soy beans and we are starting to see it with a variety of corn gmo producers. The reason I am non-GMO is not because I think GMO‚Äòs are terrible and unnatural, I am non-GMO because the legal system behind the food industry is lacking in a lot of protections that we really need. The least I can do is support small farmers by buying non-GMO foods.
The non-GMO fad really seems like the "organic" fad where a bunch of privileged people get scared by a few words without actually thinking about what they mean. Heaven forbid we tell them that anything living is organic.

The biggest issue with GMO foods is that there was an assumption for a long time that a safe food that's modified would also be safe. To the point where regulatory bodies didn't (and many still don't ) require testing in order to sell genetically modified foods to the public. The issue is that assumption is incorrect. There are many instances in nature where a defective protein is hazardous when ingested. One example is mad cow disease. It's not caused by a virus or bacteria or fungus. It's just a misbehaving protein. The same kind of thing could happen with any genetically modified organism. And yes there have been animal genes placed in plants already, but this could happen with just plant based modifications. Without testing we will never know. Even with testing we might not know the long term effects of any change.
I don't have a problem with GMOs, especially when it comes to something like being able to feed more people.

About GMOs: I think the big problem with them is actually taking a blanket stance either for or against. GMOs themselves are not necessarily evil or harmful, and it seems a lot of people have huge misconceptions about how or why they are even developed.  I think they're a useful tool for food growers to respond to things that put their crop at risk. People talk about them like they are actually bad for you or not healthy I  some way (naturalistic fallacy), but I think the biggest concern is actually if the GMO becomes an out of control invasive species. I keep reading what I can about them, continuing to develop the best informed opinion I can.

The GMO debate is about as stupid as it gets all vegies and fruits we eat is GMO have you seen the OG corn or many other plants with fruits, and these people might as well be anti-vaccine as well if fact they probably are a lot of cross over.
The GMO controversy is just plain stupid. The simple reason why is that its just too vague and generic.  Yes, there are some GMO plants that have since shown to be harmful, at least potentially so, such as Round Up Ready crops. Those ones are bad and should be replaced with better alternatives.  But GMO as a whole is not harmful or bad. Its good, and in a slower and less precise form, has been going on pretty well all of human history.  Potatoes being selectively grown and cross bred to get variants that don't kill us. Bananas and avocados being selectively grown and cross bred to not be mostly seed. Wheat and other grains being selectively grown to be taller and thus produce more. Natural resistances to diseases, to pests, to weather, all selectively grown or cross bred into just about every plant we eat.  And now, more modern technology is doing the same thing but by isolating genes, doing it in a lab. What's the real difference? Instead of planting a some seeds from a plant that naturally grew more with seeds from one that naturally resisted a specific disease and repeating that over and over until Mother Nature decided to finally produce a plant with both traits, then clearing out all of the others and planting clippings of the result to spread it through fields before repeating the process when a new disease appears or one ends up growing even more, we do it in a lab with less random chance, getting results faster and sometimes even letting us do mixtures that weren't possible before.  As a result, we are getting crops that yield far more per harvest, grow faster, are resistant to even more diseases, have fewer or smaller seeds than before (do you really think the current seedless bananas we eat are fully natural?), and sometimes that are even healthier than before (ruby rice, I believe its called. The yield of rice with the nutrients of tomatoes).  In the past, this Cavendish banana issue would have been resolved slowly by cross breeding them with the disease resistant wild bananas until they eventually got a disease resistant Cavendish banana or a seedless variant of the wild banana. Plantations likely would have shut down on larger scales (relatively speaking as a hundred years ago they wouldn't have had as many or as large of plantations anyway) and bananas probably would have wound up pretty scarce for quite a while before they were finally successful, assuming they were able to cross breed them in time in the first place.  So GMOs as a whole are NOT bad, and anyone that says otherwise can try finding a list of plants that we didn't modify centuries ago with cross breeding and eat those. I hope they enjoy the wild bananas that are 85% seed. As for the GMO plants that actually are harmful, yes, we should work on removing them and replacing them, but that has other issues slowing down the process, namely idiots that disagree that lives are worth more than money, especially given the current crisis going on.

obviously there are concerns around genetic modification in terms of how it impacts and interferes in local ecosystems, potentially changing far more species than just the intended one whether it be plant or animal, but by and large mainstream anti-GMO rhetoric is a bunch of fearmongering misinformation.  like, the bananas we eat are pretty much all genetically modified as they're sterile and are reproduced by cloning.  not to mention all the crops that humans have genetically modified over centuries through selective breeding and grafting etc - those aren't "natural"  it's frustrating because genetic modification can be so incredibly useful, whether it's extending the shelf life of produce therefore making it more accessible to poorer folks, or creating flood resistant rice that can feed millions of people, or saving the banana industry and all the people who rely on it for income and nutrition.  as long as the potential consequences of introducing the gene from the wild plant are thoroughly studied and the pros and cons are carefully weighed, as I'm sure they will be, I don't see the problem

GMO's have been around since the beginning of time only now it has a name. When organisms grow in the wild they are changing and mixing with other organisms all the time. When agriculture became domesticated seeds were often traded and bought by man and the strongest strains went even further. Now we are able to take those strains and combine them in a lab. It's nothing artificial or science fiction. No franken-fruit or anything.
The stuff we humans have done to food plants boggles the mind.  GMOs is one of the nicer, safer things! There are lots of rules, regulations and stiff testing laws.  Back in the atomic age they would throw seeds , seedlings and tree buds on trays and expose them to large amounts of radiation to see what would happen!   Look up how we almost lost the ruby red grapefruit.

Greetings from America! I have a trick to preserving bananas that my plant bio professor taught me:   If you separate all the bananas and store them as single bananas away from each other, the amount of ethylene released is smaller since a bunch of bananas release ethylene clouds while single bananas don't. I've been doing this for nearly 2 years and it works like a charm. But you'll have to get used to seeing bananas placed all over the house.

I believe there's a good reason for GMOs but also can be bad reasons. If the bad one is ruining the original crop and dangerous, then I see a problem with it. As long as it doesn't harm the local environment then I see no problem. It's meant to overcome a possible food shortage and save lives, and I believe that outweighs the "OMG GMO EWWW" factor some people get all hyped about.

This was a brilliant video, thank you,, Anne! Not gonna lie, that natural banana with the giant seeds made me viscerally uncomfortable.  I worked in produce marketing for a few years and while I never viewed GMOs unfavorably before, I grew to appreciate them even more after that job. Genetically modified plants often yield more produce, they're easier for farmers to grow, and are (for the mostpart) just as healthy as their organic counterparts, not to mention they last longer. Either way, you have to wash your food with cold water before you eat it, because even organic food is grown with fertilizer, and some people think they can eat organic without rinsing first. The main issue I have with GMO plants is the corporate side of things, like plant patents, crops designed to only grow with certain fertilizers and pest control options, plants designed to kill bees, and other issues that have arisen due to large commercial farming.
Does anyone else here feel so good at seeing people link and search for primary sources to back their points? No? Just me?
I refuse to take part in the gmo arguments for the simple fact that, of the people in my life with firm opinions on the subject, roughly half have lived at or below the poverty line for most of their lives and support the fact that many of the gmo foods are within their budgets, while most of the anti-gmo sect (again, my personal life so this is not an indication of the wider world view AT ALL) have no problems partaking in their preferred (genetically modified) cannabis strains while speaking out against it.  I was youngish (4 or 5 maybe) when the 'the banana switch' happened, and according to my mother I went from loving bananas to despising them once they hit my store. Humanity has used selective breeding, cloning and grafting to modify every single vegetable and fruit we have today. Your mind would be blown seeing what fruits looked like even 2000 years ago. The fruits were tiny! Our fruits are often tenfold or more large, juicier and sweeter than they used to be. In some ways they border scarily close to genetically modified candy versions of their original selves. So GMO is simply a new technology to modify our food in a different way. It‚Äôs cheaper and more accurate than selective breeding. I haven‚Äôt seen any ways its more evil or dangerous than the alien monstrosities we have already have bred today. Nothing we eat is really ‚Äúnatural‚Äù anyway. Our farm crops are mutants bred for our convenience.
From my understanding, GMOs are the same thing as cross pollenating or graphing plants or breading plants. Something that has been done for thousands of years. GMO is just modified at a deeper level then in the past that gets a more specific result. But we already eat GMOs even in the "Organic" foods. As our ansesters would take seeds from genisus plats, AKA the original plant. These were plants that were geneticly different from their siblings that would make them not able to survive on their own. Thus ancient humans would take seeds from these kinds of plants. This starting with weet, as the plants that did not drop their seeds where the ones that humans could get to, thus they could plant them and eat them and have more control. So from the very beginning of farming, we have been modifying plants by propagating plants that otherwise would have died. Eating the plants, the trees that gave off the best fruit or grew the best potato, that plant would be the one that is farther propagated, thus making them better over time and modifying what nature originally created. So if you really want to eat "Organic" fruits and vegatables, you need to go back to the wild ones. Like the wild bananas. Likely how we got the ones we have now is, people would eat and propagate the bananas with the smaller seeds. This happened for so long that they no longer have seeds. So those are modified too. GMO or Genetically Modified Organisms have been around and created sense the beginning of the settled human life. We just do it more efficiently then our ansestors. They took 100s of years to do the same thing that we do now in only a few years.   I think it's more likely that people are and have always been afraid of change. GMOing the way we do now is new. Thus not comfortable. We don't have generations worth of experience as to how to deel with it, and so like all new things, we fear it. Now some GMOed plants might not be a good as there more "Organic" counter part, but as far as I know, it's not a lot.   As for rather we should or not, I think it would be better to create a crop that will help people more then it harms, then to not use it at all. If these new bananas that can survive this fungus, and preserve people's lively hoods then we should be using them. Or at least when the crop in one field becomes infected they can switch over to the new plant. I'm willing to eat a banana made in a lab if it means millions of people keep their jobs and in turn their lives. But if making sure you don't eat GMOs is more important to you, you do you. The chocolate and banana being microwaved is a step away from what we would do in scouts, where you'd wrap them in foil and toss them in the coals. Regarding the hack where you cut a wedge out of a banana and stuff it with chocolate bits: This is an old Girl Scout recipe. It's called Banana Boats. In the Girl Scout version, you cut the wedge out of the peel, leaving one end uncut, scoop some of the banana flesh out and eat it, stuff the trench you just made with chocolate chips and miniature marshmallows, put the banana peel back over it, wrap it in foil, and put it in hot coals in your campfire for about 5 minutes or so, just enough to melt everything. Delicious!

Great video. A fun thing I learned about seedless varieties of fruits like bananas and watermelons is that they are triploid. Which means they have three sets of chromosomes instead of two (or 4 or 6), the odd set means the chromosomes won't pair up properly during meiosis and therefore the plant is unable to make seeds.

GMO science is sound.  GMO policy is not.  GMO allows predictable changes (at least more predictable than artificial selection through breeding) and it allows changes to be made quickly (important in cases like this where there is a disease threatening a major food source and there may not be time to go through the iterative process of selective breeding).  GMO policy is where I have issues because the policies can threaten the livelihood of farmers due to the patent on the modifications from major biotech companies causing farmers who end up with "tainted" seeds (ie Farmer A planted non GM crops and farmer B planted GM crops and farmer A's crop seeds got fertilized by farmer B's plants) to not be allowed/able to use the seeds.  Obviously a workaround for the biotech companies would be to make the commercial seeds produce sterile crops through genetic modification, but I am not sure if this has been done to solve this problem.

....beeeeeeeeen-
Speaking as a graduate student in conservation & someone that teaches introductory genetics, the lack of nuance surrounding the GMO debate has to be one of my biggest pet peeves. People seem to conflate so many unrelated issues with modern agriculture & free-market capitalism with "GMOs are bad" when the technology - like electricity or any other innovation - is neither inherently good or bad. It's always a question of how people use it (e.g. nuclear bombs versus medical isotopes for cancer-screening).   I personally think that genetic engineering is an absolutely essential part of sustainable development, but I'm happy to agree that many of the current, commercial, uses of genetic engineering in agriculture are less than ideal (or even bad applications of the technology). Using transgenic gene modification to make your plants more resistant to the broad-spectrum herbicide you also sell, i.e. Roundup-Ready crops, is probably not ideal - or necessarily ethical from an environmentalist's viewpoint - but there are myriad ways that this same technology (and other, more modern techniques like CRISPR) can be used to promote sustainable development rather than reinforcing our dependence on pesticides, fertilizer, and water in agriculture.   One way is to integrate the gene groups from undomesticated varieties that confer higher pest-resistance and/or predator/parasitoid recruitment into our domesticated cultivars and reduce the need for pesticide applications. Another is to increase plants' drought resistance, and another to increase their thermal/UV tolerance to bolster them against the effects of climate change and reduce the substantial amount of water needed to make land arable in many parts of the world. Yet another is to optimize growth rates and yields to reduce the land needed to grow the same amount of food. None of these are hypothetical: all of them are being researched today.   Outside of agriculture, GMOs are responsible for one of the greatest breakthroughs in pharmacology/medicine availability. Know someone that needs insulin? Their ability to get it is largely thanks to genetically modified microbes. Before this was available, animal-derived insulin (mostly from pigs & cows) was our only source. Over 2 tons of pig pancreas were needed to produce 8 ounces of usable insulin - making it both prohibitively expensive for many diabetics and only available in small quantities - while today we can essentially grow it in a vat thanks to genetic engineering.
Bananas stuffed with Chocolate chips, mini marshmallows and a teaspoon of strawberry jam are wrapped in foil and shoved into hot coals is an old Girl Scout camping desert. (And we called them Banana Boats!)

And this is my thinking on GMO: when it's used for shit like Monsanto or to put a chokehold on farmers, forcing them to buy seeds when they could otherwise grow produce with seeds in it and use those seeds in turn, GMO is wrong. For the most part, though, GMO seems to do a lot of good. It's been incredibly beneficial, allowing for higher crop yield and allowing current foods to give more nutritional value than foods in the past did. Speaking of the past, we've been genetically modifying food for millennia. GMO isn't this evil thing that will hurt your body if you consume modified produce. Raise all the middle fingers at corporate scum trying to step on others and stockpile money, but don't boycott all GMO because some assholes are using a legitimately helpful tool for their evil enterprises.

We have now the technology to make GMO's even faster, and be modified to be more resistant, more efficient, be more nutritious, you name it. I find it amusing that with the introduction of advancements in technology to modify the genes in organisms, we started to debate if they are beneficial or harmful to us, or if it is a good or bad practice in a moral point of view, yet humanity has modified plants and animals throughout all of it's history without the use of modern technology. Through selective breeding we have changed breeds of dogs, horses, chickens, cats, cows, maize, wheat, bananas, apples, flowers, almost everything that we cultivate or use as livestock we have handpicked and selected their traits with trial and error. Our biggest concern right now would be that given the little variety we have in our produce and livestock we are at risk that with one little organism or change in temperature could end our entire supply of corn for example. Either cultivate wilder varieties that can survive infections (but we would need to change the supply and demand), or through technology, modify them to be more resistant, which as well, will have to be a constant battle with microorganisms as they adapt to infect more resistant crops.

So the ‚Äúleaf‚Äù that was used in the banana hack to grow it was actually a monstera deliciosa ‚Äòcutting‚Äô. The monstera deliciosa is a famously propagate-able indoor plant. This meaning that if you take a proper healthy cutting from it the cutting will root and grow from the cutting in just plain air for a good while. You can get yourself a full grown plant to put in a pot and will give you a health sprouting plant within a month. So in putting that in a banana and showing you growth it‚Äôs basically just saying ‚Äúthis isn‚Äôt more damaging to the cutting‚Äôs growth than leaving it out in the air... probably‚Äù

Most of the plants we eat had to have genetic mutations so they would be tasty, easier to grow, produce bigger yield, ect. That was done through selective breeding but the genetic difference is still huge compared to ones we see in the wild. Now that technology can change the genetics faster and more targeted compared to breeding, I see no problem if it can help people. Of course, the plants should still have to pass certain criteria so that the GMO crops won't have ecological problems when planted outside in a field and that any modifications won't have unintended consequences to the people who eat them (for example, some plants have been modified to make their own insecticide so that insecticide would have to be tested as safe for people to eat)
The opposition to GMOs seems to come from a mix of misinformation and unethical buisness practices from companies like Monsanto. They aren't bad in and of themselves, it's the corporations being able to patent specific genes that are unethical.

There is nothing wrong with GMO's. They are not dangerous, and can be used to great effect for both humanitarian purposes (such as with golden rice, with significantly higher nutrient content than regular rice, for poorer countries where rice is the main food and malnutrition is an issue as a result) and in conservation (the American chestnut was basically wiped out by an introduced fungus in the 1900's. transgenic implantation has allowed native seedlings to survive the blight while preserving 99.9% of the plant's original genome...something which is impossible to do through hybridization.)   It's not even an unnatural phenomenon either. Sweet potatoes exist because of a transgenic mutation facilitated by a bacteria. A 'natural GMO' if you will.   The only valid argument to be made against gmo's is that it grants too much power to large food corporations to design and control future crops......however this still happens anyway, since plants from breeding programs can be patented in the exact same fashion. In either case it has nothing to do with the gmo's themselves, but rather the potential for exploitation.
I think the banana from the 60s that Ann talks about is the type of banana that banana-flavored candies based their taste on. Those candies are the closest we can get to that extinct banana.
*and that is why I have trust issues*
People that are anti-GMO don't understand a damn thing about GMO's and other agricultural practices. They are victims of the Non-GMO/Organic food fear-mongering marketing campaigns.  Humanity has been manipulating the genes of our crops and livestock since the dawn of agriculture, be it selective breeding, hybridization, mutagenesis or more recently, transgenic modification. There's so many foods that we have today that are the result of radiation mutagenesis, a process where we basically blast a crop/seed with radiation, see what happens and then breed the resulting foods that have the qualities we like. Rio Red grapefruit and seedless watermelons are excellent examples. Nobody says boo about those inaccurate processes but are suddenly terrified of a scientist switching genes on or off with significantly more precision.    GM crops literally save millions of lives every year through food security and earnings by creating drought resistant/pest resistant/disease resistant/more nutritious crops.  I firmly believe being anti-GMO comes from a place of both ignorance and privilege.  They aren't the ones facing starvation or a loss of income if a crop fails due to drought or disease. The world would be so much further along with perfecting Golden Rice and other biofortified crops if we didn't have ignorant, first-world Neanderthals screaming "Evil Frankenfood!" every time time a new breakthrough is made.

I think that the biggest problem with introducing the GMO banana would be the potential of the fungus mutating to be able to infect these new plants. This has been seen before in GMO corn, a corn was developed to repel bugs that ate it but the bugs then mutated to be able to eat it.
I am not against GMO crops. Most of the time this is exactly what GMO crops are, they target a few specific genes that make a crop more resistant to things like disease, drought, poor soil, and or pests. All in all making these changes does not change the nutritional value or safety of the food. It can actually reduce the amount of pesticides, herbicides, fertilizers, and water used in the production process, dramatically reducing the ecological impact of agriculture.  Now the truly interesting part to me is the prospect of creating crops that are more nutritious and or tasty. Ever had a tomato or watermelon with little to no flavor, what if we made a GMO that always produced delicious fruit. Or what if we could find a way to make a banana have enough protein and other nutrients to make it a full meal? Like Ann said people all over the world face food shortages and food deserts, GMO crops could pave the way to a greener and more food secure world.

A banana is not a fruit, it's a berry. Since the flower that a banana grows from only has one ovary, it is a berry. Also, the banana has more than one seed, and has the three distinct layers that all berries have.  Here is a link to my source: https://www.livescience.com/57477-why-are-bananas-considered-berries.html

Alot of people are actually unaware how much fruit and vegetables are genetically modified. Broccoli, broccoli raab, cauliflower, cabbage, Brussel sprouts, kale and kohlrabi are all the same species of plant. Orange is a cross between mandarin and pomelo  Grapefruit, banana, almond, strawberry, lemon, and pretty much all "varieties" and seedless fruits/vegetables are man-made. We‚Äôve bred them selectively to get the desired characteristics.

The Panama disease is actually why banana food flavoring taste different than your typical banana. The Gros Michel banana is the one we get the food flavoring from, and until the 1950s, it was the most common banana. The Panama disease wiped out the crop to the point where, by the 1960s, banana growers had to switch to the Cavendish (which was resistant to the disease at the time). The Gros Michel is still grown today, but no longer at the scale that it once was. [source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gros_Michel_banana ]

Something we've started making with zombie bananas is a delicious mild curry. (We freeze them in their skins to use for this and banana bread.)   For each person, you'll need 1-2 chicken thighs, de-boned  and cubed, 1-2 bananas, a smallish onion (optional), curry powder and cream.  Finely dice the onion if you're using it and saute it in a bit of oil until soft and golden brown. Add in the chicken and curry powder. How much curry powder you use is a matter of taste - I use around a teaspoonful of medium heat powder. Stir well to coat the chicken, adding a little more oil if needed to help the curry powder spread. Brown the chicken well, then add in the defrosted banana - you'll be able to scoop it out of the skin easily. Mash it up a bit with a spoon/spatula while cooking, then add in enough cream to make a medium thickness of sauce. Simmer to thicken the cream and ensure the chicken is fully cooked through. Serve with the side dishes you usually have with curry.

About GMO: Humans have been modifying plants from the beginning. Almost any fruit or vegetable you can think of has been changed in some way (usually bigger with more sugars). The only difference is that it used to take decades or even hundred of years. With GMO the results are achieved within a couple of years.

I knew wild bananas aren't edible. This came up in the debunking of Creationist videos which frequently make fur point that the banana is a sign of intelligent design because it's fully edible, wrapped, and easily opened by the hand. Scientist picks up wild banana, of which none of these things are true and it's mainly hard seeds, and says "This is a banana as Nature or God made it. You're looking at the banana agriculture made." A moment's thought would reveal that in natural fruit seeds are the major feature, and the monoculture of the cultivated banana is seedless.  That was a radical change, far more radical than a bit of careful gene-splicing. I think people do all sorts of scares about GM food, but it's done a lot to reduce poverty without releasing an unspecified plague (which we appear to have managed for ourselves because of the global village).
As a person from the Philippines, I'm so fortunate to have access to more than just one type of banana. I had Lakatan a few days ago, so delicious although a bit more expensive than the common Latundan. I miss eating those green skinned banana we called Baloy and my favorite Si√±orita, small but very fragrant and sweet. I've not eaten those two in over a decade.  Also, I'm pro-GMO. As someone who lives in a less affluent country, we really don't have that privilege to whine about our food. What scientists and farmers are doing is to provide reliable food to everyone and not just a select few. If they have to genetically modify an organism to do that, then why complain? If people can find a better alternative to feed the masses, then let's do that, but atm, gmo is the more readily available method we have. People joke a lot about feeding random things to children in Africa but GMO and similar food technology are actually feeding a lot of people with cheap food.
