When I was in Sri Lanka in 1980, a friend took me to his brother's banana shop.   Think a small wooden shack  into which you could just fit 3 people  and thousands of bananas of at least forty different varieties.   They ranged from cooking bananas as long and thick as your arm to what  in Sri Lanka are called plantains - not the same as our plantain weed - that would fit in the palm of your hand.   The brother wanted me to try them ALL and in most Buddhist countries it's very rude to refuse a gift.   I could hardly walk!   Nowadays I confine myself to the five + varieties I find in Footscray, where both the large cooking bananas and the plantains are available.   I would never touch a boring Cavendish.  Perhaps Ann you could do a food tour of Footscray.  Don't forget the Century Eggs!  They are delicious!

The most important thing with GMOs is to prevent the exploitation of the people growing them as with any other food. Genetics being copywrited or trademarked present serious concerns like when farmers were sued for growing copywritten crops because of crosspollination from a neighboring field.  The true concern isn't the science and growing some sort of zombie plant, it's corporations using it as another tool to drag more capital out of a market.

banane
GMO can be problematic, but not because of the actual genes being modified. Since the modified plants are much more resistant it needs to be sterile to not spread uncontrollably. It also gives the producing companies the advantage of farmers needing to purchase new seeds. The producers also have the possibility to make a pesticide that pretty much needs to be used with the plants, all of this gives them too much control and advantages over the farmers, and that's usually problematic.
The problem I have with GMOs is that when people mess around with genes, it often has unintended consequences. It creates new proteins humans have never eaten before, for one thing (and there is a theory that this may be one cause of the rise in food allergies around the world). The biodiversity of the planet is part of what keeps it healthy, and GMOs are threatening that.  The problem with the fungus is not bad genes in one kind of banana, it's monoculture...growing only one kind of banana everywhere.  If they grew more kinds of bananas, grew other crops amongst the bannans, etc., it wouldn't be possible for a disease to take them all out.

my take on GMOs...      substantial amount of our dna is the way it is because of horizontal gene transfer. a virus doesn't go through research and development, it just does what it does (and endogenous retroviruses for instance, although very fascinating from an evolutionary standpoint, can and do sometimes cause diseases).          at least with genetic engineering, we have the scientific method to investigate whether or not the changes will be detrimental. "GMO" shouldn't be a bad word, and i believe the technologies of genetic engineering will solve many problems.       there might be drawbacks; i don't know much about the lasting effects of round-up, but i certainly am wary of monocropping and massive amounts of pesticides on things, often very pervasive in the environments outside of conventional farms but i don't think we should blame round-up ready plants for pesticide overuse/ misuse, and i don't think we can flat- out poopoo GMOs because of this.  semi-coherent rambling? over.
Love your channel. Just wanted to say, humans have been genetically modifying our food since long before we knew what genetics is. Anytime a plant or animal is considered to be "purebred," it is genetically modified. Genetic modification is the selecting of traits we want  over the ones we don't, and we've been doing since the human race transitioned from hunter/gatherers to farmers/herders. This is basically my long-winded way of saying, no food is "non-GMO," and if there is a way to save BANANAS, go for it!

Maybe just one example for the spreading of misinformation unrelated to food: Here in Germany there are some people who are unhappy with the measurements being taken against the spread of Covid-19 and they don't trust anything the government says, some even claim that there is no pandemic. Recently a court in Lisbon decided that it was illegal to keep a couple of German tourists in quarantine on the basis of a positive Covid-19-test. The Portuguese judges argued that PCR-tests were unreliable and thus could not be the basis for restrictions of certain right like free movement. Somehow the information about the case came to Germany and the special media that the corona-critical people consume. They went completely nuts. They thought that finally they got official recognition that the whole pandemic is a sham. What those conspiracy websites did not tell their readers however is that the court ruling in Lisbon caused a massive reaction in Portugal itself. The whole scientific and medical Portuguese community condemned the ruling and said that the judges misinterpreted the two studies on which they based their judgement (they studied law not medicine after all). The scientists confirmed that yes, PCR-tests are valid and very useful to determine whether a person is infected with Covid-19. This vital part of the Portuguese debate never made it to the German public and thus this twisted half-version poisons the debate by critics spreading the false conclusions of the judges in Lisbon completely disregarding the scientific expertise. Misinformation and disinformation are a huge threat to democracy and we need to take it very seriously!
There's so much debate about GMOs and I think part of the conflict comes from them being lumped together as one homogeneous group. People tend to fall into the "GMOs are always bad" group or the "GMOs are the best thing ever group." But we should really look at them individually and also look at who is responsible for producing them. Some GMOs are awesome and will provide huge benefits to food production and nutrition around the world. Some are very concerning and may increase pesticide usage. And some of the things that corporations are doing with them are very shady (such as practically forcing growers to buy dicamba-resistant crops to prevent their fields from being wiped out). It's a complex issue.

GMO's are great. You can not say otherwise and claim to like apples, corn, strawberries etc... I grow the true species of strawberries one might find in the wild. Despite having a large patch of them they almost never bare fruit and when they do they're the size of pea. Wild Plums are great but good luck picking a ripe one; they change color, look fantastic.... but how they look has nothing to do with whether the fruit is ripe or not. They're also only about the size of a golf ball with much of that being the stone-like seed in the middle. I would never plant them again and am all for modern cultivars. Lots of other plants have similar issues and being bread into something more desirable is largely a good thing we should welcome in a changing world. That microwaved banana is a classic staple of just about every kids campfire/late evening barbecue party in the UK where the cooking was half just wrapping things in foil and stuffing it into the glowing embers of the bonfire.  You cut into a banana, insert some chocolate and wrap it in tinfoil then chuck it in the embers. Its hot, sugary and chocolatey (very good on evenings where a bonfire is necessary) and the banana skin helps keep it from getting everywhere when you unwrap the foil. Its unusual and you normally have one then stick to roasted marshmallows for every time afterwards.  Except the microwave bit just removes any of the reasoning behind having it in the first place. You know - weird food cooked in fire is fun. And when its cold you find any hot food is that much more tasty.

I live in Brazil and here we have many different kinds of bananas. Easily in the market you can find  banana "nanica" (Cavendish), "ma√ß√£" (apple banana, with a slight  sour taste) prata (silver banana, which grows very tall). Banana da terra is a variety to be eaten cooked, fried and makes a delicious pur√©e.  We have also the banana ouro (golden banana), a delicacy, small and very, very sweet, my favourite. I have Cavendish and banana-ouro in my garden, so I can let them ripe naturally. Now I know why hey taste so much better than the ones from the supermarket!

There is nothing wrong with GMOs. It is a term used as a scapegoat for unsustainable agriculture practices like monoculture. Banana plantations, corn fields, palm plantations, coffee, cacao, tea, beef, etc are more detrimental to the environmemt than a GMO. There are more sustainable options - coffee grown in shade, beef raised locally, avoiding products with palm oil. I will never have freshly ripened bananas unless i live somewhere tropical, and that's probably for the best - i love bananas. I found a grower in Hawaii that grows several varieties of bananas and I had no idea so many types existed. Small, big, red, tall, short...
Guys- banana smore's exist and they are really good! We make them when we go camping. All you do is take a banana, slice it open, stuff it with mini chocolate chips and mini marshmallows, wrap them in foil and put it in the fire for ~20 min (flip once). The sugar in the marshmallows caramelize the banana and the chocolate adds a great sweetness.

about the end: lots of people confuse GMOs (genetically modified) with Growth Hormones that were used in meat production. if we didnt have modified genetics, we wouldnt have edible sweet corn or huge watermelons. and when they modify plants like that, people like to picture an evil scientist with a huge syringe, when really hes most likely taking a cutting off one plant and splicing it onto another one with a rubber band until it grows. its deceivingly simple. so yeah, GMOs are one of the best things to ever happen to food and even more so if it can save entire plantations that take up huge majorities of export in central and south america and the rest of the world. i really appreciate it being brought up here in such a nice way!

The reason most banana flavored candies don't taste like banana like we're used to is because they are flavored to taste like the old breed of banana that was the most popular before being almost completely wiped out by that fungus. The old breed isn't currently commercially viable due to the fungus, but I don't think it was completely wiped out, it'd be interesting to see if that breed could also be revived using the wild banana genes and if we could see the commercial return of a banana that tastes like banana candy

GMOs in and of themselves are not bad. However, like most things, capitalism has a tendency to exploit it. For example, this modified banana might help solve a lot of food issues, but if the only person you can but seeds from is Monsanto, then they have created a monopoly (as you cant go back to the old ones due to new machines only working with the GMO version).

imo GMOs can be a good thing but from the farms I've visited, specially in brasil where we live off of exports and large-scale farms, the trouble with them is that the seeds are controlled by these large-scale producers and the smaller ones basically have to pay way too much for the plants and can't compete, and are forced out of the business or to rent out their land to large agro-industrial corporations.  These banana producers you've shown in the video aren't great for the locals, the employment they generate is low-pay and has terrible conditions and the food shortage could be avoided by diversifying local production in smaller scale instead of having massive amounts of land dedicated to only bananas... Those are my two cents  Obviously GMOs could really help out with exporting bananas so they are good for the people who like buying them at the store and the large producers make a profit, more than the people who plant them themselves

In high school I took an environmental science class where we had a huge debate on GMOs. The biggest concern to have about GMOs in plants is that there is less genetic diversity in them. A disease could easily sweep through the area where genetically modified plants are grown and wipe them out. Despite this, our class agreed that plant GMOs were not that bad because they help economies, food shortages, etc.

In my opinion, genetic modification of organisms is a totally useful and save tool to solve problems. What you change in the organisms and with which purpose is a completely different question. It should much more important to discuss each GMO project individually instead of GMOs in general. On one hand, there are plants which where genetically modified in a way that they grow with less water or that they are resistant against larvae, so you do not need to apply insecticides. On the other, there are herbicide resistant GMOs and I personally find the idea behind this not very sustainable, thinking of the soils and the environment loaded with herbicides. It's just not compable.

People who are against GMO are ridiculous. They seem to be under the misconception that GMO foods are somehow bad for you or have less nutritional content than non-GMO foods even though there is absolutely no evidence to support that. Genetic modification is important because it's what keeps crops alive and their yield high. We've done this for literal centuries through cross-breeding and only recently have developed a faster method by irradiating seeds to induce mutations in the plants and then cross-breeding the ones that gain beneficial mutations. In fact, you could say that bananas even as they are now are technically genetically modified, since they were bred to have tiny seeds as opposed to wild bananas which have huge seeds.

GMO's - I think we tend to focus the debate on ecological threats (which are important), but there are also very big problems around the social + economical consequences of GMOs. They can lead (and commonly do) to serious food sovereignty issues, where farmers who were independent (at least for their inputs, not from a market price perspective) suddenly become dependent on outside providers of seeds (and often also on matching fertiliser and pesticide products, since the giant chemical companies are into buying up seed companies these days). It also leads to diminishing levels of biodiversity, which makes ag systems less able to resist change or stressors (the Panama disease being a prime example of what happens when you have a huge crop of clones (no genetic variability): a disease that kills one plant then rapidly kills them all. That problem is fundamental - creating a GMO resistant against the current strain can buy time (which is important), but it's likely that somewhere in the world, in a giant banana plantation, some form of the fungus (or some bacteria, fungi or insect) will mutate and, if it can kill one plant... it's the same story. Genetic diversity means the dangerous mutant does not exponentially get to grow its numbers. It's very important.

My greatest concern with Panama Disease and the banana industry is a problem prevalent in the entire agricultural industry‚Äîthe desire to produce monocultures. The market demands large amounts of identical crops, and doing so is highly ecologically unsustainable. It wipes out soil fertility significantly faster and produces huge masses of genetically identical crops that are highly susceptible to disease (if there was more genetic diversity, diseases wouldn't be able to affect all plants equally, and it would be much more difficult for one disease to wipe out an entire field, or even, as is the case with these bananas, an entire species). Most staple crops, corn being a good example, are monocultures, and if the agricultural industry continues to operate as it does today, it's at high risk of allowing disease to destroy a large portion of our food supply very quickly. The current solution is instead to innovate more and stronger pesticides and other agents to protect these monocultures, which is even more ecologically unsustainable. Unfortunately, because food diversity and sustainable practices are more costly than spraying monocultures with pesticides or modifying them against every new disease that appears, capitalism dictates we use the more dangerous and more profitable route instead.  I'm personally not even against GMOs in theory and don't think there's any particular health risk to them, but I am concerned about how they're used for profit‚Äîfor example, RoundUp Ready plants, which are genetically modified to not die when sprayed with certain RoundUp pesticides. This forces farmers to buy these trademarked seeds from RoundUp if they want to use this highly effective pesticide, because it kills any other plants. Farmers can even face lawsuits for using seeds that have been cross-bred with these RoundUp Ready plants. Imagine the dystopia of living things being trademarked‚Äîand then realize it's already happening! The agricultural industry is a nightmare, which is why even veganism is not the best solution to reducing one's ecological footprint.  The best way to go is to get involved in local agriculture and invest in community farming!

I think with GMOs a lot of people don't really know much about them, what goes into the actual modification or how strict the regulations are on them. It's always seemed to me that some people just use GMO as a buzzword similar to 'natural' vs 'processed' and act like it's bad just because it isn't 'natural' or 'organic', when in reality genetic modification is just a more direct and efficient version of cross breeding or selective breeding.
One thing I will offer as advice for keeping bananas from going brown more quickly, from personal experience, is keep them away from cold & frozen foods while shopping & on your way home -same goes for temps whether they‚Äôre in your car/with you on a bus or at home.  I live in a colder country so I have to be mindful of what I put my bananas with & make sure they stay well covered with thicker reusable shopping bag for my way home (I use insulated tote bags, one for cold & frozen foods, one for others). One thing that I don't think has been touched on is that the reason why cavendishes are particularly susceptible to this fungus is because they're all essentially clones of each other due to selective breeding removing the large inedible seeds from that species. That's why if one banana in a plantation gets one, all the rest do as well: they have no genetic advantages over one another when it comes to fungal infection, so none will survive.

Speaking as a graduate student in conservation & someone that teaches introductory genetics, the lack of nuance surrounding the GMO debate has to be one of my biggest pet peeves. People seem to conflate so many unrelated issues with modern agriculture & free-market capitalism with "GMOs are bad" when the technology - like electricity or any other innovation - is neither inherently good or bad. It's always a question of how people use it (e.g. nuclear bombs versus medical isotopes for cancer-screening).   I personally think that genetic engineering is an absolutely essential part of sustainable development, but I'm happy to agree that many of the current, commercial, uses of genetic engineering in agriculture are less than ideal (or even bad applications of the technology). Using transgenic gene modification to make your plants more resistant to the broad-spectrum herbicide you also sell, i.e. Roundup-Ready crops, is probably not ideal - or necessarily ethical from an environmentalist's viewpoint - but there are myriad ways that this same technology (and other, more modern techniques like CRISPR) can be used to promote sustainable development rather than reinforcing our dependence on pesticides, fertilizer, and water in agriculture.   One way is to integrate the gene groups from undomesticated varieties that confer higher pest-resistance and/or predator/parasitoid recruitment into our domesticated cultivars and reduce the need for pesticide applications. Another is to increase plants' drought resistance, and another to increase their thermal/UV tolerance to bolster them against the effects of climate change and reduce the substantial amount of water needed to make land arable in many parts of the world. Yet another is to optimize growth rates and yields to reduce the land needed to grow the same amount of food. None of these are hypothetical: all of them are being researched today.   Outside of agriculture, GMOs are responsible for one of the greatest breakthroughs in pharmacology/medicine availability. Know someone that needs insulin? Their ability to get it is largely thanks to genetically modified microbes. Before this was available, animal-derived insulin (mostly from pigs & cows) was our only source. Over 2 tons of pig pancreas were needed to produce 8 ounces of usable insulin - making it both prohibitively expensive for many diabetics and only available in small quantities - while today we can essentially grow it in a vat thanks to genetic engineering.

Both are actually able to sprout in a glass of water but only if you get a part of the branch/root. I dont own a monstara but I do have a bunch of pothos so bear with me while I go nerd here üòÇüòÇ  When you look at a pothos branch you might see little brownish nubs on the underside, beneath the leaves. those are new roots (if given the right environment) but the Pothos leaf you used was only the leaf so it have nothing to create roots from. My opinion is that pretty much everything we eat is genetically modified üòÇ like all farm animals have been selectively bred, which is just genetic modification through breeding which is a lot more touch and go üôà the same can be said for the bananas we eat, their mother plants were selectively bred from the wild type to make it edible for us, then the bandana plants have all been cuttings of that selectively bred plant, they‚Äôre pretty much all clones. The trouble with gene based genetic modification is the uncertainty of the outcome in a non-laboratory setting.  Like animals being introduced to different countries, you think you know what will happen but then something you don‚Äôt expect occurs and causes problems for the indigenous wildlife. It‚Äôs fair to be cautious with genetic modification for things like pesticide resistance, where it‚Äôs a concern that it could become integrated into pest and/or dangerous plants of a the same (or similar enough) species.  But for things like this, ie resistance to a pathogen, it seems worth the risk to help save these banana plantations, and the banana as an edible fruit itself. Especially as I would expect it has been rigorously tested for issues in a laboratory setting. üòÅ

At scouts we used to cut into fruits like bananas and oranges, pop some chocolate inside then wrap them up in tin foil and pop them near the campfire. I remember it being amazing but I don't think I'd try it again using a microwave!
The GMO debate is interesting in the sphere of agriculture, where actually educated people debate whether or not introduced genes can influence the ecosystem by either 'contaminating' wildlife or by being horizontally transferred and just being able to wipe out the surrounding ecosystem, but I am sure that the policing of the borders of plantations to make sure that nothing gets out is very strict... The main issue I take is some people believe that consuming genetically modified plants will modify them too... Honey, I am a researcher at a university that studies bacteriocins (bacterial antibiotics that act on specific bacteria instead of just wiping out everything that our current antibiotics do), and do you know how big of a headache it is for everyone in the field to come up with a way for our bodies to NOT digest them the second they enter?... Our bodies are surprisingly good at breaking down the food we eat, not just in the stomach and intestines, but blood vessels as well. The genetically modified material has no chance of entering your cells and do any damage. And even if they did miraculously enter our cells, how will they insert themselves in our DNA?... We use a technology called CRISPR, which allows us to insert genes, but the genes used in the process are taken out, and the genetic material stays where it is. And even IF by some miracle you get the genome of a banana in some of your cells, the cell itself will trigger reactions that something is wrong and will kill itself (worst-case scenario that the body kills it, but even then the monitoring system of cells is pretty good, considering that new cancer cells appear in our body constantly, and the system does very well at keeping them at bay). You will not turn into a banana from eating the GMO bananas, you will just feel nice from eating fruit.

I think that GMO is something that is OK but needs to be completely transparent to the masses so companies do not abuse it.   People need to know exactly how the food was modified,  to avoid modifications for the sake of saving money or increasing sales that are detrimental to the fruit or buyers health.    GMO itself is not a bad thing.  Almost all fruits and vegetables we eat are GMO in one way or another: watermelons were originally tiny fruit and were almost all white pith inside with almost no red fruit area,  corn was very small and each corn stalk made less cobs, and the citrus fruits we eat today never existed in the wild.    The difference is that these were modified very slowly over time by cross breeding and killing those with undesirable traits while today we have the technology to directly tranfer dna and skip those decades of natural selection.    I personally would have no issue buying a banana modified with a gene to resist this fungus as long as I was told how it was modified.  If it was modified to have a higher sugar content,  or grow larger while being less nutritious,  I would not want to eat it.    P.S. -  if curious you can look up comparisons of wild corn and other crops to see how much we have modified plants over the years,  long before DNA editing was discovered.  Most foods we eat would not be available without the round about genetic modifications farmers performed in the last century or two :)

Thank you Dave and Anne!
GMOs are totaly safe and are actualy safer than the process humans used for ages, which is crossbreeding and importing.   Nearly all the fruit and veggies we get today are totaly different from what the wild plants looked like, because we crossbred the plants to make the fruit and vegetables better, bigger, tastier. We basicaly took the process of Evolution and played with it, we killed off the strands we did not like and kept the ones we did. You can also splice plants with a different strand of the same species and it makes a hybrid of a sort that grows different stuff than the plant would normaly grow, everyone with a garden who ever grew any fruit knows this process well as its used often to make the tree grow the right kind of fruit you want to. You can even make an apple tree that grows several kinds of apples on different branches.   Why is this more dangerous than GMOs? Because its less controlled. You dont know exactly what wiping out a strand of apples, for example, could do. Insects depend on plants and plants depend on insects, changing the plants for a totaly different one just because it has better yield (hence why we only have cavendish bananas and all other strands are almost wiped out) could change the entire ecosystem. Also, with this process, it can make a "retarded" strand that is so crossbred (like the noble lines of Europe or purebred dogs) that it causes other problems. This Cavendish thing is the exact thing I am talking about, we crossbred bananas until we made the ultimate perfect banana fruit. Then we only started planting these, because they are the best with best yield, people will pay more for these and you can earn more money to feed your family. Now, a fungi which only targets the canvendish is out there and it could wipe it all out. And we have no alternatives, because all other kinds of bananas are looooong gone.   How are GMOs better? We cracked the genes and we can therefore make a custom plant that works better in every way. Instead of culling the strands and influencing evolution, we create a new genome from genes where we already know what they do. Exactly what the professor did, he took the gene that makes the wild banana resistant to the fungi and spliced it into the genome of the Canvedish. Now, we know how the cavendish grows, we know all about the plant, and we added just one single small adjustment to make it better. Replacing the old canvedish with this new GMO one only makes the plant more resistant while changing nothing for the enviroment. Its the same plant, just slightly different. Which is a controlled process, much better controlled than wild splicing and creating new kinds of bananas that could destroy the entire ecosystem, which is what we did for centuries via crossbreeding the plants.   Another thing why GMOs are much better, they can be made resisistant to all kinds of stuff. You could make wheat that is better in every way and you need less land to grow more food, less water to get the same yield and waaay less pesticides, herbicides and all other chemistry that makes agriculture so bad for the land. You would also better control the soil, make sure you are not depleting and destroying it (Which many of the tropical plants do) and therefore you dont have not make new plantations and abandon the old ones.   GMOs are basicaly better in every way for us, for the enviroment and for the farmers. Its only that they sound scary and scientific, so people are against them for no real reason. The best reason they can come up with is that "its unnatural". Well, so is crossbreeding. And we did it for centuries anyway. We could literally solve world hunger by GMOs and there already are areas where that is being used, the famous "golden rice" which solved vitamin A defficiency that killed thousands every year in countries where rice is the main source of nutrition. They made the same rice, just easier to grow with more nutrition and with vitaming A, and it solved the problem for the areas where golden rice is available.   Its a proven controlled concept that is much better than any alternative.

I know that there's a lot talk about GMO being bad but you hear that from communities that overlap with antivaxxers and pro essential oils so it obviously has to be taken with a grain of salt. The scientists who are doing this modification aren't typically going to be releasing a random food that they tinkered with hoping it's ok, there is research and safety that goes into it. Just like vaccines. This isn't a diy channel telling people to wrap bananas in tinfoil.  Of course there is the odd discussion about saviorism which has been applied to wild animal species. Extinction is often a natural phenomenon and has been for centuries, so where we are working had to preserve a species from the past that's not fit to survive, should we instead be investing in a hardier one for the future?

I used to be anti-GMO, because of the possibility of dissemination and the risk that with the existence of a very interesting variety of cereal it could become the only one cultivated. Now I think that GMO and agronomy as a whole are tools needed considering the increase in population and climate change. And that we should use science to keep improving the plants we use (for food and also for pharmaceutical active ingredients).

There's basically no risk incurred by eating GMO foods, and this is just one of the many situations where GMO provides an enormous benefit: fungal resistance for the bananas and not having to apply massive amounts of a new fungicide to protect existing banana crops.
Anti GMO people are usually living in super developed countries, and don't realize the very real and positive effects that GMOs have with respect to food security for people who rely on them. GMOs have increased food production in many nations, which has helped with both nutritional issues, and economic issues. Yes mono-crops have problems, and we can all hem and haw about big agriculture's moral failings, but at the end of the day, to be anti-GMO comes from a place of privilege, and verges on anti-scientific thinking.
GMOs are good. They are safe to eat and make our food more resistant to drought, pests, and bacteria. This incredibly important when we think about global hunger and how hard it may be to grow certain foods in different regions. Greedy corporations are the issue, not science.

(As an explanation about the cyanide, apple seeds contain amygdalin, which releases cyanide. There is very, very, very little of this substance in apple seeds, but it‚Äôs a big ‚Äòfun fact‚Äô that has been going around for awhile, leading some to worry about accidentally eating the seeds. Like I said, you‚Äôd have to be trying to eat the seeds to experience any major issues)

I think most people don't understand what GMOs are exactly. They just hear "genetically modified" and think "not natural" so its going to be bad. The fact of the matter is most of what we buy in stores is GMO in some way. For example, there's no way to sustain fruits and veggies that flat out don't have SEEDS and the solution is they produce the seeds in a lab, essentially. Another example: Tomatoes don't grow that big naturally, and if you plant a seed from a tomato you bought from Walmart or where ever its not going to grow the same thing you ate, they are modified.    Any concern for negative side effects of GMO products is something scientists are already thinking of and is figured out during testing phases. That footage Ann showed of James Dale is probably showing his process of testing: he's made hundreds of genetically modified banana plants and is testing them over and over to see if the modifications had the desired result, and to see if there are any unintended side effects. He doesn't just send the first modified banana plant he made, this is probably the result of years and years of testing.
Banana skin is not an UV protectant!! there are 3 sunscreen types, physical (mineral), chemical and hybrid (mix between the previous 2). There are only 2 natural,mineral UV protectants:Titanium Dioxyde and Zinc oxyde. those are also good for sensitive skin. chemical sunscreen can be irritating, thought it has benefits of not getting a white cast. However, physical sunscreen has been very well developed these days where the particles are micro sized, allowing for little to no white cast.  Clothing can also help, something tight woven, dark coloured is good for sun protection! although some are better than other due to stretch, wear and tear etc... But there are some special developed UV clothing if you are interested. but please whetver your UV protectant is, do your research, apply 2mg/cm2 every 2h and take sun protection seriously! melanominal suncancer is a serious issue and should not be taken lightly.

Ly
Personally I'm cautious about GMO when the genes are from wildly different organisms (e.g. animal gene in a plant), when the objective is to add or eggagerate a trait for profit that can have serious effects on native plants and animals (e.g. GM salmon and glyphosate-resistant soy), and where a private entity will own the resulting GM seed/creature in perpetuity (e.g. annual seed license fees and prohibitions on saving seed).  Where the genes come from related organisms like this wild banana gene and the papaya blight resistance gene and where the resulting crop is given/sold to people to manage without requiring continuing license payments (which was the case with golden rice), I think GM has a lot of potential to improve food security, health, and the livelihood of farmers.   I think GMOs are an area where scientists and the big companies bankrolling this research need stronger ethical checks in their selection, production, and distribution models. It's a pat routine now to trot out golden rice as *the* example of a benevolent GM effort as a response to criticism of crops that increase pesticide usage. However, calling up the good a person does is not necessarily a defense against the harm they might also do; a person's generous charity work would not excuse their drunk driving. I want to see more than one of these food security-enhancing crops, I want more recent developments than 20 years ago, and I don't want to see small farmers getting shaken down for license fees to keep growing food.

For the aloe grown in the banana, maybe they got different roots, but I also wonder if that's just how wet aloe vera roots grow. I fish keep and grow "semi-aquatic" plants off the top part, and the roots between my wandering jew and pothos plants are very different in the water and in soil. Plant roots that usually grow in the water are thin and pale like the aloe in the banana. When it's in soil, it's like the one you stuck outside. I'm saying the aloe actually grew in the banana since we don't really have evidence it did, but I wouldn't be "too surprised" if the roots grew like that in a damp/wet environment
Regarding GMO products, my opinion varies...  - If the modification is introducing a gene already present in the species or very, very closely related to the source (like here with the bananas), no problem. Mutations are unlikely to be introduced by this change alone.  - Plant->plant in general is fine, but cross-species laboratory modifications do make me a bit worried (allergies, unforeseen mutations).  - Animal->animal cross-species (variants are like the banana example, a-OK) GMO freaks me out, to be honest - and I am highly interested in genetics! Even wanted to be a gene researcher in the past, haha. If it's a gene that has absolutely no reason to be there by itself and was taken from another species (even if it's resistance to a decease), I get goosebumps.  -When we are talking about not just cross-species, but cross-KINGDOMS, oooh, that's real mad science, I tell you! Whose idea was it to take the anti-freeze gene from fish and put it into tomatoes??? My guess, which is purely unresearched speculation, the genes are actually quite similar in reality (and likely even the same 'variable' gene with a different 'value' attributed to it), but the very idea still feels so alien to me somehow!
GMOs are no problem for me. I've made a long research session on it before, and there is no real evidence that it is harmful for humans. What can be a problem is, that some GMOs are explicitly designed to be very resistant against many bugs, which can in fact can lead to problems in the food chain of certain animals. So for me, I have no problem in buying certain food or other GMOs, it just always depends on what has been modified, and the available research regarding this. Yes, it certainly is a good chunk of work to do that kind of research, but first, you'll educate yourself on the topic, which in fact everyone should do, and second, it'll help you put together a more healthy diet, since you start to really understand the food you've been eating your whole life. So for me, GMOs are totally fine, as long as they don't disrupt the whole food chain in nature.

I think the ethylene thing makes sense - sure its from the pulp, but the outer layer is water proof, likely there's a thin waxy layer on the epidermis because it does not need to breathe unlike the leaf, so unless there's little holes, gas will pass only slowly through the layer bc diffusion is impeded. but if you rip up a bunch of nanners, you open up a massive wound in tissue that allows diffusion far better, so more ethylene will diffue out of the bit until the area is closed down, but even the dried out tissue might be more permeable
i'm a student in biology, we study GMO a lot to understand how genes work and thing like that.   As you said, "natural" bananas  are pretty much un-eatable; since the prehistoric times, humans have selected which of those bananas had slightly smaller seeds, only re-planting the seeds of those ones. then they planted the seeds of the bananas that were bigger, and so on and so one, which makes it so through history and a selective planting, bananas became bigger, with way smaller seeds, and aquired some pretty good taste. That is, technically speaking a modification of their genes, so it is gmo. every single organism (tomatoes, dogs, horses, wheat) humans have interracted with, for thousands of years, has been genetically selected, and so modified. We are surrounded by gmos, which is not a bad thing.   Now, to speak about the laboratory-made gmo, which is way quicker : there are different types of it. The gist is "i can copy any gene and put it in another organism, trying to make it express the same things" :  - take "glow in the dark" gene from jellyfish and make it express in rat organs: now, you can check  what's the size of the rat organ without having to open the poor animal. That is objectively good, at least for the rat.  - Take "resist the disease" from banana A and make it express in banana B : banana B can now survive the disease, which is objectively better for EVERYONE involved (except whatever made the disease, i guess).  The problem is that some companies, like Monsanto, use this super cool technic to make stuff that is... not good.  -"If I make my apple tree super-resistant to pesticide, i can literally drown it in pesticide, and my harvest will be fine !" is bad, because then there is pesticide everywhere, which is both bad for the environment, the insects, the biodiversity, the humans that have to do the harvest, and even people who eat those apples if they have not been rinsed profusely.  - "If I make wheat that, even if planted, will not give any sprout, it's good for me because that means farmer cannot grow their own and have to buy it from me !" is very bad for farmers, and quite scummy.  - "If I make my pear express the pesticide, then no bug will eat my pear and i will sell more!" is bad because if not done properly, people will bite into a pesticide-making pear, and eat the pesticide.   So, be careful with big words like "GMO" ! Not all of them are good, but not all of them are bad ! The technique is very cool, and the biggest enemy in all this is people who want to make money whatever it takes, be it on the back of dying farmer. As always, Capitalism is the problem. ^^

The thing with genetic modification/engineering is that it covers such a wide variety of things, so that are good and some less so. And even long before the flavour saver tomato, seedless watermelon/grapes and round-up ready crops, humans have been genetically engineering foods through selective breeding. I think it deserves a much more nuanced look than it gets. That being said I do also understand the hesitation and scepticism around it and I think we should be sceptical, we should be asking questions about the process and motivation, but we shouldn't outright dismiss a good thing, like TR4 resistant bananas, just because they fall into the category of genetically modified.

Good job transgenics!  It's funny how people are so against "Genetically Modified Organisms" when most of what we eat is modified with selective breeding at the very least. Wheat? Corn? Beef? All selectively bred for centuries before genetics even made its way to the lab. The plants or individuals who have the most/most desirable yield were used to create the next generation. But the layman doesn't include that when they say "GMO". Instead, they are trying to refer to genetically *engineered* organisms.  And, truthfully, modified plants are actually safer than "organic" because they don't need much pesticide at all, which is good for consumers and the farmers who would otherwise be exposed to the chemicals extensively.  Studies have shown--and the FDA agrees--that there's no safety/nutrient difference in the meat between regular, altered, or even cloned beef cattle. (No, we aren't actually eating clone meat, the process is far too expensive and the purpose of cloning good producers is to have breeders, not the individuals we eat)
i think people would be less scared of GMO if clickbaity popsci articles would stop depicting it as a syringe of vague chemicals going into a fully-ripe tomato
All bananas are heavily, heavily genetically modified. Anyone concerned about eating this new disease-resistant banana due to it being a GMO shouldn't have been eating bananas in the first place. The trees that bear the bananas we eat don't even grow from seeds... they are grown from cuttings from other banana trees. It's why these bananas don't have enough genetic variance to survive a disease like this without a lot of human help. They all basically just come from trimmings of trimmings of trimmings (etc.) of the same original tree.
I‚Äôm going bananas
I think it's interesting to point out that the cavendish not having those big hard seeds is part of what makes it so suceptible to disease. In other bananas, even if they were suceptible to the disease at some point, genetical variation from each individual plant would mean natural selection would take it's course, and genes that can resist the disease would be favourably picked.  But cavendish bananas don't reproduce via seeds. To some extent, they're all genetically identical, because they're clones of each other, so there are no disease resistant genes to be favourably selected. GMO is, right now, the ONLY way to introduce disease resistance to the cavendish, and like you said, that's kind of a big deal.

The problem with the conversation on GMOs is that a lot of people don't get that technically everything we eat aside from wild-caught/hunted meats and foraged vegetation is in some fashion genetically modified. Selective breeding, cross-pollination,  and multiple other "natural" (read: not done in a laboratory) factors modify the genes of the organisms we consume all the time and have done so for hundreds or in some cases even thousands of years. Different stocks of corn, or apples, or chickens, or whatever else, had to be genetically modified to get what we have today, the process just took longer because we didn't have the technology to cause those changes with speed and accuracy.

I think a lot of people don't understand what GMO actually means, and that plays into the fear. GMO simply means a genetically modified organism, i.e. one who has been bred to have certain genes. Selective breeding is a form of genetic modification. Modern crops and domesticated animal breeds are all examples of genetically modified organisms. What most people are referring to when they fret about "GMOs" are transgenic organisms, i.e. ones whose genes have been modified in the lab.   The advantage of using science to select for genes in a lab setting becomes clear if you look at our banana here, with its susceptibility to disease. It's hard when breeding living organisms to breed for a single trait, because a lot of genes pass on to the next generation together. An easy to picture example is the modern dog. Basically, the friendliness to humans trait (genes) happens to get passed along with the genes for.... floppy ears! That's why many dogs have floppy ears, while wolves have pointed ears. Notice how it's not a hard and fast rule either though, because there's plenty of friendly pointy-eared dogs out there. Breeding has an element of luck involved. So when we get into the lab, we can take most of that element of luck and guesswork out.   Returning to the banana, sure, we could try breeding the wild one with the cavendish, but it will take generations to approach a desirable product again, with no guarantee if it will be palatable and take well to large scale farming. It would certainly never be the same. By selecting just the gene we want from the wild variety, we can keep our familiar banana around while making it hardier.   Transgenic organisms are a really useful technology in a modern world obsessed with productivity and optimization, and efficient production of highly nutritional food is becoming more and more needed. We have cold-resistant strawberries and high vitamin-A containing rice, for example. There are so many possibilities, from practical to wonderful. We can make crops that can grow in poor and polluted soil, or bacteria that produce medicine in large quantities. Or we can make wildly flavoured fruits that taste like other fruits. Imagine if we brought back the old banana flavour!

I learned about the banana disease back in 2013/2014 and the article was from 2008. The honest to goodness fact is that most foods are GMOs. Whether we‚Äôve inserted genes or specifically altered breeding of seeds, most mainstream foods are GMO. From what I‚Äôve heard and read, GMOs aren‚Äôt necessarily bad things. Most of them are like this new strain of cavendish banana where it‚Äôs been made more available for more places by making them disease resistant or stronger roots or harder for bugs to eat. GMOs have solved a lot of hunger issues throughout the world where there are droughts or strong wings that can destroy food supplies. I believe the cavendish banana is also a GMO. Most bananas in the wild are heavily filled with large seeds, but we‚Äôve modified the ones with smaller seeds to be seedless. I don‚Äôt think GMOs are the problem. I think that the processing of food and changing of how our bodies react to it is bad. There are a lot of buzz words around food to try and sell products. The microwaved chocolate banana is a common campfire food (at least in the UK). Usually you wrap it in tin foil then put it in the ashes of a campfire and the chocolate melts into the banana. We always did it at camp, some people loved it (like me) and some hated it, but I've definitely never heard of it being done in the microwave. I'm actually currently working toward a PhD in Genetics, so the topic of GMOs is really interesting to me! I can understand why some people might be skeptical of GMOs - it can definitely feel like a mad scientist's experiment at times. But for anyone who is worried about GMO bananas - think about it this way: bananas have more than 36,000 genes (that's actually more than we do!). These modified bananas are just like normal bananas, but 1 of those genes was chosen specifically by us. Also, before any GMO food makes it into the grocery store it would be subject to a bunch of testing to make sure it is completely safe to eat. GMO foods are safe and can lead to healthier and more plentiful food for the world.

Maybe we shouldn't encourage farmers to continue to grow giant clonal monocultures.  That's why these fungi are so devastating to all of our bananas.  If we actually encouraged farmers to use different breeds of bananas, and not ones that we have to clone to actually grow since cavendish can't propagate themselves, we could encourage a more robust banana agriculture.  All that's going to happen with this scientist adding the genes from a fungus resistant wild banana to our cloned bananas is that in 50 years, or less, something new will come along that will ravage the crop, and since they're all clones, it will spread unchecked.  The only intelligent way to stop this is to stop cloning bananas and figure out ways to grow genetically diverse plants with small enough seeds that consumers won't complain.  Or consumers will just have to learn to deal with some seeds.

Fun fact: Aloes are Xerophytes, which are plants that have adapted to the lack of water in their environment. Their roots are thick, allowing them to absorb water faster, and the thickness of the roots also prevents the loss of water.  In the video the roots that they glued on were not only too thin to be aloe roots, but were taproots (grew straight down). Aloes have adventitious roots (roots that grow sideways, just underneath the surface of the soil) which allow them to absorb water as soon as possible after it hits the ground! üòÅ

Poor Dave! Thank you for being the guinea pig! You're such a good sport about it, too!¬† Now about the banana and chocolate melted in the microwave - we've done something very similar to that when camping with Girl Scouts.  Take a banana, cut the slit/flap and eat the banana slice.  Then stuff the gap with chocolate chips, mini marshmallows, chopped nuts, shredded coconut, etc. just as if you were making an ice cream sundae, replacing the banana skin flap over the contents.  Completely wrap the banana in aluminum foil, shaping your foil in a unique recognizable form (like with a long coiled piece of foil, or a  flattened "flower" shape near the top) so you can distinguish it from everyone else's wrapped banana.  Then place over campfire COALS for about 5 minutes til the chocolate and marshmallow have melted. Remove from coals with tongs, unwrap, hold with a potholder or a bandana that has been folded into many layers and eat! The warm softened banana is a non-dairy substitute for cold dairy ice cream.  I promise, it really does taste good!

Genetically modifying a plant in this manner is very similar to cross-breeding. It's not like you're taking a gene from an incompatible species (like a fish or animal) and placing it in a plant, you're doing some of what cross-breeding does. Most vegetables we eat now were cross-bred or selectively bred based on genes they exhibited through natural evolution. I'm OK with this type of genetic modification in plants (non-sentient organisms), but not animals (or heaven forbid, people).
I think the apple one was done a bit wrong. I think the idea is that the ethylene from the bananas helps the APPLE to ripen faster, not the other way around. Also I hope I never see that wild banana with the giant black seeds ever again.

I don't have a problem with GMOs on the biological side, because it's like cultivating plants with a time machine. Same concept, but it doesn't take years of careful selective breeding between individual desirable specimens. It is true that we don't know all the consequences it may have, but that goes for most of science that is not immediately and obviously harmful. The only problem I have with GMOs is that as a human invention, they can be patented and that's a huge issue of ethics, distribution and money.

for the banana peel "meat", you're supposed to soak it in lemon juice and boiling water for a few minutes to soften it and get rid of the banana taste. as a vegetarian, seeing the way they prepared it made me cringe so much!! also, food waste is a real issue, so besides being tasty, eating the peel helps with that :)
I feel the topic of Panama disease and other kinds of bananas needs to be addressed more thoroughly. For instance, the Gros Michelle has fallen out of mass production but is not "extinct", there are several plantations for instance in Florida and you could even still buy them in parts of the USA. You also didn't mention the real issue with banana plantations: they are all clones of the same plant which is bred to not make seeds, which is exactly called Cavendish, and new plants are made through cutting and striking. The plant (which is actually really a herb) grows fruits which should contain seeds but they're sterile, and you can sometimes instead find those miniscule black dots in their flesh which are exactly the empty pod where the seed should've formed. This lack of genetic variety is why the fungus is so deadly, a population of genetically identical members is a treat for any kind of disease as if their cells simply can't fight this invader, then none of them can, and the GMO crop would basically literally be Cavendish 2.0. There are also a lot more banana and plantain crops that are not as highly commercialized (such as the many kinds of small bananas, which also have flavours similar to the Gros Michelle) but that exist and have very small/negligible seeds. Not saying the video is false but you sort of skimmed over a lot of important facts that should be addressed and that were left open and misinterpreted. I'm not a botanist myself, so people can better correct me if they want, just a lot of bits of information I found and looked up occasionally and put together. Got to fight misinformation!

I am very pro-GMO, but that doesn't mean I'm without worry. The main concern for me about GMO is unknown threats to the ecosystem they're placed in. Extensive research can be done on a GMO without being able to say with 100% certainty that it won't cause adverse effects to the ecosystem. As an example, imagine if the gene that was placed into the banana caused bugs that feed on the leaves or fruit to now be poisoned by it. Over many years those bugs might be wiped out, then the animals that feed on those bugs might be wiped out, then suddenly the whole ecosystem could be threatened.   In some cases, like this one where bananas being wiped out by a fungus, there is enough good caused by GMO where I think it's totally justified. But you also can't argue that it without risk.

They may have gotten the banana sunscreen thing from mushroom coral.  If you take it out of the ocean and set it in the sun for a few minutes it coats itself with a mucous layer that protects it from UV rays.  It is its natural protection for if it gets exposed during low tide or if it gets washed up onto a beach.  You can rub the mucous on your skin as a sunblock.  But mushroom coral and banana are about as far removed species as you can get.

All normal bananas have the large seeds. Gros Michel and Cavendish have been given a chromosomal condition called Triploidy where they have three sets of chromosomes instead of the normal two. The extra chromosome makes the banana sterile. They still have seeds but they are tiny.
Regarding the insertion of a rust resistance gene into the Cavendish cultivar of bananas, I think that many people do not understand what genetic engineering is, and are afraid of the unknown.  Almost all foods that we consume today are genetically modified from their wild type relatives, including bananas.  The difference between the genetic engineering processes of today versus techniques that are hundreds or thousands of years old is in precision.  In the past, if I wanted to engineer resistance into a crop plant, I would have had to cross (hybridize) different strains of the species, each strain having desirable traits, and hope that I would find a plant with most of the desirable traits among the offspring.  This process could last for years, and I could be lucky in developing a plant with a maximum number of desirable traits (e.g. resistance, palatability, durability), or such a plant might remain forever out of reach due to genetic factors (e.g. linked genes).  In the modern era, as a scientist, I would obtain a plant strain with the trait I want, identify the responsible gene(s), and use it (them) to precisely replace a corresponding gene in the crop plant strain.  Thus, instead of randomly mixing up genes and hoping, I can accurately give a plant one single trait without changing anything else about the plant.

Hey thanks Anne! I was doing a presentation on the benifits of GMOs in one of my college classes you just gave me another example to research I'll make sure to cite you as a research source too
I just finished my masters thesis about the safety assessment of genetically modified papaya and I have learned about how many parameters are evaluated in order to authorize the commercialization and use of GMO‚Äôs. Based on scientific evidence, I think they have been a great solution for so many of the problems that we face, like climate change and population growth.
I study environmental science and biology in university currently and have studied GMO‚Äôs for a couple years. My biggest gripe mostly involves the experiments conducted on animal species. One example being the Atlantic salmon populations that have been modified to add a gene from the Chinook salmon to promote a rapid growth rate. These fish are being farmed currently. I wonder about the possibility that this modified salmon population escapes into natural environments. This could lead to a disruption in native species given that these fish would grow faster and thus be able to outcompete some of the native species. Another example is Bt corn, corn modified to produce a toxin that will kill the pest species that feed on the corn. While this sounds good there is a possibility that it can also impact the environment, namely if the pollen being released from the corn will fall into wild plants and harm the insects that feed from them. With GMO‚Äôs I feel like they can be done correctly and with benefits such as the banana example in the video but precautions and analyzing must be done to ensure that there won‚Äôt be long term effects on both environmental and human health. There are actually multiple bananas that are edible besides the ubiquitous Cavendish banana. I actually like some of them MUCH better than the standard banana. They're just not considered as commercially viable at this point in time. In fact, when Ann mentions that bananas make up a large portion of the diet in many areas, I'm fairly confident that many of these are NOT the bananas you typically see in the store. So, rest assured, even if the Cavendish goes the way of the Gros Michel banana (which is rare but not completely extinct), there will still be edible bananas in the world.

I think a lot of people are anti-GMO because they don't know a lot about what it means so they assume that it's dangerous and scary. GMO is not straight forward or one type of thing because there are so many different ways of modifying different foods and for different reasons e.g flavour, colour and size enhancing, putting off pests and disease prevention and making foods produce certain vitamins for our benefit. Most of the time GMO is not only harmless but incredibly beneficial to us. People just need to understand it more.   If anything harmful comes about from GMO foods, it's more likely to be corporate greed instead of poisoning from the food. This is because once a company modifies a food it is now genetically new and different  therefore can be copyrighted. Farmers have to pay the company that created it for every time they grow a modified crop and many modified crops are made to not be able to reproduce naturally. Even if a farmer were to reproduce or clone a plant they could get sued big time. This level of greed could lead to people not getting food when they potentially could. E.g if the Cavendish modified to be resistant to the fungus is made commercial, many farmers may not be able to afford a modified crop.

I think the GMO issue is an interesting symptom of a condition of our society as whole. It's a technology that has so much potential for good but it also has some nasty caveats and ways to exploit it and even potential for some very destructive and malicious apllications so it, kind of justifiably, gets a bad rap. The problem is, however, that people are much more willing to criticize it and denounce than to actually learn about it and how it can be used to improve society. Almost all the negative attention that GMOs get is due to large corporations like Monsanto and whatnot using some terrible business practices that are possible because people as a whole, and by extension lawmakers, don't understand the actual source of the problems. Only when enough people understand the issue at just a basic level can society be improved by these technologies. I guess it applies to more than just new technologies, issues like global pandemics and the rise of unreliable news and information sources.   That's why this channel is so great. On the surface it's an Aussie lady who gives cooking tips and makes fun of life hacks, but Ann and Dave continue to sneak in a good bit of critical thinking and educational content about everything from the intricacies of modern journalism to banana supply chain logistics and I love it. If a video about fake banana tips can make you think about human nature and the challenges of a capitalist global society you're doing something right in my book.

27:25 Here's what I'll say: I've never spoken to anybody who was wholesale against GMOs who also understood what GMOs really are. There is nothing inherently bad about genetic modification. Most plants we eat have been "genetically modified", selected for different tastes, textures, growth rates, shelf stability, and so on. We just found a different, more efficient way to do it than generations of successive breeding and cross pollination and such. Absolutely we should be responsible when we're tinkering with genetics, but GMO foods are not inherently bad or something. With an increasing world population, particularly, we can't afford to be fussy sometimes. If we want bananas in twenty or fourty years, that's what it might take.

I honestly don't understand why some people are against GMO crops when selective breeding often leads to a similar result, it just takes much longer. Markers are used to follow the gene of interest and a line containing the gene of interest is continually crossed with the line that does not have the gene, until the gene is incorporated. With GMO, the gene is immediately incorporated into the genome of the organism.

Oh no, come on, Ann.  VPN's are a scam.  That's really disappointing to see you taking a sponsorship from one.  Debunking: data security and privacy. No.  Data security and privacy are protected by the https protocol that usually shows up as a lock icon in the URL.  Your ISP is far less likely to sell the limited data they can get than the sites that you're actually visiting are, i.e. Comcast isn't likely to sell your data because they can't get much out of https data but YouTube definitely sells your personal data regardless of VPN use.  Changing the location you're browsing from: No.  Used to be true, isn't any more. If you choose a VPN in Canada to watch CBC Gem or the UK to watch whatever, they both block ALL VPN traffic.  What does that mean? It means if you live in Canada and you're actually physically in Canada, if you use a VPN endpoint in Canada, you won't be able to watch Canadian region locked shows.  Customizing content from other places: No.  Your browser reports region data.  Unless you go into your browser settings and turn off region data, its gonna look exactly the same.   Everything they said was a lie.  To make things worse, companies like NordVPN and SurfShark don't own their own servers in other countries.  They rent them from the lowest bidder like everyone else does.  You're not getting an Amazon AWS instance located in New Delhi if you change to India.  You're getting a scuzzy, back-room server that NordVPN has no control over and who have and will sell and spy on your data themselves.  You really should have known this.  I'd rather see a Raid Shadow Legends ad than a vpn ad.
I noticed that for some time now, the tops of the bananas I buy in the supermarket are already wrapped in some type of plastic wrap.

Here's why I don't understand the hatred towards GMOs. Humans have been selectively breeding plants for years, hand picking traits that we think are desirable and guaranteeing that only those of a specific standard move on to the next generation. We have effectively been messing with evolution and conducting gene modification on not just plants but animals for centuries. The only difference is that it doesn't require science equipment. GMOs in and of themselves aren't bad, they just speed up the process. It's what humans choose to do in response to having GMOs, such as over farming, that are actually bad. If I'm wrong and the actual genetic modification does pose problem i apologize and I'd love to hear about it.

The topic of Genetically modified is very very wide. There are a lot of options out there. Different techniques, different plants, different adaptations. The problem is the majority is harmless. Yes it can be done in sketchy ways, as anything can be done in sketchy way. But there is a lot of research, technology and regulation in place to use it in the best ways and prevent anything sketchy. What it usually is is just manually speeding up the breeding of plants which has happened since people first started farming crops. A farmer might pick the seeds of crops that grew faster op produced bigger fruits and use the seeds for their next harvest. We do the same now, we just use different more developed tools now.
The banana we are used to is already genetically modified, only by breeding. Because seeds were bred out of the bananas, they don't reproduce this way, rather we propagate them. This results in less genetic variety in the plantation and thus no banana plant (of a variety that we want) can evolve that may be resistant to funghi.
A lot of the issue with GMOs comes from monoculture GMO, which is what causes there to be no variety of breeds and then one disease wipes them all out.  GMOs also wipe out all the wild plants of that variety.  You can have this same issue with non-GMO and the potato famine in Ireland and the problem with the bananas are great examples of what happens when you don't grow crop variety.  I hope this problem they are having will help them to branch out into either more varieties of bananas or just a variety of food in general.  I certainly know I don't want 25% of my diet to consist of literally only one food.  Not even "fruit" in general, but literally just one specific fruit.  Yikes.  I also don't mind paying more for bananas in stores - they are dirt cheap right now - so that farmers can continue to make a living off of their crops as their fields dwindle or if some plantations have to switch to growing something else.  I support farmers doing what is good for them AND the plants they farm, not just what is going to give consumers cheap produce.

November is the month my mother, sister, and I traditionally bake several batches of banana nut bread.  When going out to buy bananas, I'm always disappointed and a bit annoyed that grocery stores remove their brown (ripe) bananas and only allow the green and yellow ones to stay on the shelf.  When it comes to baking, the riper the banana the better.  Because of this, i often have to buy the bananas at least two weeks in advance to make sure they're ripe enough.  To speed the ripening process up, over the last two plus decades I have always closed them in a paper bag with an apple. I've done some literature studies on panama disease. The strain of the fungus that wiped out bananas in the 50s (strain T3) still infects most of the soil in banana plantations today, its just that the Cavendish is resistant to that strain. Its the reason we switched to the Cavendish even though its less flavourful than its predecessor (as a side note, "artificial" banana flavour is accurate to bananas before the 50s, and we didnt bother to change the artificial banana flavour to match the Cavendish). Switching to a new banana thats resistant to the new T4 strain is the most viable solution we have right now. GMOs are only about as dangerous as any other selectively bred organism, so i dont see why not use the modified Cavendish.
worth remembering with regards to being anti GMO bananas, that bananas themselves as we know them were created by human selective breeding, which is basically like doing "acoustic" GMO haha.

The Monsanto GMO debate from the farmer's view: Yes, the GMO seeds produce a better crop. However, some seeds are modified to grow their own pesticides or - worse! - the only pesticide you can use is sold by Monsanto; their seeds are engineered to withstand that specific mixture. The Monsanto seed plants will produce their own seeds. However - again! - these plants are modified so that their seeds are sterile; you have to buy new seed every year. There are other companies that offer GMO seeds, but Monsanto rose to infamy in the 90s due to its asinine business practices.

If I remember correct, the main hang up with GMO crops is that they can be patented (not sure if that is the right term) by big companies. And, there have been cases where accidental cross breeding lead to lawsuits between them and smaller farms, which can cripple competition. Correct me if I am wrong though.
Cavendish bananas are already HIGHLY genetically modified from a seedy wild banana, just through selective breeding, grafting etc., instead of more modern gene-splicing methods. There's no evidence-based reason to think modern GMOs are dangerous, outside of potential allergens being found in new foods (like if a species is crossed with a peanut, for example)  but that kind of thing is rigorously tested for. Most of this fear around GMOs could be eliminated by simply educating people on them...   TL:DR: Bananas are already GMO, what does it matter if they do a little gene-spicing on top of it?

Non-GMO farming - cross breed plants for generations and generations until you get the features you are looking for.  GMO - make the changes in the lab and do it quickly.  Basically the same process, but quicker. I have no issues eating GMO foods. Ok.. people who don‚Äôt like Genetically modefied food.. like come on. Especially here when it saves live u are just being stupid,
GMOs have a lot of benefits such as have increased crop yields via more efficient crops, less pest damage and safer storage.  They have also been used to fortify them with vitamins/nutrients not naturally found in the plant so that more nutrient deficient populations have access to them.  Nonetheless, the real issue with GMO plants is they imply a monoculture (as they spend so much time developing one specific seed, they would only use it some small parts of the field, but the entire part).  Monocultures are bad because they decrease the genetic diversity of the crop, which decreases the resilience, since if the one crop you have does not have the trait to combat the new issue, the entire crop yield is compromised (think the Irish potato famine of the 1800s).

I know bannanas and avacado both ripen more quickly is they are stored without airflow. When you stack back stock of banana for sale you are recommended to stack them in a staggered fashion so the get maximum air flow. It also lowers the chance of errant moisture causing mildew .   When we receive avacados you store them staggered if you want to try and keep them from ripening as quickly and you cover them with plastic bags if you need them ripe very quickly.   I hated managing produce at my old job because avacados are a waste nightmare. If you run a store with a small turnover you cannot order enough of them to have nice avacados out on the floor. They are either baseball hard or ruined. I probably threw out about 30lb of avacados after every 3 or 4 days.

So many comments promoting the fallacy that gmo‚Äôs are the same as selective breeding.  Yes, selective breeding has been going on for ages. But selective breeding within a family/species is very different from crossing and splicing genes from different families/species. There are many unintended consequences as genes from different species were not designed to go together.

GMO is said to be harmful because there's some sort of mutation in the genes. When the genetic cells are modified, the cells could change, added, decreased, or dissapear, this create some mutation in the genes. I asked my biotechnology friend who learned molecular biology, she said that the altered genes could become somatic cells and gamet cells that could create cancer cells in the body, and there's a possibility of this happening. But the possibility of this happening is relatively small and more study is needed to understand this matter. My friend also said that GMO products could impact the ecosystem stability, creating new and harmful diseases. The understanding and acceptance of GMO is different in places like europe and america, according to my uncle who works in the food industry. So really, there's still more study needed to understand the impacts of GMO to our health. But changes like these are needed to prevent crops and other produce from extinction like the banana. Truthfully i'm a bit torn on GMO products, some say it's bad, some say it's not.

The anti-gmo sentiment makes me so upset. There are a lot of food security, nutrition related GMO advancements, but there's a lot of what I view as misguided opposition to even testing some crops on a wider scale, and unjustified fear from lack of understanding of GMOs. GMOs have been around since humanity started planting crops--it's called selective breeding--we just do it faster now.  That said, the question of dependency on big agri-business is one thing, but even without GMOs, that problem still exists...So I don't think it's a valid reason to disallow GMOs entirely.
The GMO fear is really an unfortunate result of the diet industry and how fast misinformation spreads--and maybe the growing mistrust of science as well. At the end of the day, GMO is often going to result in more sustainable and ethical foods, like with this banana situation and also the ability to reduce pesticide usage, etc, by making our food resistant or repellant to pests. There IS room for debates on the ethicality of GMO with how a bunch of GMO seeds will make it so the resultant crops' seeds are infertile (which is very bad for farmers, obviously, and creates a lot of unnecessary waste in the interest of making people buy more seeds from whatever company)--but not really on health effects.
I find Ann's video not only fun to watch but also informative. She encourages everyone to have a second thought on what they consume on internet and I really appreciate that in this overwhelming-information age. Keep going Ann!!!

In a case like the banana, I am not so much against adding a genome of a related plant. Usually, the modification is made to boost productivity and profit like soy beans that are used as feed for meat production. I am not able to put all that in one sentence, of course. But that is entirely wrong in my view.

i think a large part of the issue with such high risk diseases in food cultivation is that things are processed in such standardized ways and in huge quantities in unsafe working environments (yay for capitalism! /sarcasm). same goes for diseases among farm animals like chickens that live in close proximity to one another in unsafe environments. plus it's worrisome that foods such as the banana is mainly created in one variation, bc this lack of diversity in the fruit makes it harder to develop genetic resistance to diseases.

I think there's not a lot of clear information on genetically modified foods. Technically, isn't most food inherently genetically modified? It's been bred to be the most useful, the highest yield, the most palatable, etc. I think a better conversation is whether the food has been sustainably farmed. Obviously we don't want food that's injected with random things, but if it's not harmful, and if it's improving the plant's survival, then it seems fine to me!
