That wild banana triggered my trypophobia üòÇ Eewwwwww!
There's nothing inherently bad about GMOs. All of our food has been modified by humans in some way. Historically it was done through selective breeding. Modern measures such as transferring genes has resulted in dozens and dozens of crops that can resist disease and pests and have provided tons of food for people in struggling areas of the world.  When most people think "GMO" they think of forced mutation. Which was done in the past but hasn't been done for decades. That has some health concerns since the plant has a tiny chance to mutate something harmful or to mutate away the nutritional value.  But when you take a very specific gene and change it such as with these bananas then it's fine. At this point you're essentially artificially cross-breeding the two banana plants to get the result you want.  Hell, bananas are already a little sketchy since most cavandish plants are more or less clones of each other due to the practice of cutting branches and planting them to make more banana trees. That's why all banana bunches look so similar. And also why they are so susceptible to the fungus. Lack of genetic diversity.

The banana with chocolate in the microwave is very similar to something we used to do in Scouts. We called them "campfire banana splits‚Äù. We‚Äôd slice open a banana and make a foil packet around it. Then we‚Äôd add dessert toppings in to the banana. Usually chocolate chips, butterscotch chips, peanut butter, mini marshmallows, caramel pieces, etc. Sometimes we added fruit like cherries or crushed pineapple.  We‚Äôd seal up the banana and toppings in the foil packet good and tight and shove it in to the coals of the fire. Leave it there for just a bit, pull it back out and let it cool enough to touch. Then we‚Äôd open the packet, pull back the peel some more, maybe add whipped cream on top and use a graham cracker as a scoop to eat the resultant gooey mess.   It was really good and and really fun because we could all make it however we wanted. I highly recommend it.

"GMO" is a bit like "vehicles." There's a lot of difference between the free-at-point-of-use minibus that runs up and down a valley twice a day two days a week so the people there can get to the big towns for the services there and the hundred SUVs, Hummers and Range Rovers parked nose-to-tail along the "KEEP CLEAR" markings outside the school to save the precious little snowflakes from having to walk 300 metres from home to bus stop and 50 m from bus stop to school gate. Likewise, there's a huge difference between GM "Yes, actually you can still produce food in this soil and climate" crops or GM "Yes, actually you can get enough vitamin A from locally-grown food" crops and GM "Hey, you should buy seeds from us, plant them, spray the entire county with glyphosate, get a harvest that can't be replanted and then have no choice but to keep buying seeds from us every year and by the way don't worry about the stories in those silly left-wing biased fake-news media glyphosate won't do you any harm at all" crops.

In regards to the aloe roots, succulents do this weird thing where if you propagate them over water, instead of soil, they grow those very pale, very spindley roots. It speeds up the root growing process, but these roots are less reliable than the thick ones that grow naturally. So I believe that's what they did, as opposed to gluing roots from a different plant on to it

It's not because of the disease, it's the method the Cavendish banana is grown. Hi Ann - I'm a food science student and I'm glad you brought up GMOs. I feel like the public badly needs to be educated on the value of GMOs. There are definitely some problems with GMOs, but most of it comes down to Monsanto being a shitty company, imo. GMOs can do a lot of good things and will increasingly become important as the world population continued to boom. Thanks for another great video!
Thank you for your thorough research and intellectual honesty.  People need more good scientific role models.  I think GMOs are a problem when they are allowed to spread randomly into nature (which they do now).  That's why the original GMO experiments were in Hawaii, to prevent the spread.  On the other hand, there are sterile GMOs, but people have criticized those because they force farmers to dependent on the companies that make the plants (because the farmers can't just save the seeds and replant.)  But for environmental safety all GMOs should be sterile.   I don't know how bananas breed, but would pollinators be exposed to the GMO banana?  You can't predict the effects of that.  There are, for example, insect-resistant GMOs which, in turn, breed GMO-resistant insects, which changes the environment in unknown ways.   I noticed a lot of people who call themselves scientific get upset when you try to criticize GMOs.  There's something fishy about it.
Any agriculturally produced food is technically genetically modified. We've been breeding plants to make them easier for us to eat for thousands and thousands of years, it's just now our technique is a bit more sophisticated. I take issue with it where it impacts biodiversity, but it's not really bad for our health.
GMOs are very complicated and it‚Äôs easy for us to say ‚ÄúI‚Äôm anti gmo‚Äù without understanding the whole story. There is a new potato gmo that has a decreased (or eliminated?) amount of carcinogens when deep fried at a high temperature (ie French fries).

Wrapping the top of the banana is something I swear I remember my family doing most of my life. Thinking back on bananas in my early years I feel like wrapping the tops of the bananas might be rooted more in the fact that back then, before all the Earth friendly conservation of materials and aversion to plastics got super popular, I remember banana bunches being sold in supermarkets with the tops wrapped in plastic; though I suspect that was more for ease of transport and stocking than for preserving them, since wrapping the tops would hold the bunch together and prevent those errant single bananas from coming apart on the store shelves or during shipping. So I can only assume my family, and many others, thought that wrapping the tops was for preservation instead, and started doing it at home themselves.

When dave said it's been along year. My heart hurt for the guy. Thank you for your service.
Anti-GMO sentiment is, as far as I've seen, almost exclusively fearmongering "what if" statements and people fundamentally misunderstanding the concept of Terminator Seeds (and also people seem worried about the impacts of GMO seeds in the wild so why would they NOT want farmers in the developed world where they usually buy new seeds every planting season anyway as I understand it?) and where they WOULDN'T be sold (places where the infrastructure is unsafe/unstable and so farmers need to be able to replant seeds because they can't buy new seeds all the time), I'd be happy to see someone bring a worry that's not "but what if it does this thing that I have no evidence that it'll do?"  Also, it's not like NATURE doesn't modify genomes every day, what do you think a mutation is?!  Viruses sometimes end up giving organisms DNA that is useful to said organisms, monarch butterflies and even humans have some DNA sequences that originally came from viruses if I recall correctly.  And we modify genomes through selective breeding.  It's not like there's any more inherent danger in specific gene-editing techniques, and I'd say that the less specific methods of modifying genomes are MORE dangerous, there are FEWER checks on the genomes of organisms created through selective breeding than there are on more specific gene-editing methods, I mean, look at the dog breeds, there are a few that have breathing problems because of human interference in their breeding, those breathing problems either would not come up in the wild or would die out quickly, but we keep breeding new dogs that suffer because of sloppy techniques in breeding and people being weirdly attached to a look that actually causes issues for the dog.  Imagine if we could/would edit the genes of those breeds so they could still look similar but breathe better, it'd be a boon for both people and those poor pups.  Personally, if a product had a "Proudly made with GMO's" label on it, I'd go out of my way to buy it, because I think that's the only way we're going to be able to continue making safe, reliable food in a world we're constantly screwing over and changing so that our own crops struggle, and in a world where diseases are constantly evolving and have such a quick life-cycle, thus giving them more mutations in a shorter time span.

There is nothing at all wrong with eating GMO plants.  Humans have been altering the genes (in one way or another) of the food they eat for millennia.  Genetically modifying our food plants can increase yield, increases the nutritional value, cut down on pesticide use, allow for a greater range of growing locations/conditions, and even prevent the extinction of a species.

I'm far more comfortable with genetically modifying a crop to resist a fungus than I am modifying a crop just to look more appealing, as in plumper redder strawberries, usually at the cost of flavor.  That sort of modification is really more about getting consumers to buy the produce instead of overcome an actual problem affecting the crop and livelihood of those dependant upon said crop.  I think this is a good use of Genetic modification.

They want everyone to buy their seeds or close shop. Just one piece of information to add to this problem with banana fungus: the reason that happens to banana productions is largely due to the way we bred them to get to where they are today, that is this nearly all flesh and sweet fruit. That made these bananas seedless, since those black spot inside are not functional seeds. So to make  more trees the farmers have to get parts of another plant and put it on the soil to grow into another producing banana tree. On doing that, we get to a point where whole plantations of banana are basically a clone farm, with each individual plant having the same genetic code os the others. That's why a single disease affects so much of the production, since, if one plant is vulnerable, they all are. That is why you see the researcher introducing genes from another species of banana, because that is the only way to get resistant plants. In a normal population of a plant or animal species, a few of the indivicuals might be resistant to a new disease, so they'll be able to survive and pass on their pathogen-resistant genes.

All our food crops are genetically modified through heavy selective breeding over the millennia. The sort of genetic tweaking the researcher did in this case would likely entirely be possible through these traditional techniques, but much less accurate or rapid.

Literally a billion people.

I don't mind GMOs. If they make the food safer to eat, healthier and more nutritious, and/or make the plant more resistant to diseases, I say go ahead. People don't want dangerous chemicals in their food and GMOs can help with that since GMOs are genes from other plants. GMOs can also reduce the need for pesticides, which is also nice. It's a balancing act. While people hundreds of years ago had to breed and select crop to grow based on traits they saw, we can do that much faster with how they make these _scaaaaaary_ GMOs. These new modified plants are rightfully rigorously tested, but they can do so much good.

Anti-GMO sentiment is largely a product of disinformation and lack of understanding.  GM is a tool, nothing more.  There are viruses in nature doing things like swapping genes around between species all the time, but somehow that random genetic modification is perfectly fine.  When we do it intentionally to benefit humanity, people get upset.  For comparison, nobody seems to care that the ruby red grapefruit was a product of atomic gardening (intentionally irradiating crops in the hopes of finding novel mutations) even though it resulted in a new genetic pattern that is transmissible.  Had that gene been altered intentionally, would it be any different?  How about selective breeding?  You're still hoping to isolate or find novel mutations.    If I grew a trillion rice plants and found one that produced vitamin A, propagated it and gave it to malnourished parts of the world, I'd be a hero.  When a scientist does this intentionally, inserting vitamin A producing genes into rice, Greenpeace gets upset and convinces activists to destroy development fields.  And no, the common objections don't apply here.  Just about every plant already produces beta carotene, so there's no contamination to be had in the surrounding environment, and no, Monsanto is not planning to license the crop to peasant farmers - they granted free licenses to the patents to anyone making $10k or less on their rice harvest annually (and they did so 20 years ago, long before anyone forced their hand), and yes, the seed is allowed to be kept and propagated.  People need to grow up, stop being willfully ignorant, and learn instead of being afraid.  We're projected to top out at around 10 billion people on this planet, and it's going to take something to feed them all.

It's 12:56 am and now I want to eat a banana, chuckle.
All bananas have the big hard seeds originally. The commercial bananas we get have been bred to be triploids (three sets of chromosomes), which leads to the seeds being unable to mature and thus the banana stays "seedless". The same type of trick is used to make seedless grapes and seedless watermelon. If you think about it, how would plants without seeds be able to fill the market if they don't have seeds that you can use to make more of them? For most, seedless produce, you breed together two plants with different chromosome numbers (plants can have a lot more sets of chromosomes than people can) so that you end up with the sterile, seedless version. I say most instead of all because some plants can reproduce by growing more plants via their root system and I think that is the case for banana trees but I'm not positive about that. So, if the resistant strain of banana has a diploidy version (two sets of chromosomes) and tetraploidy (four sets of chromosomes), then they could probably breed a sterile triploid version again. That being said, I think GMO's are fine and the fear surrounding them is mostly due to people not knowing what they are or what their purpose is, along with the spread of misinformation.

May I offer a banana hack that does work?  If you take a banana that is completely green (not due to turn yellow for a week or so) and wrap it, overnight, in a paper bag, it will turn yellow in a day or so.

Well, actually the banana that was "wiped out" by Panama disease in 1950s was not exactly wiped out from the face of the earth. It is just not cultivated for export anymore and replaced by cavendish banana. This type of banana, however, is alive and well in places where it is naturally grown, like Indonesia (and I believe some other Southeast Asian countries). In Indonesia it's known as pisang ambon (which funny enough also a name of a type of liquor in The Netherlands). Pisang means banana, by the way. I personally like the taste of pisang ambon much better than cavendish. I find cavendish banana very bland. But I guess being in Indonesia we are blessed with many different type of bananas that taste good and we don't have to import (I am sure people in several other Southeast Asian countries can say the same) so I don't have to eat cavendish banana. Fun fact: the earliest evidence of domesticated banana from wild variety (as Ann said, wild banana have seed while domesticated ones are not) is from the island of Papua New Guinea. I am from the island of Java, and now that I live in West Papua I discovered types of banana that I didn't even find in Java, and they are all good!
Also, just want to say a big THANK YOU Mrs. Ann for dedicating your time to educating people. It is so important to have the correct information about things. And with the internet being bombarded with misinformation in pretty much every topic known to man, you are a breath of fresh air! Keep it up!
GMOs have saved people's lives! Crops like golden rice that have been modified to contain vitamin A has helped stop so many people develop eye problems in places where they don't have access to more nutrient rich food. GMOs are great people are just scared of things they don't understand
I'm a biologist, and i want to congratulatz you for bringing the topics of gmo and banana disease and i want  to complement/coment somethings: -The thing is the variant banana we eat are all genetic clones, they dont have seads, so they are reproduced by assexual means, that does't produce genetic diversity. What this means in this case as that all bananas plants has the same suceptibility for disease. So when one new disease they are suceptible appears, all bananas trees  in the world will be sucetible to get sick and die.  About the GMO, is a complex assunt, and im not specialisty but i did an article about it when i was studying in USA: Generally, GMO are safe and heavy tested before going to fild, usuaaly the problems are not directed relacted with the technology itself but how we use it. For example herbicide resistent corps are byitselft usually safe, but is common to farmers use a lot more herbycide when using it and they are dangerous. Or some answrts to enviromentla concers created new social problems, like farmers not being able to stck seads to cultivate the plants next season and needing to buy all again.  What i mean is if your contry has solid health regulation and fiscalization, GMOs probably are going be fine: they are heavy tested before going comercial so allergies and health problems are ussualy discovered a long before they went to the market. We shouldn't ban the tecnoogy all together,  GMOhas a lot of potencial, but we  DO need to regulate with more care how the technology are implantected, because most of thir social,enviromental and health impacts are caused by secundary means ( what we called the tehcnology web).

GMO is not good or bad. It's all in how its used. The bad reputation comes from corn which in the US most GMO corn is classified as a pesticide. They were trying to make it pest resistant and made it inedible. Unfortunately it is still used in modified forms. The second problem with corn is the patent. Again in the US a GMO plant is patented and owned. This means you cannot grow and sell the plant without press permission of the owner. Unfortunately corn reproduces using a pollen which can travel up to five miles. This pollinates non-GMO corn and farms which grow a portion of their crop for seed now have the GMO corn. The industries have been strong arming the family farmers and threatening to sue and take their farms if they don't sign contracts. This has lead to some massive legal issues int he U.S. and a negative reputation on GMO. It's sad because there are great uses of GMOs such as golden rice and the Banana which could potentially save millions of lives.
In my mind GMOs aren't that different from selective breeding. Yes, care should be taken when it comes to growing GMOs to ensure they don't hybridize with wild plants but that's the only real risk they seemingly pose. I feel like most of the stigma of GMOs arises from a lack of understanding and of the idea of what is and isn't 'natural'. No crop plant is really natural as humans have selectively bred them for specific traits and are thus very different from their wild ancestors. GMOs are just a faster and easier way of getting the desired traits into crops.

There's a lot of paranoia about GMO. Almost everything we eat has been "Genetically modified" by selective breeding. Modifying it with gene splicing is just another technique - yes, the results need testing before releasing into the wild, but the danger is hugely overstated. We just need to resist the efforts of some organisations to make GMO crops that cannot be bred so that seeds need to be bought from the manufacturer. Regulating gene splicing is good, but there;s no need to be excessively afraid of it as long as manufacturers are appropriately regulated.

The problem with GMO is that it conflicts with the precautionary principle. We don't know the long term effects of such genetic modification, because we don't have a separate world we can run trials on. When we have ran trials with such things so far, there have been loads of examples of cross pollination and the crops escaping into the wild. There've been legal cases about it happening, so a lot of trials get cut short or cancelled.  So, to a lot of people, there just isn't the evidence that GMO is long term safe.

I hate this misconception that GMOs are automatically bad for humans, because unless they're made by an evil scientist they're designed to be either higher yield, nutritionally enriched, or disease/pest resistant (less pesticides, chemical fertilizers, etc on your food, and look up "golden rice"). It's really just a quicker form of selective breeding, which has produced almost all our modern food crops and livestock. There can of course be problems with them that should be carefully considered, but usually this has to do with their effect on the environment they're planted in (will they cause a drop in insect populations, affecting the food chain higher up? Will they spread beyond the fields and threaten wild species in the ecosystem?), and not on human health directly.

I'm surprised! I grew up eating baked bananas with melted chocolate, I think its absolutely delicious!  Fantastic with peanut butter as well. It works better if you wrap it in foil and heat it in the oven rather than microwave, or throw it on the bbq/fire.
Anyone who thinks GMOs are evil (instead of certain organizations, like Monsanto, the bastards) should know that the untampered-with archetypal banana was shaped like a big, flat potato, had inedible huge seeds instead of the almost invisible ones the cavendish has, and they weren't really that smooth and sweet. Farmers spent generations making those, along with potatoes, onions, and pretty much everything we eat. The food scientists of ancient times did what they could with their tools, and modern food scientists are doing what they can with theirs. I promise you won't grow tentacles if you eat cold-resistant garlic! IMO buying locally and in-season are where your efforts should go if you want to make a difference. Cheaper, too.
There is a fungus that is attacking coffee plants, but the reason it is flourishing is the global warming. I'm wondering....
Am not opposed to GMOs but am concerned with the companies selling them, especially in places like africa. GMOs are often patented and farmers often have to lisence seeds and their use in order to be able to grow and sell crop. In certain countries in africa GMO companies have been giving away GMO crops and then issuing cease and desist orders years later demanding they pay to lisence the use of their GMO products.   Ive even read about a patented strain of corn (i think) being grown in america where a neighbouring farmer was issued a cease and desist because his crop had been cross breeding with them.

As someone who has a bachelor in genetics i want to tell everyone that GMO's nowadays are safer than ever before. This is because now the genetic modification is controlled while the first gmos were more random. That didn't stop the people then from actually making edible food which tasted great and there is no reason for it to be different now. Most fruits and vegetables we currently eat are not how they first blossomed on this earth. But they are the result of farmers interbreeding different crops until they get something better and tastier. Interbreeding of plants is genetic modification. Also we can't leave out the fact that without GMO crops we can't have crops for everyone on our overpopulated planet and we won't be able to have crops that are resistant to climate change. And let's all remind ourselves how much of a privilege it is to be able to buy organic and "non-gmo" fruits and vegetables

With GMOs, there is a huge difference between the idea that‚Äôs the genetics are changed chemically and will harm our bodies. That‚Äôs not the case it‚Äôs a form of DNA splicing , like copying and pasting favourable qualities from one set of a species /type of food to another. There is the more scientific worry of loss of biodiversity as the new genetic traits of the GMO crop as pollen is spread easily. However in the case of these bananas that‚Äôs a good thing as it means we‚Äôll get more fungus resistant bananas, which betters the community that there‚Äôs bananas a grown in as well as allowing us to keep the cavendish banana. Fun fact banana sweets are flavoured after the extinct type of banana and that‚Äôs why they don‚Äôt taste like actual bananas. I think we should just be mindful about GMOs and what the specific genetic change is for. If it is to fight against a fungus or bacteria then I think it‚Äôs perfectly fine to allow that plant to be in the open as the pollen exposure to other variations of the same plant species would be good. However other reasons we should consider further how they are grown so we don‚Äôt risk a loss of biodiversity

I don't mind GMO and I don't care about "organic" food. It might just be because I'm a programmer, if we just look at plant DNA as just code, we can modify them how we see fit, since gene mutation happen in nature anyway, so that's basically the same thing.  However, I am opposed making a crop too hardy, since it might invade the local ecosystem and disrupt the food chain, so counter measures should be in place in case of this. This in fact, is exactly how we modify bacteria and virus for organic molecule production/gene therapy. This will eventually be the future and I think completely avoiding it is futile, but we should open to the idea and regulate this so we can take more advantage of it instead of shriveling in fear if we just avoid using it completely and something accidental suddenly happened.

my family really doesn't worry about our bananas going bad, when they turn black they become super rich and sweeter than before so instead of throwing them away we just freeze them and use them in banana bars (a banana dessert) or smoothies we always have frozen bananas on hand either frozen or fresh. truth be told me and my siblings will sometimes let the bananas go black and freeze them so our mom will make banana bars out of them! XD  so don't just throw away your blackened bananas, just freeze them! they're awesome to use in baking and other treats like smoothies, makes them super rich and sweet without using a lot of added sugar.

I eat bananas almost every single day of my life. Here is my only one life proved hack that actually works.  Separate the bananas from the batch, if one rot they all rot faster because they are connected, if you just rip them apart they will rot "individually".  Try for yourselves.

The one about the heated banana and chocolate is actually a delicious dessert we eat here in Sweden! Often we prepare it for when going outside and playing in the winter when we are gonna have a fire.  We grill sausages and stick bread and then after we put the pre-prepared bananas with chocolate inside, rolled in aluminimun foil, down in the hot coals and let it melt and cook the bananas which we then eat with spoons. Delicious, don't hate! :D  If we want it inside we use the oven the same way, I've never tried the microwave.

everything is GMO - livestock, pets, crops, even us (not negligible part of human DNA is from viruses acquired during evolution). GMO bacteria produce huge part of modern medicaments and food aditives (insuline, xanthan gum etc.). there is nothing bad on eating GMO (enviromental impact is another story - large monocultures of GMO interbreeding with wild population is questionable), people simply dont understand it. we do GMO for thousands of years (through breeding animals and crops), only now we can modify the organism with great precision. it could solve many problems, especially in developing countries suffering climate crisis.
As for the banana temperature, 13-15 degrees is very much feasable in some homes. At least Europe (and undoubtedly elsewhere, but I don't know for sure), homes tend to have a cellar that's halfway or entirely underground, and is quite a bit colder than the living room. Even during the summer. So maybe store bananas there if you can.
Ah yes, Dave eating food is the reason I came here
On  the topic of GMO: I think it is important to remember that all our cultivated plants are bred and since breeding is a form of genetically modifying organisms, all foods in stores are genetically modified. There never was a natural grown sweet large banana, only  one with lots of seeds and little flesh that had to be cooked before becoming edible.  GMOs are just a more effective mechanism of breeding and I don't see a problem with them in general.  They seem to have a lot of potential for fighting world hunger and solving environment problems (e.g. depending on how you use them they can decrease pesticide need)  It is also important to note that GMOs get tested over long periods of time before allowed on the market.  However the topic is pretty complicated and entails a lot of things to consider. I just wanted to point out some positive aspects for a thing that is often painted overly negative
Thank you Ann, love the content, always well researched and so entertaining to watch! Keep up the good work ü•∞
GMOs are one of those topics where everyone can show off how little they understand about the genetical and chemical make up of the world around them. I'm a biochemist and manipulating genetic material is my bread and butter. We have to follow very strict guidelines to make sure everything we produce in the lab stays there. There are few things that are under such close examination as genetically modified organisms. And that is very good, as they could cause a lot of harm. But as others have already mentioned, we have been fastening evolution for as long as people have been around, basically. The only difference between picking a plant that seems to grow better than the others, and adding a gene that will make a plant grow better than the others is, that we actually know what we did, thus controlling it better. Monocultural agriculture is a massive problem. It lessens biodiversity to an alarming extend. I'm no ecologist, so I can't really make a statement on the matter, but people act like GMOs will eradicate biodiversity all on its own, completely ignoring the opportunities it offers. GMOs can be made to me more nutritional (e.g. golden rice), to withstand parasites, bacteria, viruses, and fungi, making the use of often poisonous herbicides and pesticides obsolete, thus helping to keep insect and critter populations healthy, which would actually strengthen biodiversity.  There is so much misinformation and fearmongering concerning GMOs going around, it's baffling me.

How‚Äôre they not sued for spreading wrong info

Hi there! I live in the Philippines and there are actually so many other types of edible bananas, though I'm not too sure which ones are resistant to that fungus. In our country the cavendish actually isn't our go-to banana since we have sweeter alternatives. The problem with those varieties though is that they have really short shelf lives so they're not good for export.
one of the few good things of being back to living in Brazil after 10 years in Canada was having access to different kinds of bananas other than Cavendish (we call it nanica); my favorite is the the pome banana (prata), which is less sweet, with a nice sourness to it.  I was sad to learn that this variety is also affected by the fungi =( hopefully the same method of preserving the Cavendish can be used for the pome.

The bananas we consume right now have a different genetic code than the original wild banana does, hence the lack of seeds (as you showed). All bananas, even the Cavendish have large hard seeds if they are allowed to ripen on the tree. That's why even the people that grow bananas pick the ones they eat when they're still green. Then they either eat them green like a vegetable, similar to the way plantains are eaten, or ripen them up to eat them as fruit. The only time bananas are allowed to ripen on the tree is to get the seeds to grow more trees.
GMO's are fine, with current science and techniques we can rapidly create new species of fruit and vegetables, yet little do people realize this is something that humans have been doing for millennia through selective breeding. That gross wild banana just shows how far humanity has raised bananas into something we find palatable.

The arguments against GMO tend to be based on misunderstanding and the assumption that 'natural' is better. The problem with that thought process is that the bananas we're eating now aren't natural, they've been selectively bred by humans in order to make them edible. The same is true with a lot of the food we eat. The nebulous term 'natural' and the prevailing assumption that it's better and that anything that isn't natural is bad is just people naturally (pun not intended) being afraid of something they don't understand. I think the more people are exposed to GMO the more accepted it'll become over time.

The GMO issues is... meh. I joke a lot that I wish California had pushed through their GMO labeling, because they'd find out that half of the stuff in a supermarket was made with GMOs in some way or another. In modern day, gene splicing is a technology that is usable, if fairly new. But it's a better option than what we used to do to try and get new genetic variations, and we can more precisely control what we get. Here in America, and I believe the EU and Australia, we have government organizations that confirm the safety of our foods long before we eat them. If gene splicing was dangerous, you'd have found out when they tried it on corn and wheat before it hit the supermarket. Because most of that is GM for crop yield and resistance.

GMOs are mostly bad when they're used to exploit the farmers Sometimes people that develop GM-plants modify them in a way so that the farmers cannot get any useable seeds from them, so the farmers have to keep buying seeds after every crop, but if the farmers DO end up getting a seed from the GM plant and it grows on their land the people that developed the plant could SUE the farmer since the GM plants are owned by the developers. The only way to keep fruits edible for a bit longer is to store them at the fridge. Low temperatures slow down movement of molecules therefore reactions take place at a much lower rate, ripening fruits a bit slower than if they were left in room temperature. They are gonna ripen and rot anyway though, thats inevitable.

Generally I'm not really fond of genetically modified foods for a number of reasons, but I heard about the banana problem a while ago and I'd say it's a reasonable use of genetic modification	and I would buy it. There's also a lot of genetic modification on crops to be more resistant against bugs and diseases so they don't have to use pesticides anymore which is also good. Then there's gmo that just wants to increase the income of a plant by enhancing their size or whatever which just feels wrong to me. If those plants go wild they could cause serious damage to the ecosystems by eliminating the wild variant. I think that's a serious problem to be considered. What would we do if the Panama disease mutates again, like it did before, and we don't have a wild banana to modify our bananas with it? That's a serious issue. So we really have to think about if we actually need to modify a plant or not. If we need to, like with the Cavendish banana, then I think it's acceptable. If it's not that urgent and just to make even more money with something, I don't think it's enough of a reason to allow genetic modification.  Fun fact: the artificial banana flavor we often taste in sweets was designed after the died out sort of banana, so it actually doesn't taste like the bananas we now eat at all!

That "chocolate banana in the microwave" one is actually pretty grounded in reality. I've never tried it in the microwave (and don't plan to), but when I was a kid we often made similar things in a campfire. You split a banana, put some chocolate into it (we usually used milk chocolate), sprinkle some cinnamon, and maybe even add a few mini-marshmallows if you want. Then wrap it up in foil and put it in the embers of the fire for a few minutes. Usually you'd eat it with some ice cream on the side. I think it's quite delicious.

gmo is great for the sake of survival, preservation and discovery.  I mean change is the only thing that is constant. Going against the river current wont get you anywhere. GMO is great if done with good intentions and not capitalized.
Fun genetic banana fact: the gene structure of banana crops is basically the same, meaning there's very little genetic variation. That's why banana crops are devastated so quickly once disease strikes. Because they're all basically the "same", none of them can resist the disease. On the other hand, wild bananas have much more diverse genes, so one individual is very different from the other, and that's why they can survive the fungus cited above.
On GMOs I got this to say, when you eat a "natural" plant how many "mutant" genes do you think you ingest? It's MILLIONS, genes by nature mutate and change, we just don't see the difference because it takes several generations for those changes to become apparent. All GMO does is introduce those changes in a very controlled and goal oriented way. So instead of waiting several dozen generations for a mutation to occur naturally and then having to breed the seeds from those we can do it by injecting the mutations we need. It simply saves time, money and effort, and yes it also saves on energy and pollution because you can grow a successful modified crop in a shorter time and with fewer resources than having to wait and hope you get it.  And for all those worrying, altered DNA we EAT does NOT influence our own DNA because: 1: It gets digested and broken down into smaller chemicals 2: Even if it could get into your blood stream (at which point you'd have to worry more about sepsis) there is no method of injecting the altered DNA into your own genome
Once again, Dave is amazing eating some of the stuff that is made.

Thanks for the fascinating video! About the GMO's, I definitely do not support it. When GMOs are weaponized against farmers so they have to buy new seeds every year, then that's a nope from me. In this case with the cavendish banana, then I am all for it. I do want to clarify though that there is a clear difference between hybrid and GMO. Hybrid is when I cross two plants, let's say two tomato plants, and I keep crossing them to get new seeds. GMOs is taking the DNA from one plant, animal, or whatever and putting it in another, so it's not natural or even close to hybrid. We've done hybridization for thousands of years, sometimes on purpose and sometimes by accident. GMO is not natural and cannot be done on accident. You are purposely taking dna from one and putting it into something else. So for the people who keep mixing the two, I hope this clarifies things.

Everytime someone brings up being against GMOs, I think of this quote from Nobel Prize winner Norman Borlaug: "Some of the environmental lobbyists of the Western nations are the salt of the earth, but many of them are elitists. They've never experienced the physical sensation of hunger. They do their lobbying from comfortable office suites in Washington or Brussels. If they lived just one month amid the misery of the developing world, as I have for fifty years, they'd be crying out for tractors and fertilizer and irrigation canals and be outraged that fashionable elitists back home were trying to deny them these things."  Now, he was talking about people reacting to the use of technology in the developing world but honestly I think it applies to GMO as well. People don't realise how they take these things for granted and go up in arms against them, but if they actually had to live without them they would have other ideas. Think about how desperate the world is for a Covid vaccine right now, even though the "anti-vax" community has been on the rise for years. It will be the same with anti-GMO if banana crops are threatened.  Besides, bananas are already plenty modified from their "natural" form, they have been selectively bred. Google "wild banana" and you'll see something more resembling the original banana - tiny and full of seeds that you don't want to eat. Splicing two different types together to get disease resistance is not going to make you grow an extra arm or leg. Plus organisations like the FDA and other regulatory bodies are already super strict on safety testing. In California, there has been debate about whether they need to label coffee with a proposition 65 warning. Coffee. Which has already been drunk for generations in large quantities across the whole world with no noticable negative affects (unless you really overdo it, moderation in all things of course).By the time they make it to your local supermarker, anything genetically modified in your food is going to be pretty darn safe.

GMOs are the best way to feed the world nutritious products. Have you heard anything about golden rice? It's super helpful. Genetic modification of food is something humans have been doing since the start of agriculture through selective breeding and later forced mutation  (such as radioactive farming producing the ruby grapefruit). Using scientific technology to control this process is safer than older practices. And the reason there is only one kind of edible banana is they're modified to not produce seeds. They have an additional set of chromosomes which prevents normal meiotic divisions. Anyone who eats bananas thinking they're non GMO is just uninformed.
GMOs are also known by another name, selective breeding. Brassica oleracea, for example, gives us at least nine different vegetables, including broccoli, cauliflower, cabbage, brussel sprouts, etc. We've done it with animals too, otherwise we wouldn't have the different breeds of dogs or horses or cats, or practically all domestic animals. The only difference between GMOs and selective breeding is that we're getting more immediate results with genetic tampering rather than a slow progression through generations. Heck, if you really look at it, humans are also a product of it, as it's assumed that one reason why blond hair and blue eyes is common in Europe is because European ancestors saw the recessive genes as attractive and therefore tended to have kids that also carried the genes. It's really interesting to look at how different genes express themselves, and honestly, wild bananas are actually still edible, you just have to eat around the seeds. Otherwise our ancestors wouldn't have eaten them and bred them to have smaller seeds.

I've just graduated with a botany degree and am all for GM. Especially if it's cisgenics where genes from the same group of plants is taken from one and Inserted into another. This is just sped up cross breeding and cuts years/decades of work out of creating a perfect cross breed such as the resistant Cavendish mentioned.
Technically, bananas don't come from trees. What you see is not a tree. It may look like a tree, but so do Palm Trees. But like Palm Trees, they aren't trees. I'm not sure what Banana Plants are related to. But Palm Trees are actually a type of grass. Also, did you know that bananas are berries?  Also, the thing about Panama Disease is that yes, it wiped out a species of banana, and could wipe out another. But did you know that the Cavendish Banana is a crossbreed between that now extinct banana and another species? So perhaps bananas won't be wiped out. But bananas as we know them today, perhaps. And with that species that's resistant, that could work, though that would be even more hybridization that could affect modern bananas. So even if those scientists are successful, it could still end up changing the banana as we know it.  And as for people who are against GMOs, I don't understand why they can't do research to see that it's not a bad thing. In fact, all plant-based foods in grocery stores are in some way GMOs. Do people have issues with scientists taking genes from one plant to putting them into another as opposed to crossbreeding them? Crossbreeding and selective breeding are two types of GMOs. Would they be opposed if farmers just cross-pollinated the two bananas and hope for the best rather than rely on scientists who can actually pinpoint the specific genes responsible for the desired effects?

Personally, I think that preserving a food by genetically engineering them to be resistant to certain diseases, is not a bad thing. And if you look back into history we have been engineering our plants and animals, for a lot longer. Yes, those things were done with cross-breeding those animals and plants. But in the end it is engineering, because we are eliminating what we consider undesirable traits, or adding desirable traits. Take the carrot for example, they were not originally the bright orange color we know. Originally they were actually a beige/white. Wild corn, is not as big as the corn we are familiar with. As for animals, well we don't have to look far and merely watch our own pets. Life-stock itself is also engineered. And yes, most of it wasn't done in a lab, but in the end it is engineering. Human involvement in the process of development of species.  One also has to consider the impact humanity has on food production and consumption. We are by nature a ravenous beast and our numbers are growing only larger as time passes. We cannot afford to lose something like a banana, it would cause famine in certain areas.  My conclusion is that genetically engineering our food is only a step in our own evolution to keep our own species alive. But one should also keep the implications of it in mind and keep an eye on the ethical question, so we don't cross certain boundaries.

One of the weird thing about the GMO discussion is that our "normal" crop plants are not really any more natural than genetically modified ones. They've been selectively bred for thousands of years. "Natural" rice has basically nothing to do any more (genetically) with wild rice. Wheat is a hodgepodge genetic mix of about three different origin species. And "natural" bananas (such as the Cavendish banana) are genetically clones (that's why individual banana sorts are so vulnerable, while others aren't - they're not actually strains or sorts of plant like with other crops, but genetically identical clones). The reason why these bananas are reproduced by essentially cloning the plants? They've been bred so much that they don't really produce seeds any more, because we don't want seeds in our bananas. So you can't do it any other way. There is very little natural about the way these crops work any more.

Kurzgezagt made an excellent video on the topic of GMOs and how we've been using them for an absolute eternety. Like insulin, which people don't seem to have a problem with, but scoff at the idea of modifying foods. They explained different ways that we've been helping crops, like apart from pesticides - engineering plants to be toxic, as in - insects that eat them - die. And the toxins are designed to be non-harmful to humans ( in the same way chocolate is not poison to us, but is deadly to dogs ). As they say - GMOs are an ally, not a threat in the fight to protect nature and minimize our impact on the environment. Worth a watch.

Thank you for the video, it was really interesting.¬†  To answer your question at the end of the video: it's a problem with many other foods (vegetables, fruit or cereals). The source of the problem is rather the need of our current society for uniformity and over profitability. Producers (large or small) are pushed to practice monoculture. It follows that the genetic variety of the plants is reduced and they are therefore less resilient to disease, just like humans in case of inbreeding. Moreover, intensive cultivation weakens the soil in the long term, so it would be necessary to favour pluri-cultures (cultivating different species or families on one land) or to do permaculture.  This is my opinion on the subject as a florist who has made botanical studies.   As a franche native speaker I written  this text in French then translate it so I post the original version and hope I didn't make any translation mistake:  Merci pour la video c‚Äô√©tait tr√®s int√©ressant.  pour repondre a ta questuion en fin de video: c‚Äôest un probl√®me qui se retrouve avec  beaucoup d‚Äôautres alliments ( l√©gumes, fruits ou c√©r√©ales). La source du probl√®me c‚Äôest plut√¥t le besoin de notre soci√©t√© actuel d‚Äôuniformit√© et de sur rentabilit√©e. Les productuer (petit ou grand ) sont pousser √† pratiquer la monoculture. Il endecoule que la vari√©te genitique des plante est reduite et elles sont donc moins r√©sistantes aux maladies tout comme les humains en cas de consanguinit√©. De plus la culture intesive affaiblis les sols sur le long terme, il faudrais favoriser les pluri-cultures (cultiver diff√©rente esp√®ce ou famille sur une terre) ou de faire de la permaculture. C‚Äôest mon opinion sur le sujet en tant que fleuriste qui a fair des √©tude de botanique.

To be honest, as long as it is safe for consumption, I do not care about if it's genetically modified in a lab or not and because every country has a food regulation there is no way it would be sold in shops before this is known.   If we are all honest here, the main reason why we don't like the idea of genetically modified food is because we don't trust it to be safe... which means it's simply the fear of the unknown.  In the past watermelons were mostly seeds and a little bit of edible watermelon. The rest was that white ...pith? Not sure if that is the correct name for it. Over time, with selective breeding, we shrunk the size/amount of seeds and increased the amount of edible watermelon, so it's more like what we know today where the pith(?) is a thin layer coating the inside of the skin. Lemons have almost doubled in size to few hundred years ago and I'm sure many other foods have changed due to selective breeding. But not many have a problem with this as we know what selective breeding is, whereas genetic modification sounds sciency/important/need a degree to do it rather than just a good knowledge of the plant and how it works so we're nervous.  If you break down what the Dr. did, and yes it will be massively simplified as I am NOT A DOCTOR!!!!!! All he did was find a type of banana, the wild one, that was resistant to the disease, and then used selective breeding to allow the banana we all eat to now be resistant as well. The only difference was that he did it in a lab to speed up the process and accuracy as, if memory serves me well, selective breeding doesn't always work as the new plant may not get the desired end result. Like if you wanted your kid to have blue eyes so you choose a partner who has them and the kid is born with brown instead. With selective breeding it can take a long time before the new plant gets what you wanted it to get from the old plant, as you can't simply communicate to tell it. Just like how you can't tell the embryo in the womb to take the blue eyes gene to be born with the desired blue eyes. However, genetic modification seems to speed up the process by taking the specific thing you wanted from the old plant, in this case the resistance to the disease, and putting it in the new plant.   After which, I have no doubts, the 'new' or modified plant would be rigorously tested to ensure safety for consumption before replacing the old food and no one would probably notice unless they were informed.  So no, I don't have a problem with safe for consumption food that has gone through selective breeding, whether it's in a lab or in a field. The only issues I have with food is when they are unsafe for consumption or when the main way they are grown/harvested ruins the planet.

all food is GMO so its not really an issue.
As someone studying Plant Science at University, Panama disease is a huge topic for us and using gmo's seems to be a good solution. Using traditional breeding methods (e.g. selection), we generally change about 1.500.000.000 gene base pairs in order to create new resistances for certain diseases. While for example, editing the genome with CRISPR is much, much more precise and we only have to change 30 gene base pairs for the same effect.   So while people think GMO's are doing very unnatural things to our crops, it is actually just speeding up what we already did before, and it is genetically changing a lot less in our crops then what we were changing before.
Finally, some positive news about GMOs! They are not inherently bad, the technology has just been misused by some companies. GMOs can be such amazing solutions for a whole array of problems.

GMO foods have massive potential and I support them in general... I definitely don't support any type of food being controlled by a single company in that way, farmers should be able to control their own crops.
GMOs are perfectly safe. People are scared of ‚Äúchemicals‚Äù in their food, even though everything is made of chemicals, and people are scared of GMO even though all food contains genes. GMOs can do anything from keeping your apples from browning once cut, to saving the banana, or even preventing children from going blind by making a rice that produces more vitamin A. Not to mention each new product is rigorously tested and held up to probably a higher safety standard than most other foods.

I actually do the cooked banana with chocolate a fair bit - I get allergic reactions to raw banana, but heat destroys the enzymes I cannot eat - and it's one of the ways I can get the purest banana taste while also heating it. However!! One shouldn't do it inside the bananaskin. That smells bad and the taste of the cooked peel leaks into the banana and that's not good. Peel the banana and put it on a plate with a little chocolate spread on it (using chunks of chocolate has a tendency to just burn them on the outside before they're melted on the inside since you can't stir them), and then pop that in the mikrowave for about a minute or until the banan starts to show signs of bubbles on the surface. That's pretty delicious. Especially if you add a dollop of icecream and have it as a treat. However, in most cases I would prefer a raw banana if I could have it, and I certainly wouldn't cook it the way the hack suggested.

Hi, succulent enthusiast here! I'm not sure that's an aloe. From what I can see, it looks a lot more like a gasteraloe to me, or maybe an alworthia or just plain haworthia. That doesn't really change the experiment though. I was totally expecting root rot as soon as I saw the "hack."  If you actually want babies like this to grow, then 1. leave pups with the mother plant until they are at least 1/3 the size of the mother plant and have their own roots, or 2. suspend them in a cup with the baby root system hanging OVER, but not IN water. Keep in mind that haworthias go dormant in summer and their roots may die back if you keep on watering them, so leave those alone.

Ugh I hate fake videos like the ones you showed as they are unfair to the public.  People believe them and try them out, only to be disappointed. They should be ashamed of themselves.
As a scientist I am completely pro-GMOs. I don't work in the food industry at all but I have enough understanding about how it works to see that the fact that something is GMO doesn't make it dangerous in any way. If you look at the banana example, in old times what you would do would be to try to crossbreed the two banana species to get a resistant variety that also tasted good. The difference is that with current technology we can simply introduce the resistance gene and save 50 years of plant crossings.
The big reason a disease like that can wipe out the entire population of bananas is that all the bananas we eat are 'clones' - that is to say cavendish bananas are fully sterile and new trees can only be made by methods like replanting root cuttings from an existing tree or via modern tissue culture. The reason for this is that they have an odd number of copies of their genome (specifically they have three copies, making them triploid), meaning that when they go to make seeds with meiosis, the resultant seed cells get one good copy of the genome and one partial mangled copy, and cannot survive. The plants are perfectly fine and healthy otherwise, their fruit just isn't chock full of hard seeds, and they can't reproduce without our help. The clonal reproduction unfortunately means that every individual plant has exactly the same genetic weaknesses, and can be wiped out by all the same things :(
Ann goes so hard when it comes to research. What a legend.

Love you and Dave‚ù§‚ù§‚ù§‚ù§‚ù§‚ù§‚ù§‚ù§‚ù§‚ù§‚ù§‚ù§‚ù§‚ù§‚ù§‚ù§‚ù§‚ù§‚ù§‚ù§‚ù§‚ù§‚ù§
I think that people are blowing the GMO issue out of proportion. All it does is accelerate the process that happens naturally via breeding. Instead of breeding plants together until you find the one with the exact properties you want, you can genetically modify them and save a huge amount of time.  I‚Äôve worked in the vegetable seeds business and it can very well take 5+ years until you get the desirable gene combination.
I come from a family of old style farmers, and let me tell you, the whole "OGM is bad" thing is stupid: we've been doing that kind of thing literally since the beginning of the farming era of humans, most of what we eat is already a hybrid of some kind - Cavendish Banana trees don't have seed anymore and as such are CLONED trees basically, and wouldn't survive as a species withou us. We've done that to both plants and animals, both for eating, company or aesthetics. As long as there are controls so that we don't end up eating things that are toxic in large quantities, I don't see the problem.
I think I saw an article where they talked about a "super freezer" somewhere North (Spitsbergen), where they freeze in all kinds of seeds of plants in case something happens. It is like a huge safe filled with seeds.  In case of something happening, the seeds are there to replant and reproduce plants and crops. Most plants and crops are in some way genetically modified so they will grow faster, better production and also being able to be digest in the body. Which causes for low biodiversity, as almost all plants, crops and grains we eat are similar. If, like the bananas, a fungus grows and kills the banana plant, it will/can kill all banana plants in the entire world, due to low biodiversity. Those seeds stored are all different and have big biodiversity. Crossing certain seeds and plants makes them more diverse and can save the banana plantation, like the professor is doing.  If we talk about GMO, it doesn't necessary mean bad. It can be modified to make it more digestible, have better properties and characteristics. For example native starches aren't always good thickeners, by modifying them they become better thickeners and have a better use than unmodified starch. (If I remember correctly from my lectures).

Our geography teacher is your kind of pro-environmentalist type guy and we expected him to oppose GMOs too. He showed us a Greenpeace video protesting GMOs, but surprisingly he was all for it. He felt that there weren‚Äôt really any arguments or studies which actually properly show GMO foods as dangerous to human health, at least for things like this. It‚Äôs especially important in a world where the population is just going to keep growing, food security gets worse and we have to keep finding ways to feed everyone, especially in those poorer countries where they don‚Äôt have as much as we do in the western world, and it‚Äôs not without precedent to find scientific solutions seeing as way back in the early 20th century, when scientists like Fritz Haber found a way to increase fertiliser production and essentially prevented a huge famine. The problem with having just one variety of banana, is that genetic modification is just a temporary solution. When a new fungus or disease pops up the whole crop will again be at risk. In my most humble opinion the best solution would be to breed different varieties, so the risk is spread. The disadvantage is that different breeds will require different ways of growing and processing. Bananas are relatively cheap because at the moment they are all the same and can thus all be processed in the same way. We need to weigh what is more important: cheap bananas with the risk of them going extinct, or more expensive bananas with less risk of them all being wiped out at once.

As a person who is critical of GMO: I think most people who are afraid of GMOs don't know much about them so they prefer avoiding them at all costs, which is a decent strategy, however I know a little bit about the history and how they work, and in general GMOs are not harmful. However, corporations use GMOs to exploit farmers and even crops themselves. There is no ethics involved in the intentions and actions of companies like Monsanto who wish to only milk as much profit as possible out of their creations, frequently ruining the lives of farmers intentionally.  I don't believe humble attempts at fighting food scarcity are evil.  I believe corporations like Monsanto creating crops that can only be used with their own pesticide and suing farmers because their Monsanto brand DNA was found in their fields due to the natural germination process is absolute irrefutable evil.

Piss poor attempt at trying to use the banana's potassium as a natural fertilizer. 1. A single banana has far too much potassium in it that it'll cause an overdose to the plant and the plant's nitrogen intake will be negatively affected, so the sun will only burn/starve the plant as the photosynthesis that turns the sun's rays into its food cannot happen.  2. Soil is required as it's not hydroponic growing and thus requires a compilation of different nutrients to keep the plant healthy and a stable living environment.

The chocolate microwave banana thing is so close to a really traditional thing here in the UK, but you don't use a microwave for it. Instead, you cut a single knife slit along the banana and stuff it with chocolate buttons, then wrap it in foil and either bake it, put in on the barbecue, or in a campfire, until the banana is baked and the chocolate is melted. Cavendish bananas are basically all clones as they can't reproduce sexually (they have no seeds anymore). This makes them more vulnerable to new pathogenes because they can't adapt. Also, selective breeding, cross-breeding and cloning plants using their ability to reproduce non-sexually with shoots is in the end similar enough to GMOs, although the process is slower. Just make sure the GMO plants are infertile, so they don't spread uncontrollably. And don't just make GMO plants in order to be able to use more aggressive pesticides or to exploit poor farmers (looking at you, Bayer/Monsanto).

My thoughts re GMO is that technically, the cavendish banana is the result of selective  growing practices, and surely that‚Äôs like a form of (natural) genetic modification. In fact, a lot of our food is the result of crops being selectively chosen to the point where they are nutritionally ‚Äúweaker‚Äù or more susceptible to certain issues. I‚Äôm personally pro GMO within crop development but not within e.g dairy and meat farming. We have to consider that food scarcity is a real problem, and if in the west we want to continue encouraging the growth of mono crops and continue to have food ‚Äúfads‚Äù that can destroy local economies and food sources (Im thinking if the issues with quinoa and avocados which have both lead to local food shortages for indigenous communities), we also need to accept that there may need to be external interference for those crops to grow at the rates we desire or to continue to grow with resistance to strain specific issues

For the Aloe vera on banana hack they record the video on reverse. They took the already rooted aloe vera on banana footage first, cut the root, and then record the rootless aloe on the vase. GMO is frustrating, because there's really nothing wrong with the plants! You're absolutely in the right to be suspicious of the companies that do the genetic modification, companies like Bayer's Monsanto are famous for developing plants that are infertile, so farmers have to buy the seeds again, and suing the socks off farmers who end up with some Monsanto seeds on their fields. But we've been genetically modifying plants since we first started farming them. Everyone eats GMOs, which is especially clear in crops like corn that, like the banana, are just not worth eating if they're not domesticated, aka, genetically modified. Genetic modification has also been used in other staple crops like rice, to create a strain that's resistant to flooding, and one that has enhanced vitamin A to combat a common vitamin deficiency in impoverished rice-eating areas.  I genuinely try to avoid the "GMO Free" labels they put on stuff here in Canada, because I feel like it really feeds into a dangerous myth about the dangers of GMOs! No food company is out here publicly developing and selling Lex Luthor fruits that'll kill you!! While you should worry about company's money-grubby-ness, it's not for food safety reasons, but rather because they're incentivized to sell as much of their product as they possibly can to farmers, and don't much care if the farmers can really afford them.

For the peel 'bbq', it helps if you shred the peels into irregular and thinner pieces, so it takes on a similar look to pulled pork, and you cook it until the texture softens and it *feels* like pulled pork. The hack video didn't do it justice, you need to saute the skins longer and then add the bbq sauce towards the end. Otherwise, yeah, you might as well do zucchini noodles! Of course, it isn't meant to be exactly like meat...just close enough to be a good sandwich :).  To make it more accurate as well you need 2-4 skins - so when I get bananas I will save the peels in a baggie (which I also refrigerate) as I eat them and usually in less than 3 days I have enough to make it worth the trouble. As someone who has studied biotechnology and understands the process of Genetically Modifying food, I really don't understand why it is hated on so much As we all know (and as Ann has talked about before), the line between natural and artificial is very blurred so the argument of it being unnatural is bogus If done with good intentions, like to bring about pest or disease resistance like in the case of the Cavandish banana, it is actually very good because we will only be swapping out a gene or 2 and genetics is a very widely studied field of research so we can pin point out any potential side effects in advance with a relatively high degree of correctness. So, I really don't understand the big dance around it being bad Let me know if I missed out anything

As a biochemist I approve the use of gene engineering to enhance bananas. It has already been done on rice to increase the production of beta carotenes (golden rice) in order to combat vitamin A deficiency in populations that do not have all that many sources for carotenes in their diets. People seem to be afraid of GMO because they don't fully understand the process of gene engineering, and that seems to also apply to the people making the laws about the use of GMOs. It would be lovely to raise awareness about what genetic modification really is.

I've never understood the anit-GMO fad. Someone clearly went on a marketing campaign to say that GMOs= evil chemicals or some such. I have issues with hormones and pesticides to a degree (the potential lasting impacts of hormones in people who eat them, and the environmental  impact and detrimental effects of pesticides on good insect populations and such). But GMOs are like...75% of the food we eat. The historic versions of most fruit and veg are so different!  So many apple varieties were created through grafting and controlled cross-pollenation.  What Professor Dale did was just advanced cross-breeding. Instead of selecting the best specimens of both species over several generations of plant and breeding them together, he expedited the process.  GMOs are one of the least damaging things we can do to our food supplies, as far as I understand. I mean, it's not like that gene will effect US! Last time I checked, I'm not a banana tree!

No issues with GMOs at all.  I've been researching transgenics for over a decade and there is just nothing to be concerned about. Certain organizations (like the organic consumer's association and greenpeace) are anti-GMO partly because of what a huge money-maker the so-called organic produce is, but mostly out of ignorance.  In some cases, I am sorry to say, it seems to be willful ignorance. We've been eating food that has been bred using transgenic technology for over three decades (hundreds of years if you count hybridization as a genetic modification process) and there has not been a single recorded case of negative health outcomes that can be attributed to genetic modification as a breeding process.

I think that the issue of genetically modified food is a complex issue. I am rather sceptical about modifying plants, because that gives people a lot of freedom to mess around with the nutrients inside the plant, the ecosystem around the plants and their global hold on the particular type of food. But those are not only issues particular to genetic modification alone but an issue on many different levels. And in some way the way we‚Äòve kept breeding certain types of a plant into our ideal fruit or vegetable has also automatically shrunk the natural variety of these plants. And as we can see with this example, it might be even harder to decide when genetic modification might be appropriate after all. I find it really difficult to choose a standpoint, but I do think we should always be cautious about how we play with our environment.
This is a great application of GMOs. As opposed to what Monsanto (I think the company was renamed) do. That thing about the wild bananas being resistant to the disease made me think of the phylloxera crisis. Basically, this was a disease that devastated vines in Europe in the 19th century. Then they found out that some american varieties were resistant to the disease. So they planted american vine stocks and then grafted on them the european varieties, and this has pretty much stopped the phylloxera from devastating the vines. However, after a bit of thinking, I guess that may not be possible with the banana trees since they're not actual trees ü§î

So here's some in depth explanation for the gardening hacks: some plants are capable of completely regenerating from a single node. So if you plant a thick branch in soil (with a node fully covered with soil) it can grow new roots and leaves and quickly become a whole new plant. Examples of such plants include mint, money plant, some types of crotons potatoes(the eyes of the potato are nodes), etc.  In the video of course the craft channel gave no information about having to use a stem with nodes and the way the stem needs to be cut.  About the other 2 hacks, like Ann said Banana peel actually makes excellent compost however compost means decomposed. At this point many different types of bacteria have acted on the banana and the chemical composition of a fully decomposed banana is completely different from a normal banana and most plants will not be able to use the nutrients in such a state and thus start to die and rot.

If you wish, try this for the chocolate banana: Bake the bananas whole until the skins split. Remove from the oven and let cool a bit. Open the fruit where the skin split and add chocolate ganache and cream or ice cream. In South Africa, the option of course is to add a shot of Amarula Creme.  As for the GMO debate, I think many people's objection is that this modification takes place in a lab where "it doesn't happen naturally". They also usually have a fundamental misconception of what science does, which is the reason people think "GMOs are dangerous", that "the government wants to track them with vaccines" and that chemicals in the water supply (to paraphrase the ever incompetent Alex Jones) "turn the frogs gay". In my opinion the lab is doing in a few months or years what it would take a natural cultivar decades or even centuries. It's sickening that there are people actively fighting against the science that can ensure food security. Just my opinion.

As humans, we‚Äôve been doing some form of GMO since we started farming.   I have no issue with GMOs. The only issue I have is related, but it‚Äôs not the process itself that‚Äôs the problem. My issue is the massive corporations that take GMO technology, hoard it for themselves, and force farmers to pay extortionate amounts for their seeds. And those farmers will be sued into oblivion if they try to keep any seeds from last harvest. There was even a case where a company (I think it was Monsanto, pre-Bayer buyout) sued a farmer for using their GMO seeds, because they‚Äôd blown over onto his property from his neighbour‚Äôs farm. He himself wasn‚Äôt actually using those seeds, but his neighbour was.   So that‚Äôs my issue. It‚Äôs capitalism, basically. There‚Äôs no scientific evidence that GMOs are inherently harmful. But plenty of evidence that capitalism is.

As long as we continue to study GMO and it's impact on humans, then I am all for them.  GMO crops are less of a burden on natural environments. They allow plants to be more hardy in certain environments, they allow for quicker growth and they can be resistant to various diseases and insects.  If these banana crops were left to their own devices, then we'd see more fungus-free land cleared, (environments for numerous animals, insect species and other plants) for new crops and then potentially the end of this crop.

The hate against GMOs is so overblown. Almost every food we eat has evolved/changed since it was originally discovered and humans have chosen which traits they want things to keep through selective breeding. Genetically modifying is not just cutting out a gene and pasting it to another organism in a lab, it happens naturally through evolution. Any change to a gene is genetically modifying, it can happen naturally, or in a lab. Taking a wild banana and mixing it with a commercial banana is tame compared the selective breeding humans have done to animals.

I'm all for GMO foods on one condition: I think they need a kill switch. Think about how many foreign plants and animals kill out native species and become pests. I don't want trees (on a farm that is not well maintained for whatever reason) to start spreading and infringing on the resources other nearby plants and trees need. Here in Queensland, Australia, we have a bad history of bringing in pests to deal with pests, only to lose all control over the one we brought in. If the modified plant is more resistant to problems, it may also be harder to kill off if it's no longer needed. I think that, if they're going to implement changes to protect them, they should also implement changes that make them more vulnerable to destruction by other (more controlled) farming methods. That may be vulnerability to some sort of herbicide or whatever, I dunno, I'm not a farmer. Let's just not create any more pests for ourselves, eh?

Personally, I‚Äôm pro GMO in cases like the one mentioned in the video. If it could help the food supply in rural area‚Äôs, that‚Äôs good! I believe a kind of rice was developed that has a lot more nutrients, and of course that‚Äôs absolutely wonderful for people who can‚Äôt afford to buy the fruits and veggies that naturally have those nutrients. However, I‚Äôm very against the GMO‚Äôs from companies like Monsanto. The genetically modified foods didn‚Äôt have to be pollinated by bees anymore, and somehow the plants poisoned a big part of the bee population. Also Monsanto has caused entire area‚Äôs to go bankrupt because of their copyright on the GMO plants. So, I do think that GMO‚Äôs can be helpful, especially in a world with global warming where food is going to be a lot more scarce due to floods and drought, however we should keep the environmental impact in mind when using GMO‚Äôs. Especially since they are often used in a mono-culture, which can dry out the ground.
Putting milk-chocolate in a banana and warming it up is an old hiking/scouting tradition in the Nordic countries. Original you put the banana in a tinfoil wrap and put it on the charcoals of the campfire until they are ready. Today it is also popular during summer times to do them on the barbecue.  This is called campfire-banana, camp-banana, hiking-banana or scouting-banana. It is as traditional as s¬¥mores are in some countrys.

GMO's for pathogen resistance is fine by my standards. As are crops that are made more nutritious or tolerant to low irrigation or crops that need less fertilizers and pesticides   It's when companies tailor GMOs for profit, I get angry. Glofish for example,  grains that "suicide" so that farmers have to buy new seed stock every year, or patented crops that drive small and subsistence farmers off the land.

Considering GMO, I'd say I agree with the facts that it has major benefits in these situations since the main use of it is somewhat altering the banana in such a way that it provides it with resistance to such a nasty threat. If the sole purpose is resistance to certain other nasty organisms, then it would be common sense to integrate genetic modification into the mix, in case it provides absolutely no drawbacks and will just as easily be fit for human consumption.  What I do think that some people would argue against is the fact that GMO has bad reputation because it turns "regular" produce into these oversized meaty plants, hardly resembling the original product in the first pace. The main use case of GMO in this situation isn't building resistance as much as it is just generally increasing profits for the "producers".  The idea for the debate sounds wonderful and I definitely think you should do a future episode where you'd cover in-depth about some genetic modifications, in a way as you did with the banana. I'm doing my homework but i have to stop to watch this debunking video.
As someone who studied environmental conservation and has actually genetically modified bacteria during a laboratory exercise in school, I am all for GMO. There is no theoretical difference between GMO and selective breeding, except that GMO can be done faster, more targeted and safer than selective breeding. It could take thousands of years to create a resistant strain of bananas, so genetically modifying them is probably our best way to go.
