Ann Reardon the DebunQueen!!!
Side note: "Panama disease" (Fusarium wilt) is indirectly the reason why artificial banana flavor doesn't taste like "real bananas". Standardized artificial banana flavoring was developed when the primary variety of bananas exported to and consumed in North America was the Gros Michel cultivar. The last major outbreak of Panama disease forced most banana plantations to switch to Cavendish bananas, which had a less intense aroma and flavor which did not resemble the by-then industry-standard artificial banana flavor as closely. In short, artificial banana flavor tastes like what bananas _used_ to be like - a synthetic record of a "lost" natural flavor.

On the note of bananas, you should look into the various species available in the southern states of India because we don't eat the Cavendish variety as often as the rest of the world. In my home garden my grandma grows our own bananas (I feel every household that has a back garden will have a bunch of the banana plants)  I am not aware of the scientific name of the species but they smaller in size, and stouter and a lot more sweeter. Another species that my mom loves is actually red in colour and has a firmer consistency even when ripe (she says it's called Kappa banana) and the species that is shaped like the Cavendish but is green even after ripening is called Robusta. There are sooooooo many species of bananas. So even if one goes out due to disease I have a feeling others will pick up. Also I am all for scientists coming together to help find solution to agricultural travesties like disease wiping out a species, like you said its more than us not getting to eat it, it's another person's livelihood.

We do make a dish here in Kerala, India out of raw banana peel . We take a raw banana peel it and keep it aside, the raw fruit is sliced, dried in sunlight and powdered which is an awesome baby food . With the banana peel we first dice them to small pieces and saut√© them in coconut oil along with a little mustard seeds , curry leaves , shallots and sliced green chillies . When half cooked a paste of grated coconut  is added , a little garlic paste , turmeric and fennel seeds  .    This dish is called ‚Äòthoran‚Äô which is rich in potassium and fibre.

Adding a gene from one kind of banana to another kind of banana seems to me to be essentially the same as what happens when cross breeding banana plants.     GMO becomes dodgy when mixing genes from inherently incompatible species to make something that could not exist naturally.

how do you stay healthy anne
The GMO debate is so tricky, almost more tricky in this situation when we are talking about the genes from one banana transferred to another banana type. It is almost as close to selective breeding as you can get, it isn't like they are inserting the gene for a natural fungicide from a completely different poisonous plant.  On one hand there is still a lot about coding and non-coding DNA that we don't understand, but on the other hand we are learning more every day and we can perform a lot of tests on these bananas to see if they produce any metabolites that are harmful before consumption.  It is a can of worms without getting into the moral and ethical dilemmas because like everything there are often more than two sides to a story.  You could even argue that humans should be more willing to expand into other fruit types which would allow us to move away from monocultures, which can be bad for the environment, and embrace foods that are more idea to each climate and provide better nutrition.  I'll stop rambling now, I am entirely biased because I avoid bananas as I am somewhat reactive to them, and my realm is animal science not horticulture.

14:05 I'd like to disagree. Cooked banana is delicious and definitely there's a reason to cook that. Fried banana is tasty. Just chopped the banana. Make a thick batter. Put the chopped banana in. Take a spoon and just fried a clump of it.  Or, have you tried banana roast? Take an unripe banana, roast it over a charcoal, no flame, flatten it with a big board or a big flat of a knife, roast a bit, then make a sauce from brown sugar and coconut milk. Just melt and disolve brown sugar to your liking and then add coconut milk and a touch of salt. Just pour the sauce over the banana and put a little bit of cheese and that's it. Try it

to everyone who wants a plant leaf to grow roots just like they claimed in the third hack: the leaf has to have a node (a part of the stem that is a little bit thicker) in order to grow roots, but not every plant can be propagated with this method, so google it! if your plant has a node, you can just pop it in some water and it will grow roots:) btw, the leaf in the video is a monstera deliciosa leaf which can actually be propagated in water, so if it had a node and they hadn't put it inside a banana, this would have workedüå±

Those roots are not from another plant, they're probably just water roots. Lots of thin roots to take in water from the soil (or glass of water) quickly so the plant doesn't drown. A plant that has grown in better environment would have stronger, thicker roots. Also the leaf they stuck in the banana doesn't seem to have any root nodules, it probably wouldn't even grow.
